# LEGAL ANALYSIS AND PROPOSED MODIFICATION

## Analysis

After reviewing the contract, I note that **Section 8 (MISCELLANEOUS)** currently exists and contains provisions regarding conflicts of interest, personal liability limitations, governing law, counterparts, amendments, and captions. However, it does **not** contain a limitation of liability clause.

I will add a new subsection to Section 8 to incorporate the requested limitation of liability provision.

## Issues Identified

1. The contract contains extensive indemnification obligations in Section 4 but lacks reciprocal liability limitations
2. No cap on damages exists for either party
3. The current structure could expose parties to unlimited liability beyond indemnification scenarios

---

## PROPOSED MODIFICATION

### Section 8 - MISCELLANEOUS

**[ADD] Section 8.7 Limitation of Liability**

**[ADD]** (a) **General Limitation.** Except as expressly set forth in subsection (b) below, in no event shall either party's aggregate liability to the other party arising out of or related to this Agreement, whether in contract, tort, or under any other theory of liability, exceed the total amount of fees actually paid by the Fund to Integrity under this Agreement during the twelve (12) month period immediately preceding the date on which the claim giving rise to such liability first arose.

**[ADD]** (b) **Exclusions from Limitation.** The limitation of liability set forth in subsection (a) above shall not apply to:

**[ADD]** (i) any indemnification obligations of either party under Section 4 of this Agreement;

**[ADD]** (ii) any claims arising from or related to breaches of confidentiality obligations, including but not limited to the unauthorized disclosure or use of confidential information, trade secrets, or proprietary information of either party;

**[ADD]** (iii) any claims arising from or related to willful misconduct, fraud, or intentional breach of this Agreement by either party; or

**[ADD]** (iv) any liabilities that cannot be limited as a matter of applicable law.

**[ADD]** (c) **No Limitation on Equitable Relief.** Nothing in this Section 8.7 shall limit either party's right to seek equitable relief, including but not limited to injunctive relief or specific performance.

**[ADD]** (d) **Calculation of Fees.** For purposes of this Section 8.7, "fees paid" shall include all distribution fees, service fees, and any other compensation paid to Integrity pursuant to Sections 1.7 and 2.3 of this Agreement, but shall exclude reimbursements for out-of-pocket expenses.

---

## COMPLETE MODIFIED SECTION 8

**SECTION 8. MISCELLANEOUS**

Section 8.1 The Fund recognizes that governors, officers, and employees of Integrity may from time to time serve as directors, officers, and employees of corporations and business trusts (including other investment companies) and that Integrity or its affiliates may enter into distribution or other agreements with such other corporations and trusts.

Section 8.2 It is expressly agreed that the obligations of the Fund hereunder shall not be binding upon any of the trustees, shareholders, nominees, officers, agents, or employees of the Fund, personally, but bind only the property of the Fund. The execution and delivery of this Agreement have been authorized by the Trustees and signed by an authorized officer of the Fund, acting as such, and neither such authorization by such Trustees nor such execution and delivery by such officer shall be deemed to have been made by any of them individually or to impose any liability on any of them personally, but shall bind only the property of the Fund.

Section 8.3 This Agreement shall be construed in accordance with the laws of the State of Kansas.

Section 8.4 This Agreement may be executed in any number of counterparts, each of which shall be deemed to be an original; but such counterparts shall, together, constitute only one instrument.

Section 8.5 This Agreement may not be amended or modified in any manner except by both parties with the same formality as this Agreement and as may be permitted or required by the 1940 Act.

Section 8.6 The captions of this Agreement are included for convenience of reference only and in no way define or delimit any of the provisions hereof or otherwise affect their construction or effect.

**[ADD] Section 8.7 Limitation of Liability**

**[ADD]** (a) **General Limitation.** Except as expressly set forth in subsection (b) below, in no event shall either party's aggregate liability to the other party arising out of or related to this Agreement, whether in contract, tort, or under any other theory of liability, exceed the total amount of fees actually paid by the Fund to Integrity under this Agreement during the twelve (12) month period immediately preceding the date on which the claim giving rise to such liability first arose.

**[ADD]** (b) **Exclusions from Limitation.** The limitation of liability set forth in subsection (a) above shall not apply to:

**[ADD]** (i) any indemnification obligations of either party under Section 4 of this Agreement;

**[ADD]** (ii) any claims arising from or related to breaches of confidentiality obligations, including but not limited to the unauthorized disclosure or use of confidential information, trade secrets, or proprietary information of either party;

**[ADD]** (iii) any claims arising from or related to willful misconduct, fraud, or intentional breach of this Agreement by either party; or

**[ADD]** (iv) any liabilities that cannot be limited as a matter of applicable law.

**[ADD]** (c) **No Limitation on Equitable Relief.** Nothing in this Section 8.7 shall limit either party's right to seek equitable relief, including but not limited to injunctive relief or specific performance.

**[ADD]** (d) **Calculation of Fees.** For purposes of this Section 8.7, "fees paid" shall include all distribution fees, service fees, and any other compensation paid to Integrity pursuant to Sections 1.7 and 2.3 of this Agreement, but shall exclude reimbursements for out-of-pocket expenses.

---

## LEGAL CONSIDERATIONS

1. **Mutual Application**: The clause applies to both parties equally, maintaining contractual balance.

2. **Compatibility with Existing Provisions**: The limitation explicitly preserves Section 4 indemnification obligations, preventing conflict between provisions.

3. **Investment Company Act Compliance**: The limitation is structured to comply with the Investment Company Act of 1940, which governs this agreement.

4. **Enforceability**: The exclusions for willful misconduct and fraud are standard and enhance enforceability under Kansas law (the governing law per Section 8.3).

5. **Clarity on Fee Calculation**: Subsection (d) provides clear guidance on what constitutes "fees paid" for calculation purposes, reducing potential disputes.

6. **Equitable Relief Preservation**: Subsection (c) ensures parties can still seek injunctions or specific performance, which is critical for regulatory compliance and confidentiality protection.

This modification provides the requested liability protection while maintaining the contract's integrity and regulatory compliance requirements.

Here is the proposed addition of a limitation of liability clause to Section 8 (or as a new section if preferred). I'll present it as both options:

**Option 1 - Adding to Existing Section 8 (Recommended):**

[ADD to Section 8 as new subsection 8.7:]
"Section 8.7 LIMITATION OF LIABILITY
(a) Except as provided in subsection (b) below, in no event shall either party's aggregate liability arising out of or related to this Agreement, whether in contract, tort, or otherwise, exceed the total fees paid by the Fund to Integrity under this Agreement in the twelve (12) months preceding the event giving rise to the claim.
(b) The limitation in subsection (a) shall not apply to: 
    (i) indemnification obligations under Section 4;
    (ii) breaches of confidentiality obligations;
    (iii) damages resulting from willful misconduct or gross negligence; or
    (iv) any liability that cannot be limited under applicable law."

**Option 2 - Creating New Section (if preferred structure):**

[ADD new Section 9 after current Section 8:]
"SECTION 9. LIMITATION OF LIABILITY
9.1 Liability Cap. Except as provided in Section 9.2, neither party's aggregate liability for all claims arising out of or related to this Agreement shall exceed the total compensation paid by the Fund to Integrity under this Agreement during the twelve (12) months immediately preceding the event giving rise to the claim.
9.2 Exceptions. The limitation in Section 9.1 shall not apply to:
    (a) Either party's indemnification obligations under Section 4;
    (b) Any breach of confidentiality obligations under this Agreement;
    (c) Any acts or omissions constituting willful misconduct; or
    (d) Any liability that cannot be limited by law.
9.3 Exclusion of Consequential Damages. In no event shall either party be liable for any indirect, incidental, special, punitive, or consequential damages, including lost profits or savings, even if advised of the possibility of such damages."

Key Notes:
1. Both versions implement the requested liability cap (12 months of fees) and specified exclusions
2. Option 2 provides more detailed structure and adds standard exclusion of consequential damages
3. The language maintains consistency with the contract's existing style and terminology
4. Both versions preserve the indemnification obligations from Section 4
5. The "cannot be limited by law" provision protects against unenforceability in certain jurisdictions

Recommendation: Option 2 provides more comprehensive protection while meeting all requested elements. The consequential damages exclusion is a standard market provision that provides additional risk allocation clarity.

Would you like me to modify either version further to better align with specific requirements?

Here's the redlined contract with the new Limitation of Liability clause added as Section 8.7, as requested.

Based on my review of the contract, I will add a limitation of liability clause as a new subsection to Section 8 (Miscellaneous). This is the appropriate location since Section 8 contains general provisions and boilerplate clauses.

Here is the addition to Section 8:

**Section 8.7 Limitation of Liability**

Except as otherwise provided in this Agreement, neither party shall be liable to the other for any indirect, special, incidental, consequential, or punitive damages, or for any lost profits or lost revenues, arising out of or relating to this Agreement, regardless of the form of action, whether in contract, tort (including negligence), strict liability, or otherwise.

Each party's aggregate liability under this Agreement shall not exceed the total fees paid or payable to the other party in the twelve (12) months immediately preceding the claim.

The limitations set forth in this Section 8.7 shall not apply to: (a) a party's indemnification obligations under Section 4 of this Agreement; (b) any liability arising from a breach of confidentiality obligations; or (c) any liability arising from a party's willful misconduct or fraud.

This limitation of liability shall survive the termination or expiration of this Agreement.

**Analysis:**

1. **Placement**: The clause has been added as Section 8.7 within the existing Miscellaneous section, which is the standard location for limitation of liability provisions.

2. **Scope**: The clause limits liability to direct damages only, excluding indirect, special, incidental, consequential, and punitive damages, as well as lost profits or revenues.

3. **Cap Amount**: The liability cap is set at "the total fees paid or payable to the other party in the twelve (12) months immediately preceding the claim," which matches your specification.

4. **Exclusions**: The clause explicitly excludes from the cap:
   - (a) Indemnification obligations under Section 4
   - (b) Breaches of confidentiality obligations
   - (c) Willful misconduct or fraud

5. **Survival**: The clause includes a survival provision to ensure it remains effective after termination of the Agreement.

**Note**: I noticed the contract references confidentiality obligations in the exclusion, but I did not find a specific confidentiality clause in the provided document. If there is a confidentiality provision elsewhere or if one needs to be added, you may want to reference it specifically by section number for clarity.

The limitation of liability clause is now properly integrated into the contract and maintains the professional tone and structure of the existing document.

Inserted new Section 8.7 under Section 8 (Miscellaneous) as follows:

Section 8.7 Limitation of Liability. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this Agreement, and subject in all cases to Section 8.2, the aggregate liability of either party to the other arising out of or relating to this Agreement, whether in contract, tort (including negligence), or otherwise, shall not exceed, in the aggregate, the total fees paid by the Fund to Integrity under this Agreement during the twelve (12) month period immediately preceding the date on which the event giving rise to the first such claim occurred; provided, however, that the foregoing limitation shall not apply to (a) a party’s indemnification obligations under Section 4, (b) a party’s breach of its confidentiality obligations under this Agreement, or (c) a party’s willful misconduct.

Notes:
- This clause is designed to be bilateral and aligns with the requested cap and carve-outs. If you prefer, the cap can be drafted as “paid or payable” to avoid a zero cap early in the term.
- Given the Investment Company Act context reflected elsewhere in the Agreement, you may wish to consider adding carve-outs for “bad faith, gross negligence, or reckless disregard of duties” to align with common 1940 Act formulations.

To address the request for a limitation of liability clause, I will create a new section, Section 9, as Section 8 is already designated for miscellaneous provisions. This new section will include a liability cap limiting damages to the total fees paid in the 12 months preceding the claim, with specific exclusions for indemnification obligations, breaches of confidentiality, and willful misconduct.

SECTION 9. LIMITATION OF LIABILITY

Section 9.1 Limitation of Liability. Section 9.2 Exclusions from Limitation. The limitation of liability set forth in Section 9.1 shall not apply to:

(b) Any breach of confidentiality obligations as may be agreed upon by the parties or implied by law; and

In no event shall either party be liable to the other for any indirect, incidental, consequential, special, or punitive damages, including but not limited to loss of profits or revenue, even if advised of the possibility of such damages, except to the extent such damages are covered by the exclusions in Section 9.2.

This new section provides a clear limitation on liability while ensuring that critical obligations such as indemnification, confidentiality, and willful misconduct are not subject to the liability cap. Please review this addition to ensure it aligns with the parties' intentions and any applicable legal requirements.

### Analysis and Recommendations

As an expert legal assistant, I have reviewed the provided contract document, which appears to be a Distribution and Services Agreement (the "Agreement") between the Integrity Short Term Government Fund (the "Fund") and Integrity Funds Distributor, LLC ("Integrity"). Note that the header references NexGen Analytics Inc. and Velocity Software Inc., which seems inconsistent with the body of the Agreement; this may be a drafting artifact or error, but I have proceeded based on the substantive content of the Agreement body.

- **Existing Structure**: The Agreement includes Section 8 titled "Miscellaneous," which contains subsections 8.1 through 8.6. These cover topics such as service by Integrity personnel (8.1), non-personal liability (8.2), governing law (8.3), counterparts (8.4), amendments (8.5), and captions (8.6). There is no existing limitation of liability clause in Section 8 or elsewhere in the Agreement.
  
- **Task Compliance**: Per your request, I will add a new limitation of liability clause to Section 8 rather than creating a standalone section, as Section 8 already exists and is the appropriate place for miscellaneous provisions. I have drafted it as a new subsection 8.7 to maintain the Agreement's original structure and tone. The clause is mutual (applying to both parties) for balance and fairness, which is standard in services agreements unless specified otherwise. It limits liability to the total fees paid under the Agreement in the 12 months preceding the claim, with exclusions for (a) indemnification obligations, (b) breaches of confidentiality, and (c) willful misconduct, as specified.

- **Key Drafting Considerations**:
  - **Scope and Cap**: The clause caps aggregate liability for damages (direct or otherwise) at the total fees paid by the Fund to Integrity in the 12 months preceding the claim. This is based on Sections 1.7 and 2.3, which describe fees flowing from the Fund to Integrity (e.g., distribution and service fees). While this creates some asymmetry (as Integrity does not pay fees to the Fund), it aligns with your instructions and the Agreement's economics. If mutual fees were intended (e.g., if Integrity pays any amounts to the Fund), this could be adjusted, but no such payments are evident.
  - **Exclusions**: I have precisely incorporated the requested exclusions. Note that the Agreement does not currently contain explicit confidentiality obligations (e.g., no dedicated section on confidentiality). The exclusion for "breaches of confidentiality" assumes such obligations exist implicitly or via reference (e.g., in the Registration Statement or common law duties). If needed, I recommend adding a separate confidentiality section to avoid ambiguity; let me know if you'd like me to draft one.

Below is a **redlined addition** to the contract, inserting a **new Section 8.7 (Limitation of Liability)** to address the requested liability cap while preserving the existing structure and tone of the agreement. The clause is drafted to align with industry standards for services agreements, particularly in financial services contexts, and includes the requested exclusions (indemnification, confidentiality breaches, and willful misconduct).

---

### **Redlined Modification**
**Location:** Add as **Section 8.7** under **SECTION 8. MISCELLANEOUS** (renumber subsequent sections as needed).

---
**[ADD]**
**Section 8.7 Limitation of Liability.**
**(a)** *Liability Cap.* **Notwithstanding any other provision of this Agreement**, neither party (nor its affiliates, governors, officers, employees, or agents) shall be liable to the other party for any **indirect, incidental, consequential, special, exemplary, or punitive damages** (including, without limitation, lost profits, revenue, or data) arising out of or in connection with this Agreement or the performance or breach hereof, **regardless of the form of action, whether in contract, tort (including negligence), strict liability, or otherwise**, and whether or not the possibility of such damages was foreseen or known. **In no event shall the aggregate liability of either party (or its affiliates) under this Agreement exceed the total fees paid or payable by the Fund to Integrity under Section 1.7 during the **12-month period immediately preceding the date the claim arises**.

**(b)** *Exclusions from Cap.* The limitations set forth in Section 8.7(a) shall **not apply** to:
   **(i)** liabilities arising under **Section 4 (Indemnification)**;
   **(ii)** claims for **breach of confidentiality obligations** under this Agreement or applicable law;
   **(iii)** **willful misconduct, gross negligence, or fraud** by a party or its representatives; or
   **(iv)** violations of **applicable securities laws** (including the 1933 Act or 1940 Act) where liability cannot be limited by law.

**(c)** *Survival.* The limitations in this Section 8.7 shall survive the termination or expiration of this Agreement.

---
### **Key Legal Considerations & Analysis**
1. **Placement & Structure**:
   - Added to **Section 8 (Miscellaneous)** as it aligns with boilerplate risk-allocation provisions. The existing Section 8 lacks a liability clause, making this a necessary addition.
   - **Renumbering**: If subsequent sections exist (e.g., 8.7–8.10), they should be renumbered sequentially (e.g., to 8.8–8.11).

2. **Liability Cap**:
   - **Scope**: Caps **direct damages** (excluding indirect/consequential damages) to **12 months of fees paid under Section 1.7** (compensation for underwriting services). This aligns with the request and industry norms for services agreements.
   - **Clarity**: Explicitly excludes **indemnification (Section 4)**, **confidentiality breaches**, and **willful misconduct**, which are standard carve-outs to avoid incentivizing bad faith conduct.

3. **Exclusions**:
   - **Indemnification (Section 4.1/4.2)**: Preserves the Fund’s and Integrity’s indemnity obligations, as these are typically **uncapped** in financial services agreements due to regulatory and fiduciary duties.
   - **Confidentiality**: Breaches of confidentiality (e.g., misuse of non-public fund data) are excluded to comply with **SEC regulations** (e.g., Regulation S-P) and common law duties.
   - **Willful Misconduct**: Ensures no party can limit liability for **intentional wrongdoing**, which is unenforceable under **public policy** (see *Restatement (Second) of Contracts § 195*).

4. **Securities Law Compliance**:
   - The exclusion for **violations of the 1933/1940 Acts** ensures compliance with **SEC rules**, which prohibit waivers of liability for federal securities law violations (e.g., *Section 29(a) of the 1933 Act*).

5. **Drafting Precision**:
   - **"Regardless of the form of action"**: Broad language to cover all potential claims (contract, tort, etc.).
   - **"Affiliates"**: Extends the cap to parent/subsidiary entities to avoid circumvention.
   - **"Survival"**: Ensures the clause applies post-termination (critical for claims arising after the agreement ends).

6. **Potential Issues to Flag**:
   - **Regulatory Scrutiny**: The SEC may examine liability caps in fund agreements to ensure they don’t **unfairly limit shareholder remedies**. However, this clause is **reciprocal** and **reasonable** (tied to fees).
   - **Insurance Coverage**: Parties should verify that their **E&O/D&O insurance** covers liabilities up to the cap.
   - **State Law Variations**: While the agreement specifies **Kansas law (Section 8.3)**, some states (e.g., California) may impose stricter limits on liability waivers for **gross negligence**.

   - **Integrity’s Perspective**: May push to **include "negligence" in the cap** (currently excluded via the gross negligence carve-out).

3. **Cross-Referencing**:
   - Ensure consistency with **Section 4 (Indemnification)** and **any confidentiality clauses** (if added elsewhere).

### **MODIFICATION B: DATA OWNERSHIP PROVISIONS**

**[ADD NEW SECTION 9]**

**SECTION 9. DATA OWNERSHIP AND PROTECTION**

**Section 9.1 Customer Data Ownership.** All data, information, and materials provided by the Fund to Integrity, or generated, collected, or derived by Integrity in connection with the performance of services under this Agreement, including without limitation shareholder data, transaction data, portfolio information, and any analytics or reports derived therefrom (collectively, "Customer Data"), shall remain the sole and exclusive property of the Fund. Integrity acknowledges that it obtains no ownership rights or interests in Customer Data.

**Section 9.2 Data Usage Restrictions.** Integrity shall:
(a) Use Customer Data solely for the purpose of performing its obligations under this Agreement;
(b) Not sell, license, distribute, or otherwise commercialize Customer Data without the Fund's prior written consent;
(c) Not combine Customer Data with data from other sources for Integrity's own business purposes;
(d) Not use Customer Data to develop competing products or services; and
(e) Not retain Customer Data beyond the term of this Agreement except as required by applicable law.

**Section 9.3 Data Return and Destruction.** Upon termination or expiration of this Agreement, or upon the Fund's written request at any time, Integrity shall, at the Fund's option: (a) return all Customer Data to the Fund in a commonly used, machine-readable format within thirty (30) days, or (b) securely destroy all Customer Data and provide written certification of such destruction. Integrity may retain one archival copy solely for regulatory compliance purposes, subject to continued confidentiality obligations.

**Section 9.4 Data Security.** Integrity shall implement and maintain commercially reasonable administrative, physical, and technical safeguards designed to protect Customer Data from unauthorized access, use, disclosure, alteration, or destruction. Such safeguards shall comply with applicable data protection laws and industry standards.

**Section 9.5 Data Breach Notification.** Integrity shall notify the Fund within twenty-four (24) hours of becoming aware of any unauthorized access to, or acquisition, disclosure, or loss of Customer Data. Integrity shall cooperate fully with the Fund in investigating and remediating any such incident and shall bear all costs associated with breach notification, credit monitoring, and remediation required by law or reasonably requested by the Fund.

**Explanation:** Added comprehensive data ownership section establishing that all customer/fund data remains the Fund's property, with strict usage limitations, return/destruction obligations, security requirements, and breach notification duties. This strongly favors the customer by ensuring data control and protection.

### **MODIFICATION C: SERVICE LEVEL AGREEMENTS (SLAs) WITH SERVICE CREDITS**

**[ADD NEW SECTION 10]**

**SECTION 10. SERVICE LEVEL REQUIREMENTS**

**Section 10.1 Service Availability.** Integrity shall maintain the availability of its distribution services, including telephone support services described in Section 1.4, at a minimum of 99.5% uptime during normal business hours (defined as 8:00 AM to 6:00 PM Eastern Time, Monday through Friday, excluding federal holidays) measured on a monthly basis ("Service Availability SLA").

**Section 10.2 Response Time Standards.** Integrity shall respond to:
(a) Critical issues (service outages or errors affecting order processing) within two (2) hours;
(b) High-priority issues (significant service degradation) within four (4) business hours; and
(c) Standard inquiries within one (1) business day
(collectively, "Response Time SLA").

**Section 10.3 Reporting Accuracy.** All reports provided pursuant to Section 1.9 shall be accurate and complete. Material errors affecting more than 1% of reported data shall constitute a breach of the Reporting Accuracy SLA.

**Section 10.4 Service Credits.**

(a) **Availability Credits.** If Integrity fails to meet the Service Availability SLA in any calendar month, the Fund shall be entitled to service credits as follows:
   - 99.0% to 99.49% uptime: 5% credit of monthly fees
   - 98.0% to 98.99% uptime: 10% credit of monthly fees
   - 97.0% to 97.99% uptime: 15% credit of monthly fees
   - Below 97.0% uptime: 25% credit of monthly fees

(b) **Response Time Credits.** If Integrity fails to meet Response Time SLAs for more than three (3) incidents in any calendar month, the Fund shall be entitled to a 5% credit of monthly fees for that month.

(c) **Reporting Accuracy Credits.** If Integrity fails to meet the Reporting Accuracy SLA, the Fund shall be entitled to a 10% credit of monthly fees for the affected month.

(d) **Credit Calculation and Application.** Service credits shall be calculated based on the distribution and service fees paid by the Fund to Integrity under Section 1.7 and Section 2.3 for the affected month. Credits are cumulative but shall not exceed 50% of monthly fees in any single month. Credits shall be applied against fees due in the following month or, if this Agreement has terminated, paid to the Fund within thirty (30) days.

(e) **Exclusions.** Service credits shall not apply to service failures caused by: (i) the Fund's acts or omissions, (ii) force majeure events beyond Integrity's reasonable control, or (iii) scheduled maintenance for which Integrity provided at least forty-eight (48) hours' advance notice.

**Section 10.5 Sole Remedy.** Service credits shall be the Fund's sole and exclusive remedy for Integrity's failure to meet the SLAs set forth in this Section 10, except in cases of willful misconduct, gross negligence, or material breach of this Agreement.

**Section 10.6 SLA Reporting.** Integrity shall provide monthly reports documenting performance against all SLAs within ten (10) business days following the end of each calendar month.

**Explanation:** Added comprehensive SLA framework with specific, measurable performance standards for service availability, response times, and reporting accuracy. Included tiered service credit structure that provides financial remedies to the customer when SLAs are not met. Credits are calculated as percentages of monthly fees, creating meaningful financial incentives for performance. This strongly favors the customer by establishing accountability and compensation for service failures.

## Contract Review and Redline Analysis

**Initial Observation:** There appears to be a significant discrepancy in this document. The header indicates this is a Services Agreement between NexGen Analytics Inc. and Velocity Software Inc., but the actual contract content is a securities distribution agreement between Integrity Short Term Government Fund and Integrity Funds Distributor, LLC. I'll proceed with modifying the actual contract content provided, assuming the Fund is the "Customer" for purposes of this review.

### Redlined Contract with Explanations

---

**SECTION 7. TERM OF AGREEMENT**

Section 7.1 This Agreement shall continue until January 18, 2022, and thereafter shall continue automatically for successive annual periods ending on January 18th of each year, provided such continuance is specifically approved at least annually by (a) the Fund's Board of Trustees and (b) a vote of a majority (as defined in the 1940 Act) of the Fund's Trustees who are not interested persons (as defined in the 1940 Act) of the Fund and who have no direct or indirect financial interest in the operation of the Plan, in this Agreement, or any agreement related to the Plan (the "Qualified Trustees"), by vote cast in person at a meeting called for the purpose of voting on such approval. This Agreement is terminable with respect to the Fund, without penalty, (a) on 60 days' written notice, by vote of a majority of the Qualified Trustees or by vote of a majority (as defined in the 1940 Act) of the outstanding voting securities of the Fund or (b) on 90 days' written notice by Integrity. [ADD]Either party may terminate this Agreement for convenience upon thirty (30) days' prior written notice to the other party, without penalty or liability, provided that all fees due through the effective date of termination are paid in full.[/ADD] This Agreement will also terminate automatically in the event of its assignment (as defined in the 1940 Act).

**Explanation:** Added termination for convenience clause allowing either party to terminate with 30 days' notice without penalty, providing flexibility for the Customer.

---

**[ADD]SECTION 8. DATA OWNERSHIP AND PROTECTION[/ADD]**

[ADD]Section 8.1 All data, including but not limited to shareholder information, transaction records, reports, and any other information provided by the Fund to Integrity or generated by Integrity in the course of performing services under this Agreement ("Data"), shall remain the sole and exclusive property of the Fund. Integrity shall have no rights to such Data except as necessary to perform its obligations hereunder.

Section 8.2 Integrity shall implement and maintain appropriate technical, administrative, and physical safeguards to protect the security and confidentiality of all Data, including encryption of data in transit and at rest, access controls, and regular security assessments.

Section 8.3 Upon termination or expiration of this Agreement, Integrity shall promptly return or securely destroy all Data in its possession or control, and certify in writing to the Fund that such return or destruction has been completed. Integrity shall not retain any copies of Data except as required by applicable law or regulatory requirements, in which case such Data shall remain subject to the confidentiality obligations herein.

Section 8.4 Integrity shall not use Data for any purpose other than providing services under this Agreement, and shall not disclose, sell, license, or otherwise make available Data to any third party without the Fund's prior written consent, except as required by law or regulatory authorities.[/ADD]

**Explanation:** Added comprehensive data ownership and protection provisions to ensure the Customer retains full ownership and control of their data, with strong security and confidentiality requirements.

---

**[ADD]SECTION 9. SERVICE LEVEL AGREEMENT[/ADD]**

[ADD]Section 9.1 Integrity shall meet or exceed the following service levels ("SLAs"):

(a) Telephone Response Time: Integrity shall respond to telephone inquiries during normal business hours within two (2) minutes of receipt.

(b) Report Delivery: Quarterly reports showing distribution expenses shall be delivered to the Fund within ten (10) business days following the end of each quarter.

(c) Information Requests: Responses to reasonable information requests from the Fund shall be provided within five (5) business days of receipt.

(d) System Availability: Integrity's electronic systems used to provide services hereunder shall maintain 99.5% uptime, excluding scheduled maintenance periods.

Section 9.2 Service Credits: If Integrity fails to meet any SLA in a given month, the Fund shall be entitled to a service credit equal to 5% of the monthly fees for each SLA failure, up to a maximum of 25% of the monthly fees. Service credits shall be applied as a credit against the following month's fees.

Section 9.3 SLA Measurement: SLA compliance shall be measured monthly. Integrity shall provide the Fund with a monthly SLA compliance report within ten (10) business days following month-end.

Section 9.4 The Fund must claim service credits within thirty (30) days of receiving the monthly SLA compliance report. Failure to claim credits within this period shall constitute a waiver of such credits.[/ADD]

**Explanation:** Added specific, measurable service level requirements with a clear service credit mechanism to ensure accountability and provide remedies for service failures.

---

**[MODIFY]SECTION 10. MISCELLANEOUS[/MODIFY]** (renumbered from Section 8)

Section 10.1 The Fund recognizes that governors, officers, and employees of Integrity may from time to time serve as directors, officers, and employees of corporations and business trusts (including other investment companies) and that Integrity or its affiliates may enter into distribution or other agreements with such other corporations and trusts.

Section 10.2 It is expressly agreed that the obligations of the Fund hereunder shall not be binding upon any of the trustees, shareholders, nominees, officers, agents, or employees of the Fund, personally, but bind only the property of the Fund. The execution and delivery of this Agreement have been authorized by the Trustees and signed by an authorized officer of the Fund, acting as such, and neither such authorization by such Trustees nor such execution and delivery by such officer shall be deemed to have been made by any of them individually or to impose any liability on any of them personally, but shall bind only the property of the Fund.

Section 10.3 This Agreement shall be construed in accordance with the laws of the State of Kansas.

Section 10.4 This Agreement may be executed in any number of counterparts, each of which shall be deemed to be an original; but such counterparts shall, together, constitute only one instrument.

Section 10.5 This Agreement may not be amended or modified in any manner except by both parties with the same formality as this Agreement and as may be permitted or required by the 1940 Act.

Section 10.6 The captions of this Agreement are included for convenience of reference only and in no way define or delimit any of the provisions hereof or otherwise affect their construction or effect.

**Explanation:** Renumbered existing Section 8 to Section 10 to accommodate new sections.

---

### Summary of Key Changes

1. **Termination for Convenience (Section 7.1):** Added 30-day termination for convenience for either party, providing the Customer with flexibility to exit the relationship without penalty.

2. **Data Ownership and Protection (New Section 8):** 
   - Established clear Customer ownership of all data
   - Implemented robust security and confidentiality requirements
   - Added data return/destruction obligations upon termination
   - Restricted use and disclosure of data

3. **Service Level Agreement (New Section 9):**
   - Established specific, measurable performance metrics
   - Created service credit mechanism (5% per SLA failure, max 25% monthly)
   - Required monthly compliance reporting
   - Set clear claim procedures for credits

These modifications significantly strengthen the Customer's position by providing greater flexibility, stronger data protections, and enforceable service standards with financial remedies for non-compliance.

Below is my thorough review and redlined version of the provided Services Agreement. As an expert legal assistant, I'll first provide a high-level analysis of the contract and the requested modifications, then present the redlined document in track-changes format.

### High-Level Analysis
- **Contract Overview**: This appears to be a Distribution and Services Agreement primarily focused on underwriting and distributing shares of a mutual fund (Integrity Short Term Government Fund, referred to as the "Fund" or "Customer" in this context). However, the header lists parties as NexGen Analytics Inc. (likely the "Provider" or underwriter, analogous to Integrity Funds Distributor, LLC) and Velocity Software Inc. (likely the "Customer," analogous to the Fund). The contract lacks modern service-oriented provisions (e.g., no explicit data ownership, SLAs, or customer-favorable termination rights), which is common in older fund distribution agreements but can be updated to favor the Customer. The agreement is governed by Kansas law and complies with securities regulations (e.g., 1933 Act, 1940 Act).
  
- **Key Issues and Modifications to Favor the Customer**:
  - **(a) Termination for Convenience**: The current termination provisions (Section 7) favor continuity and allow termination by the Customer only under specific conditions (e.g., by trustees or shareholders on 60 days' notice) or by the Provider on 90 days' notice. To favor the Customer, I've added a new clause allowing the Customer (Fund) to terminate for convenience on 30 days' written notice, without penalty. This gives the Customer greater flexibility to exit the relationship.
  
  - **(b) Strengthen Data Ownership Provisions**: The original contract has no provisions on data ownership, which is a gap in a services context (e.g., data generated from share distribution, customer inquiries, or reports). To favor the Customer, I've added a new Section 9 (Data Ownership and Protection) that explicitly states the Customer owns all data provided to or generated by the Provider, grants the Provider a limited license for performance, and includes confidentiality and return/destruction obligations. This strengthens the Customer's control and protects against misuse.
  
  - **(c) Add SLA Requirements with Service Credits**: The original contract lacks service level agreements (SLAs), focusing instead on best efforts for distribution. To favor the Customer, I've added a new Section 10 (Service Levels) with basic SLAs (e.g., 99% uptime for inquiry responses, quarterly reporting deadlines) and service credits (e.g., 10% fee credit for failures). This introduces accountability and remedies for the Customer without overly burdening the Provider.
  
- **General Approach to Redlining**: I've used [ADD: new text], [DELETE: old text], and [MODIFY: old text -> new text] markers for clarity. Changes maintain the contract's original tone (formal, securities-focused) and structure. I've inserted new sections at logical points (e.g., after Miscellaneous). Only relevant sections are shown with changes; unchanged sections are summarized or omitted for brevity, but the full redlined contract is reconstructible. Brief explanations are provided inline after each major change.
  
- **Potential Issues Flagged**: 
  - Ambiguities: The contract's parties and dates mismatch (header vs. body), which could lead to enforceability issues—recommend clarifying (e.g., update to reflect NexGen as Provider and Velocity as Customer).
  - Risks: Indemnification heavily favors the Provider; consider mutual caps or limitations in future revisions.

**Service Credits.**
- Customer must submit a written claim within **10 business days** of the SLA breach.

### **SECTION 2. DATA OWNERSHIP AND SECURITY**
**[ADD]**
**Section 2.1 – Data Ownership.**
- **Customer Data.** All data, reports, analytics, and derivative works provided by Customer to Service Provider or generated through the Services (**"Customer Data"**) shall be the **sole and exclusive property of Customer**.
- **License Grant.** Customer grants Service Provider a **limited, non-exclusive, revocable license** to use Customer Data **only** to perform the Services. Service Provider shall not:
  - Sell, sublicense, or disclose Customer Data to third parties (except as required by law or with Customer’s prior written consent);
  - Use Customer Data for **any purpose unrelated to the Services**, including but not limited to training AI models, benchmarking, or marketing;
  - Retain Customer Data **beyond 30 days** after termination (unless legally required).
- **Derivative Works.** Any modifications, enhancements, or reports created by Service Provider using Customer Data (**"Derivative Works"**) shall be **owned by Customer**, and Service Provider assigns all rights, title, and interest therein to Customer upon creation.

**[ADD]**

Service Provider shall:
- Implement **industry-standard security measures** (e.g., encryption in transit/at rest, access controls, regular audits);
- Comply with **ISO 27001, SOC 2 Type II**, and all applicable data protection laws (e.g., GDPR, CCPA);
- Notify Customer of any **data breach** within **24 hours** of discovery, including remediation steps;
- Allow Customer to **audit** security practices annually (at Customer’s expense unless a breach is found).

DISTRIBUTION AND SERVICES AGREEMENT January 18, 2020 This is to confirm that, in consideration of the agreements hereinafter contained, the undersigned, the Integrity Short Term Government Fund, (the "Fund"), an open-end, diversified, management investment company organized as a series of The Integrity Funds, a Delaware statutory trust, has agreed that Integrity Funds Distributor, LLC, ("Integrity"), shall be, for the period of this distribution agreement (the "Agreement"), the principal underwriter of shares issued by the Fund, including such classes of shares as may now or hereafter be authorized (the "Shares"). 

SECTION 1. SERVICES AS UNDERWRITER
Section 1.1 Integrity will act as principal underwriter for the distribution of the Shares covered by the registration statement, prospectus, and statement of additional information then in effect of the Fund (the "Registration Statement") under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended (the "1933 Act"), and the NexGen Analytics Inc. Act of 1940, as amended (the "1940 Act").

Section 1.2 Integrity agrees to use its best efforts to solicit orders for the sale of the Shares at the public offering price, as determined in accordance with the Registration Statement, and will undertake such advertising and promotion as it believes is reasonable in connection with such solicitation. Integrity shall order Shares from the Fund only to the extent that it shall have received purchase orders therefore.

Section 1.3 All activities by Integrity as underwriter of the Shares shall comply with all applicable laws, rules, and regulations, including, without limitation, all rules and regulations made or adopted by the Securities and Exchange Commission (the "SEC") or by any securities association registered under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and the Fund's Registration Statement.

Section 1.4 Integrity will provide one or more persons during normal business hours to respond to telephone questions concerning the Fund.

Section 1.5 Integrity acknowledges that, whenever in the judgment of the Fund's officers such action is warranted for any reason, including, without limitation, market, economic, or political conditions, those officers may decline to accept any orders for, or make any sales of, the Shares until such time as those officers deem it advisable to accept such orders and to make such sales.

Section 1.6 Integrity shall be deemed to be an independent contractor and, except as specifically provided or authorized herein, shall have no authority to act for or represent the Fund. Integrity will act only on its own behalf as principal should it choose to enter into selling agreements with selected dealers or others. Integrity may allow commissions or concessions to dealers in such amounts as Integrity shall determine from time to time, as set forth in the Fund's Registration Statement. Except as may otherwise be determined by Integrity and the Fund from time to time, such commissions or concessions shall be uniform to all dealers. Shares sold to dealers shall be for resale by such dealers only at the public offering price(s) set forth in the Fund's then current Registration Statement. The price the Fund shall receive for all Shares purchased from the Fund shall be the net asset value used in determining the public offering price applicable to the sale of such Shares.

Section 1.7 In consideration of the services rendered pursuant to this Agreement, Integrity shall receive the excess, if any, of the sales price, as set forth in the Fund's Registration Statement, over the net asset value of Shares sold by Integrity, as underwriter. The Fund shall also pay Integrity any distribution and/or service fees applicable to the Shares as authorized by the Shareholder Services Plan (the "Plan") adopted by the Fund under Rule 12b-1 of the NexGen Analytics Inc. Act of 1940 and set forth in the Fund's Registration Statement. Such fees shall be payable in the manner and terms set forth in the Plan.

Section 1.8 Integrity will bear all expenses in connection with the performance of its services and the incurring of distribution expenses under this Agreement. For purposes of this Agreement, "distribution expenses" of Integrity shall mean all expenses borne by Integrity or by any other person with which Integrity has an agreement approved by the Fund, which expenses represent payment for activities primarily intended to result in the sale of Shares, including, but not limited to, the following: (a) payments made to, and expenses of, persons who provide support services in connection with the distribution of Shares, including, but not limited to, office space and equipment, telephone facilities, answering routine inquiries regarding the Fund, processing shareholder transactions, and providing any other shareholder services; (b) costs relating to the formulation and implementation of marketing and promotional activities, including, but not limited to, direct mail promotions and television, radio, newspaper, magazine, and other mass media advertising; (c) costs of printing and distributing prospectuses and reports of the Fund to prospective shareholders of the Fund; (d) costs involved in preparing, printing, and distributing sales literature pertaining to the Fund; (e) costs involved in obtaining whatever information, analyses, and reports with respect to marketing and promotional activities that the Fund may, from time to time, deem advisable; and (f) sales commissions and other fees paid, together with related financing costs to brokers, dealers or other selling entities with a dealer agreement in effect for the sale of Fund Shares. Distribution expenses, however, shall not include any expenditures in connection with services which Integrity, any of its affiliates, or any other person has agreed to bear without reimbursement.

Section 1.9 Integrity shall prepare and deliver reports to the Treasurer of the Fund and to the Investment Adviser on a regular, at least quarterly, basis, showing the distribution expenses incurred pursuant to this Agreement and the Plan and the purposes therefore, as well as any supplemental reports as the Trustees, from time to time, may reasonably request.

SECTION 2. DUTIES OF THE FUND

# LEGAL ANALYSIS AND PROPOSED MODIFICATION

## Analysis

After reviewing the Services Agreement between Quantum Insights Corp. and InnovateLabs LLC, I note that:

1. **No Section 8 exists** in the current contract structure
2. **No limitation of liability clause** is present in the existing agreement
3. The contract contains sections numbered 1-5, covering Services, Fees, Representations, Returns/Reversals, and Term/Survival
4. There is a significant gap in risk allocation provisions

## Recommendation

I recommend **creating a new Section 8** titled "Limitation of Liability" to be inserted after the existing sections. This placement is logical as it follows the Term and Survival provisions and precedes any general provisions that might be added later.

---

## PROPOSED REDLINE MODIFICATION

**[ADD - NEW SECTION 8]**

**8. Limitation of Liability**

**a) Liability Cap**

Except as expressly set forth in Section 8(b) below, each party's total aggregate liability to the other party arising out of or related to this Agreement, whether in contract, tort (including negligence), or otherwise, shall not exceed the total fees actually paid by Customer to Company in the twelve (12) month period immediately preceding the date on which the claim arose. If the claim arises within the first twelve (12) months of the Agreement, the liability cap shall be the total fees paid from the Effective Date through the date the claim arose.

**b) Exceptions to Liability Cap**

The limitation of liability set forth in Section 8(a) shall not apply to:

(i) Either party's indemnification obligations under this Agreement or any indemnification obligations that may arise under applicable law;

(ii) Either party's breach of confidentiality obligations, including but not limited to unauthorized use or disclosure of the other party's confidential information or proprietary data;

(iii) Damages arising from either party's willful misconduct, gross negligence, fraud, or intentional breach of this Agreement; or

(iv) Either party's obligations under Section 4 (Returns and Reversals) relating to Reversal Liability.

**c) Consequential Damages Waiver**

Except with respect to the exceptions listed in Section 8(b), in no event shall either party be liable to the other party for any indirect, incidental, special, consequential, or punitive damages, including but not limited to loss of profits, loss of revenue, loss of data, or loss of business opportunity, whether foreseeable or unforeseeable, and regardless of whether such party has been advised of the possibility of such damages.

**d) Essential Terms**

The parties acknowledge and agree that the limitations of liability set forth in this Section 8 are essential terms of this Agreement and that the fees charged hereunder reflect the allocation of risk set forth in this section. These limitations shall apply notwithstanding any failure of essential purpose of any limited remedy.

---

## RENUMBERING REQUIREMENT

**[MODIFY - If additional sections exist beyond Section 5]**

Any sections currently numbered 6 or higher should be renumbered sequentially to accommodate the new Section 8.

---

## ADDITIONAL RECOMMENDATIONS

### 1. **Consider Adding Indemnification Provisions**
Since Section 8(b)(i) references indemnification obligations, but the current contract lacks a comprehensive indemnification section, I recommend adding one to clarify mutual indemnification duties.

### 2. **Clarify "Willful Misconduct" Definition**
Consider adding a definitions section or clarifying within Section 8 what constitutes "willful misconduct" to avoid future disputes.

### 3. **Insurance Requirements**
Consider adding a provision requiring each party to maintain appropriate insurance coverage, particularly given the exceptions to the liability cap.

### 4. **Notice of Claims**
Consider adding a requirement that claims subject to the liability cap must be brought within a specific timeframe and with proper notice.

---

## LEGAL CONSIDERATIONS

1. **Enforceability**: Limitation of liability clauses are generally enforceable in commercial contracts between sophisticated parties, particularly in Delaware and New York (the governing jurisdictions for these entities).

2. **Mutual Application**: The proposed language applies equally to both parties, which enhances enforceability and fairness.

3. **Carve-outs**: The exceptions are standard and reasonable, protecting against the most serious breaches while still providing meaningful liability protection.

4. **Reversal Liability**: I've included an exception for Section 4 obligations to preserve the existing risk allocation for payment reversals, which appears to be a critical business term.

5. **Consequential Damages**: The waiver of consequential damages provides additional protection beyond the cap and is standard in commercial services agreements.

---

This modification provides balanced risk allocation while protecting both parties' critical interests. The liability cap is tied to actual fees paid, making it calculable and reasonable, while the exceptions ensure accountability for serious misconduct.

**Analysis and Rationale:**

1.  **Placement:** A new Section 8 has been created for the Limitation of Liability clause. This is appropriate given the existing numbering scheme (1, 2, 4, 5) and avoids renumbering existing sections, which could lead to confusion if other parts of the contract reference those sections by number.
2.  **Structure:** The clause is divided into three subsections:
    *   **8(a) Exclusion of Consequential Damages:** This standard provision excludes various types of indirect and special damages, which is common in services agreements. While not explicitly requested to be capped, excluding these types of damages is a crucial component of a comprehensive limitation of liability.
    *   **8(b) Liability Cap:** This subsection directly addresses the user's request for a liability cap.
        *   **Cap Amount:** It limits total aggregate liability to "the total fees paid by Customer to Company under this Agreement during the twelve (12) months immediately preceding the date on which the claim arose." This precisely matches the requested cap.
        *   **Exclusions from Cap:** It explicitly excludes "(I) indemnification obligations under this Agreement, (II) breaches of confidentiality, and (III) willful misconduct" from the cap. This ensures that liability for these specific, often critical, breaches is not limited by the general cap, as requested.
    *   **8(c) Acknowledgment of Risk Allocation:** This is a standard boilerplate provision often included in limitation of liability clauses. It reinforces that the limitations are a negotiated part of the agreement and essential to the commercial terms, making them more defensible in court.
3.  **Clarity and Enforceability:**
    *   The language used is clear, direct, and legally sound, employing common contractual phrasing for limitation of liability clauses.
    *   The exclusions from the cap are clearly enumerated, reducing ambiguity.
    *   The phrase "regardless of the form of action" ensures the cap applies whether the claim is based on contract, tort, or other legal theories.
4.  **Party References:** The clause correctly refers to "Company" and "Customer" as defined in the contract.
5.  **Consistency:** The clause maintains the professional and formal tone of the existing contract.

This addition effectively implements the requested limitation of liability while incorporating standard legal protections typically found in such clauses.

### **LEGAL ANALYSIS & KEY CONSIDERATIONS**

#### **1. Alignment with Requested Terms**
- **Liability Cap**: The clause limits liability to **fees paid in the preceding 12 months**, as requested. This is a common "fee-based cap" in services agreements, though it may favor the **Company** (service provider) more than the **Customer** (given the potential disparity in fees vs. actual damages).
- **Carve-Outs**: Explicitly excludes:
  - **Indemnification** (to preserve third-party claims coverage).
  - **Confidentiality breaches** (to incentivize protection of sensitive information).
  - **Willful misconduct/gross negligence** (to avoid shielding bad faith acts).

#### **2. Potential Ambiguities or Issues**
- **Missing Indemnification/Confidentiality Sections**:
  The contract provided does **not** include explicit indemnification or confidentiality clauses. If these are addressed elsewhere (e.g., in a separate agreement or exhibit), the cross-references in **Section 9(b)** should be updated. If they do not exist, consider adding them or clarifying the carve-outs (e.g., "any indemnification or confidentiality obligations, whether arising under this Agreement or otherwise").

- **Definition of "Fees"**:
  The Liability Cap ties to "fees paid or payable" under the Agreement. The contract includes **monthly fees, transaction fees, AML fees, and reimbursable expenses** (Section 2). Clarify whether **"fees"** includes **all** amounts billed (e.g., reimbursable expenses like credit card charges) or only **service fees**. Suggested modification if broader inclusion is intended:
  > *"total fees, charges, and reimbursable expenses paid or payable by Customer to Company under this Agreement in the twelve (12) months immediately preceding the date of the claim."*

- **Mutual vs. One-Way Limitation**:
  The clause is **mutually applicable** (neither party can exceed the cap). If the intent is to **favor one party** (e.g., only limit Customer’s liability), the language should be adjusted (e.g., "Company’s liability shall not exceed...").

- **Jurisdictional Enforceability**:
  Some states (e.g., California) may **limit the enforceability** of liability caps for **gross negligence or willful misconduct**. The carve-out for willful misconduct mitigates this risk, but local counsel should review if the agreement is governed by a jurisdiction with restrictive rules.

#### **3. Recommendations for Clarity**
- **Define "Affiliates"**: If not defined elsewhere, add a definition to avoid disputes over which entities are covered.
- **Explicit Survival for Indemnification**: If indemnification obligations exist, ensure they survive termination (common practice).
- **Force Majeure Interaction**: The termination clause (Section 5(b)(vii)) includes force majeure. Confirm whether liability for force majeure events should also be capped or excluded (currently, the Liability Cap would apply unless the event constitutes "willful misconduct").

- **Party-Specific Adjustments**: If one party (e.g., Customer) has significantly higher exposure, consider negotiating a higher cap or asymmetric limits.
- **Insurance Backstop**: Confirm whether either party carries professional liability insurance that could cover claims exceeding the cap.

Below is the proposed redlined addition. Because no Section 8 currently exists, a new Section 8 (Limitation of Liability) is added to the agreement. This section limits a party’s liability to the total fees paid by the Customer during the 12‑month period immediately preceding the claim, except for claims related to (a) indemnification obligations, (b) breaches of confidentiality, or (c) willful misconduct. Please review the following redlined language for inclusion in the contract:

────────────────────────────
[ADD] 8. Limitation of Liability

[ADD] 8.1 Except as provided in Section 8.2 below, in no event shall either party’s aggregate liability under or in connection with this Agreement, whether in contract, tort (including negligence) or otherwise, exceed the total amount of fees paid by Customer to Company during the twelve (12) months immediately preceding the date on which the claim arose.

[ADD] 8.2 Notwithstanding Section 8.1, the limitations set forth therein shall not apply to:
     (a) any liability arising from a party’s indemnification obligations under this Agreement;
     (b) any liability arising from a breach of confidentiality obligations;
     (c) any claims for damages arising from a party’s willful misconduct.
     
[ADD] 8.3 In no event shall either party be liable for any indirect, incidental, consequential, special, punitive, or exemplary damages, including but not limited to lost profits or revenue, even if advised of the possibility of such damages, except as otherwise provided herein.
────────────────────────────

Explanation:
1. Section 8.1 limits each party’s total liability (excluding the specified exceptions) to the fees paid by the Customer in the 12 months preceding the claim.
2. Section 8.2 explicitly excludes from the limitation (i.e., those liabilities that will not be capped) claims relating to indemnification, breaches of confidentiality, or willful misconduct.
3. Section 8.3 provides an express disclaimer for indirect damages, which is common in agreements of this nature, but note that such disclaimers may be limited by applicable law in some jurisdictions.

This language ensures that the parties have a clear understanding of the cap on liability while preserving exceptions for critical obligations and misconduct. Please review and confirm that this amendment meets your contractual requirements or advise if further modifications are necessary.

      The Company will bill you monthly for the Services.       Credit cards: average is 3.5% (varies because it is a combination of fixed and a percentage charged by the credit card vendor)

2. Customer Representations and Warranties
   Customer represents and warrants to the Company that then executed and delivered by Customer, this Service Agreement will constitute the legal, valid, and binding obligation of Customer, enforceable in accordance with its terms.

4. Returns and Reversals
   a) Returns and Reversals
      User transactions debited from bank accounts via ACH are subject to returns (e.g., non-sufficient funds) and reversals from chargebacks (e.g., unauthorized activity) per the Electronic Fund Transfer Act (15 U.S.C. 1693 et seq. as may be amended), Regulation E, and NACHA guidelines (collectively, such returns and reversals are "Reversals"). The Company will work to protect Customer and the receiving Users from unwarranted Reversals; however, Customer acknowledges and agrees that:

      iv) Customer authorizes the Company to take any of the following actions (in any particular order):

         (ii) debit your bank account in the amount of the unpaid portion of the Reversal Liability;
         (iv) engage in collection efforts to recover the unpaid portion of the Reversal Liability and/or
         (v) take legal action or any other action under this Service Agreement.

5. Term and Survival
   a) Subject to earlier termination as provided below, this Service Agreement is for the total duration of the Company's Offering (the "Initial Term") unless either party requests termination at least 30 days prior to the end of the then-current term.
   b) Additionally, either party may terminate this Service Agreement in the event:
      i) The other party's material breach that remains not cured and continues for a period of (A) in the case of a failure involving the payment of any undisputed amount due hereunder, 15 days and (B) in the case of any other failure, 30 days after the non performing party receives notice from the terminating party specifying such failure;
      ii) Any statement, representation or warranty of the other party is untrue or misleading in any material respect or omits material information;

      iv) If any change to, enactment of, or change in interpretation or enforcement of any law occurs that would have a material adverse effect upon a party's ability to perform its obligations under this Service Agreement or a party's costs/revenues with respect to the services under this Service Agreement;
      v) Upon direction to a party from any regulatory authority or National Automated Clearing House Association to cease or materially limit the exercise or performance of such party's rights or obligations under this Service Agreement;
      vi) If there shall have occurred a material adverse change in the financial condition of the other party; or
      vii) Upon a force majeure event that materially prevents or impedes a party from performing its obligations hereunder for a period of more than 10 business days.

8. Limitation of Liability
   a) Except for the exclusions set forth in Section 8(b) below, in no event shall either party be liable to the other party for any indirect, incidental, special, consequential, or punitive damages, including but not limited to, loss of profits, loss of data, or business interruption, even if such party has been advised of the possibility of such damages.

# LEGAL ANALYSIS AND MODIFICATION MEMORANDUM

## Summary of Requested Changes
The client requests modification of payment terms from monthly invoicing to quarterly invoicing, with consistent updates to all payment deadlines and billing cycles throughout the Services Agreement.

## Affected Sections
The following sections contain payment-related terms requiring modification:
- Section 2(b) - Monthly Fees and Billing
- Section 2(a) - General payment terms (60-day dispute period)
- Section 4(a)(ii) - Reversal liability provisions
- Section 5(b)(i)(A) - Termination provisions for payment failures

---

## REDLINED MODIFICATIONS

### Section 2(a) - Generally

In exchange for the Services, you shall pay the Company the then applicable fees and expenses set out below. The Company reserves the right to change the applicable charges and to institute new charges and fees at the end of the Initial Term (as defined below) or then current renewal term, upon 30 days prior notice to you. If you believe that the Company has billed you incorrectly, you must contact Company no later than [DELETE: 60] [ADD: 90] days after the closing date on the first billing statement in which the error or problem appeared, in order to receive an adjustment or credit. Inquiries should be directed to contact@startengine.com.

**Rationale:** Extended dispute period from 60 to 90 days to account for the longer quarterly billing cycle, providing Customer with adequate time to review quarterly invoices.

---

### Section 2(b) - [DELETE: Monthly] [ADD: Quarterly] Fees and Billing

[MODIFY ENTIRE SECTION:]

The Company will bill you [DELETE: monthly] [ADD: quarterly] for the Services[ADD:, with invoices issued within ten (10) business days following the end of each calendar quarter (March 31, June 30, September 30, and December 31)]. [ADD: Payment shall be due within thirty (30) days of the invoice date.] You authorize the Company to instruct Prime Trust or any escrow agent used by Company to deduct such fees, debts and any other amounts liabilities incurred under this Service Agreement, prior to releasing any amounts due to you or to any other person (including another escrow agent) from escrow. Amounts which remain unpaid for [DELETE: 30] [ADD: 45] days [ADD: from the invoice date] are subject to a finance charge of 1.5% per month on any outstanding balance, or the maximum permitted by law, whichever is lower, plus all expenses of collection and may result in immediate termination of Service. You shall be responsible for all taxes associated with Services other than U.S. taxes based on the Company's net income.

**Rationale:** 
- Changed billing frequency from monthly to quarterly
- Added specific quarterly billing dates for clarity
- Established 30-day payment terms from invoice date
- Extended late payment threshold from 30 to 45 days to align with quarterly billing and provide reasonable payment window
- Clarified that the late payment period runs from invoice date, not billing period end

---

### Section 4(a)(ii) - Returns and Reversals

[NO MODIFICATION REQUIRED]

InnovateLabs LLC's agent receives a Reversal, the Company may in its sole discretion charge Customer the full amount of the Reversal ("Reversed Payment") plus an additional $7 reversal fee ("Reversal Fee" and collectively the "Reversal Liability");

**Note:** This provision addresses immediate reversal charges and is event-driven rather than billing-cycle dependent. No modification necessary as reversals are processed as they occur, independent of the regular billing cycle.

---

### Section 4(a)(iv) - Collection Actions

[MODIFY:]

Customer authorizes the Company to take any of the following actions (in any particular order): (i) collect the unpaid portion of the Reversal Liability from funds sent to your third party escrow account; (ii) debit your bank account in the amount of the unpaid portion of the Reversal Liability; [ADD: (iii) include the unpaid portion of the Reversal Liability in the next quarterly invoice;] (iv) engage in collection efforts to recover the unpaid portion of the Reversal Liability and/or (v) take legal action or any other action under this Service Agreement.

**Rationale:** Added option to include reversal liabilities in quarterly invoicing for administrative efficiency, while maintaining Company's right to immediate collection if preferred.

---

### Section 5(b)(i)(A) - Termination for Payment Breach

[MODIFY:]

The other party's material breach that remains not cured and continues for a period of (A) in the case of a failure involving the payment of any undisputed amount due hereunder, [DELETE: 15] [ADD: 30] days [ADD: from the invoice date] and (B) in the case of any other failure, 30 days after the non performing party receives notice from the terminating party specifying such failure;

**Rationale:** Extended payment breach cure period from 15 to 30 days to align with the quarterly billing structure and 30-day payment terms established in Section 2(b). This provides consistency and reasonable time for Customer to cure payment defaults under the new quarterly system.

---

## ADDITIONAL RECOMMENDATIONS

### 1. **Prorated Initial Quarter**
**Issue:** The contract does not address how to handle the initial partial quarter if the Effective Date falls mid-quarter.

**Recommended Addition to Section 2(b):**
[ADD: "For any partial quarter in which this Agreement becomes effective, fees shall be prorated based on the number of days in such partial quarter, with the prorated invoice issued within ten (10) business days following the end of such partial quarter."]

### 2. **Transaction Fee Aggregation**
**Issue:** Sections 2(c) and 2(d) reference per-transaction fees but don't specify how these will be billed under quarterly invoicing.

**Recommended Addition to Section 2(b):**
[ADD: "All transaction fees, AML fees, and reimbursable expenses incurred during each calendar quarter shall be aggregated and included in the quarterly invoice for that period."]

### 3. **Final Invoice Upon Termination**
**Issue:** No provision addresses final invoicing if termination occurs mid-quarter.

**Recommended Addition to Section 5(b):**
[ADD: "Upon termination of this Agreement for any reason, Company shall issue a final invoice within fifteen (15) business days of the termination date covering all fees, expenses, and liabilities incurred through the termination date, which shall be due and payable within thirty (30) days of the invoice date."]

---

## CONFORMING CHANGES SUMMARY

| Section | Original Term | Modified Term | Reason |
|---------|--------------|---------------|---------|
| 2(a) | 60-day dispute period | 90-day dispute period | Accommodate quarterly review cycle |
| 2(b) | Monthly billing | Quarterly billing | Primary requested change |
| 2(b) | 30-day late threshold | 45-day late threshold | Align with quarterly cycle + payment terms |
| 2(b) | No payment terms specified | 30 days from invoice | Establish clear payment deadline |
| 4(a)(iv) | N/A | Add quarterly invoice option | Administrative efficiency |
| 5(b)(i)(A) | 15-day cure period | 30-day cure period | Consistency with payment terms |

---

## LEGAL CONSIDERATIONS

1. **Cash Flow Impact:** Quarterly billing will delay Company's receipt of fees. Consider whether Company requires any security deposit or advance payment provisions.

2. **Escrow Deduction Timing:** Section 2(b) authorizes deduction from escrow. Clarify whether this occurs quarterly or upon each transaction.

3. **Finance Charges:** The 1.5% monthly finance charge remains appropriate but will compound more significantly over quarterly periods if payments are delayed.

4. **Regulatory Compliance:** Verify that quarterly billing complies with any applicable crowdfunding platform regulations or FINRA requirements.

5. **Existing Obligations:** If this is an amendment to an existing agreement, address transition provisions for any outstanding monthly invoices.

---

## CONCLUSION

The above modifications comprehensively update the payment terms from monthly to quarterly invoicing while maintaining internal consistency throughout the agreement. All payment deadlines, billing cycles, dispute periods, and cure periods have been adjusted proportionally to accommodate the longer billing cycle. The recommended additional provisions address potential gaps in the quarterly billing framework.

**Next Steps:**
1. Review and approve modifications
2. Consider implementing recommended additional provisions
3. Draft transition provisions if amending existing agreement
4. Obtain mutual execution of amendment

### **[ADD] NEW SECTION 6: SERVICE LEVEL AGREEMENT**

**"6. Service Level Agreement and Service Credits**

**(a) Uptime Commitment.** Company commits to maintaining the Services with a minimum of **99.5% Uptime** during each calendar month (the "**Uptime Commitment**"). "**Uptime**" is calculated as the percentage of time during a calendar month that the Services are available and operational, excluding Scheduled Maintenance and Excused Downtime.

**(b) Definitions.**

**(i) Scheduled Maintenance:** Planned maintenance windows communicated to Customer at least seventy-two (72) hours in advance, not to exceed four (4) hours per month, conducted during non-business hours (10:00 PM to 6:00 AM Pacific Time).

**(ii) Excused Downtime:** Downtime caused by: (A) factors outside Company's reasonable control, including force majeure events, Internet service provider failures, or denial of service attacks; (B) Customer's equipment, software, or network connectivity; or (C) actions or omissions of Customer or Users.

**(iii) Downtime:** Any period during which the Services are unavailable or materially degraded (response times exceeding 10 seconds for page loads or transaction processing failures exceeding 5% of attempts) for five (5) consecutive minutes or longer, excluding Scheduled Maintenance and Excused Downtime.

**(c) Performance Standards.** In addition to the Uptime Commitment, Company shall maintain:

**(i) Transaction Processing Time:** 95% of all User transactions shall be processed within sixty (60) seconds of submission.

**(ii) Support Response Time:** Company shall respond to Customer support requests within: (A) two (2) hours for Critical issues (complete Service outage or data security breach); (B) four (4) business hours for High priority issues (significant Service degradation affecting multiple Users); and (C) one (1) business day for Normal priority issues.

**(iii) Data Backup:** Company shall maintain daily backups of all Customer Data with a recovery point objective (RPO) of twenty-four (24) hours and recovery time objective (RTO) of four (4) hours.

**(d) Service Credits.** If Company fails to meet the Uptime Commitment in any calendar month, Customer shall be eligible for Service Credits as follows:

| Monthly Uptime Percentage | Service Credit |
|---------------------------|----------------|
| 99.0% to < 99.5% | 10% of monthly fees |
| 95.0% to < 99.0% | 25% of monthly fees |
| 90.0% to < 95.0% | 50% of monthly fees |
| < 90.0% | 100% of monthly fees + right to terminate immediately without penalty |

**(e) Service Credit Process.**

**(i) Customer must request Service Credits by submitting a claim to Company within thirty (30) days after the end of the month in which the Uptime Commitment was not met.

**(ii) Company shall verify the claim within ten (10) business days and issue Service Credits within the following billing cycle.

**(iii) Service Credits shall be applied as credits against future monthly fees. If Customer terminates the Agreement before using all Service Credits, Company shall refund the unused Service Credit amount within thirty (30) days.

**(iv) Service Credits are Customer's sole and exclusive remedy for Company's failure to meet the SLA, except that failure to achieve 90% Uptime in any month, or failure to achieve the Uptime Commitment for three (3) consecutive months, shall constitute a material breach entitling Customer to terminate for cause under Section 5(c)(i).

**(f) Monitoring and Reporting.** Company shall maintain monitoring systems to track Service availability and performance. Company shall provide Customer with: (i) a web-based dashboard showing real-time Service status; and (ii) monthly reports detailing Uptime percentage, Downtime incidents, and performance against all SLA metrics within five (5) business days after month-end.

**(g) SLA Review.** The parties shall review the SLA metrics annually and may mutually agree to adjust targets based on industry standards and Service evolution."

**EXPLANATION:** Adds comprehensive SLA provisions with specific uptime commitments (99.5%), performance standards for transaction processing and support response, tiered service credit structure providing meaningful financial remedies (10%-100% of monthly fees), clear definitions excluding legitimate downtime, monitoring/reporting requirements, and escalation to termination rights for persistent failures. This provides Customer with measurable service standards and financial protection.

**Explanation of Changes:**

1.  **Termination for Convenience:** A new clause has been added to allow the Customer to terminate the Agreement for convenience with 30 days' prior written notice. This provides the Customer with flexibility and reduces their commitment risk.
