Short answer up front: A post-termination non-compete is generally void and unenforceable under California Business & Professions Code §§ 16600–16600.5 (as strengthened by SB 699 and AB 1076). To deliver what you want while ensuring enforceability under California law, the clause below (i) provides a 6-month/50-mile non-compete that applies where lawful (e.g., outside California), and (ii) includes a California-specific carve-out that replaces the post-termination non-compete with enforceable protections focused on Confidential Information/trade secrets and an in-term conflict-of-interest restriction. This structure is the standard, California-compliant way to address your goal without creating an unenforceable covenant.

Suggested insertion into Article 3 (Confidentiality and Non-Competition)

[ADD] 3.3 Definitions. For purposes of this Article 3:
(a) “Company Business” means the products and services that the Company markets, sells, or develops and for which the Consultant provided services or about which the Consultant received Confidential Information during the twelve (12) months preceding termination of services.
(b) “Direct Competitor” means any person or entity that markets, sells, or develops products or services that are the same as or substantially similar to the Company Business and compete with the Company for the same customers or prospective customers. Without limiting the foregoing, the Company may from time to time (including at or before termination) deliver to the Consultant a written list of specific Direct Competitors, which list shall be conclusive for purposes of Section 3.4 to the extent consistent with the foregoing definition.
(c) “Restricted Area” means a fifty (50) mile radius of any Company office or facility at which the Consultant primarily performed services during the twelve (12) months preceding termination of services.
(d) “Restricted Period” means the six (6) months immediately following termination of the Consultant’s services for any reason.
(e) “Material Involvement” means the Consultant had direct responsibility for, provided services to, or received Confidential Information regarding, the product/service line or customer/prospect at issue within the twelve (12) months preceding termination of services.

[ADD] 3.4 Post-Term Competitive Activity (Non-California). Except to the extent prohibited by applicable law, during the Restricted Period and within the Restricted Area, the Consultant shall not, without the Company’s prior written consent, directly or indirectly (whether as an employee, consultant, contractor, advisor, officer, director, partner or otherwise) perform substantially similar services to those performed for the Company for any Direct Competitor, but only with respect to the product/service lines or customers for which the Consultant had Material Involvement. Nothing in this Section 3.4 shall prohibit the Consultant from: (i) owning, solely as a passive investment, up to two percent (2%) of the outstanding shares of a publicly traded company; (ii) engaging in work that does not involve the Company Business; or (iii) working for a diversified business so long as the Consultant’s work is wholly unrelated to any Direct Competitor business unit.

[ADD] 3.5 California Carve-Out; Trade Secret Protection. Notwithstanding Section 3.4 (and without limiting Section 7.6), the parties acknowledge that California Business & Professions Code §§ 16600–16600.5 render void any post-termination covenant that restrains a person from engaging in a lawful profession, trade, or business. Accordingly, to the extent California law applies to the Consultant’s work for the Company or to this Agreement, the post-termination non-competition covenant in Section 3.4 shall not apply and is replaced by the following:
(a) During the Term only, the Consultant will not knowingly undertake any engagement that would materially conflict with the Consultant’s duties to the Company by providing substantially similar services to a Direct Competitor with respect to the Company Business for which the Consultant has Material Involvement.
(b) For the Restricted Period, the Consultant shall not, directly or indirectly, use or disclose any Company Confidential Information or trade secrets to (i) solicit, divert, or take away, or attempt to solicit, divert, or take away, any customer, prospective customer, vendor, or business partner of the Company with whom the Consultant had Material Involvement, or (ii) recruit or solicit any employee or contractor of the Company with whom the Consultant worked in the preceding twelve (12) months to terminate his or her relationship with the Company. Nothing in this Section 3.5(b) prohibits lawful competition that does not involve the use or disclosure of the Company’s Confidential Information or trade secrets.
(c) The restrictions in this Section 3.5 are intended solely to protect the Company’s Confidential Information and trade secrets and shall be construed narrowly to that end.

[ADD] 3.6 Reasonableness; Blue-Penciling; Remedies. The Consultant acknowledges that the restrictions in this Article 3 are reasonable in scope and duration and necessary to protect the Company’s legitimate interests in its Confidential Information and goodwill. If any provision of this Article 3 is found to be overbroad or unenforceable in any jurisdiction, such provision shall be modified and enforced to the maximum extent permitted by law in that jurisdiction, and shall not affect the validity of the remaining provisions. The Company shall be entitled, in addition to any other remedies available at law or in equity, to seek injunctive relief to prevent any actual or threatened breach of this Article 3; provided, however, that nothing herein authorizes enforcement of any covenant that is void under applicable law.

Notes and issues to flag
- California enforceability: The above structure avoids an unenforceable California post-termination non-compete by replacing it with confidentiality/trade-secret-based restrictions and an in-term conflict-of-interest covenant when California law applies.
- Governing law (Section 7.10): The Agreement selects New York law and forum. That is fine, but California statutes (BPC §§ 16600–16600.5) apply notwithstanding a contrary choice-of-law if the work is performed in, or the worker resides in, California. The carve-out in Section 3.5 addresses that.
- Define Direct Competitors: To reduce ambiguity and avoid overbreadth challenges, consider appending a short schedule of named Direct Competitors and updating it in writing from time to time. The definition above already limits “Direct Competitor” to the Company Business and to matters where the Consultant had Material Involvement, which aids enforceability.
- Geographic scope: The “Restricted Area” is tied only to locations where the Consultant actually worked, which keeps it targeted and reasonable.
- Time scope: Six months is within the range generally viewed as reasonable outside California. In California, the post-termination non-compete is inapplicable, and only the confidentiality/trade secret protections remain.

Under California law, non-compete clauses are generally unenforceable except in limited circumstances, such as in the sale of a business or dissolution of a partnership. However, California law does allow for the protection of trade secrets and confidential information. Therefore, instead of a traditional non-compete clause, I will draft a clause focusing on the protection of confidential information and trade secrets, which can indirectly achieve similar objectives.

---

**ARTICLE 3 CONFIDENTIALITY AND NON-COMPETITION**

3.3 [ADD] **Protection of Trade Secrets and Non-Solicitation.**

(a) **Protection of Trade Secrets.** The Consultant acknowledges that during the course of providing services to the Company, the Consultant will have access to and become acquainted with various trade secrets, proprietary information, and other confidential information that are owned by the Company and are regularly used in the operation of the Company's business. The Consultant agrees that he will not disclose any of the aforementioned trade secrets, directly or indirectly, or use them in any way, either during the term of this Agreement or at any time thereafter, except as required in the course of his engagement with the Company.

(b) **Non-Solicitation of Clients and Employees.** For a period of six (6) months following the termination of this Agreement, the Consultant agrees not to solicit or attempt to solicit any business from any of the Company's clients, customers, or employees, with whom the Consultant had material contact during the last twelve (12) months of his engagement, for the purpose of providing products or services that are competitive with those provided by the Company.

(c) **Geographical Scope.** The restrictions set forth in this Section 3.3 shall apply within a fifty (50) mile radius of any location where the Company conducts business operations.

(d) **Acknowledgment.** The Consultant acknowledges that the restrictions contained in this Section 3.3 are reasonable and necessary to protect the legitimate interests of the Company, and that any violation of these restrictions would result in irreparable injury to the Company. The Consultant further acknowledges that the Company shall be entitled to seek injunctive relief in the event of any breach or threatened breach of these provisions, in addition to any other legal remedies available.

---

This clause is designed to be enforceable under California law by focusing on the protection of trade secrets and non-solicitation, rather than a direct non-compete restriction. It is important to ensure that the clause is narrowly tailored to protect the legitimate business interests of the Company without imposing undue restrictions on the Consultant's ability to work in his field.

Given California's strict legal stance on non-compete clauses (codified primarily in **Business and Professions Code § 16600**), any restriction on post-employment competitive activity must be **narrowly tailored** to protect legitimate business interests (e.g., trade secrets, confidential information) without imposing an undue burden on the consultant’s ability to earn a livelihood. Courts in California routinely invalidate overbroad non-competes, even if they include geographic or temporal limitations.

Below is a **draft non-compete clause** designed to comply with California law by:
1. **Focusing on the protection of confidential information** (rather than outright prohibition of competition).
2. **Limiting the scope to direct competitors** (defined narrowly).
3. **Including a 6-month duration and 50-mile radius**, but tying it explicitly to the misuse of confidential information.
4. **Avoiding language that could be construed as a blanket restriction on employment**.

**[ADD]**
**3.3 Protection of Confidential Information and Limited Non-Competition Covenant.**
(a) **Non-Solicitation and Non-Use of Confidential Information.** During the Term and for a period of **six (6) months** following the termination of this Agreement (the **"Restricted Period"**), the Consultant shall not, directly or indirectly, within a **fifty (50)-mile radius** of any office or facility where the Consultant performed services for the Company (the **"Restricted Territory"**):
   (i) **Solicit or induce** any employee, consultant, client, customer, or business partner of the Company to terminate or reduce their relationship with the Company for the purpose of competing with the Company; or
   (ii) **Use or disclose** any Confidential Information (as defined in Section 3.1) to any **Direct Competitor** (as defined below) of the Company for the purpose of developing, marketing, or selling products or services that compete with those of the Company.

(b) **Definition of Direct Competitor.** For purposes of this Section 3.3, a **"Direct Competitor"** means any person or entity that:
   (i) Engages in the same **specific line of business** as the Company (i.e., [INSERT SPECIFIC INDUSTRY/SECTOR, e.g., *"investor relations and corporate restructuring services for technology startups in the AI and biotech sectors"*: **REQUIRES TAILORING TO COMPANY’S ACTUAL BUSINESS**]); and
   (ii) **Derives more than 20% of its revenue** from such competing activities during the Restricted Period.

(c) **No Prohibition on General Employment.** Nothing in this Section 3.3 shall be construed to prohibit the Consultant from:
   (i) Being employed by or providing services to a Direct Competitor, **provided that** such employment or services do not involve the **misuse of Confidential Information** or the **solicitation of the Company’s clients, employees, or business partners** as prohibited above; or
   (ii) Engaging in any lawful profession, trade, or business **unrelated to the Company’s Confidential Information**.

(d) **Reasonableness and Enforceability.** The parties acknowledge that:
   (i) The restrictions in this Section 3.3 are **narrowly tailored** to protect the Company’s legitimate business interests in its Confidential Information and customer relationships;
   (ii) The **6-month duration** and **50-mile geographic limitation** are reasonable in scope and necessary to protect such interests; and
   (iii) This Section 3.3 shall be **unenforceable to the extent it violates California Business and Professions Code § 16600** or any other applicable law, and any unenforceable portion shall be **severed** without affecting the validity of the remaining provisions.

(e) **Survival.** The obligations under this Section 3.3 shall survive the termination of this Agreement in accordance with its terms.

---
### **Key Legal Considerations for Enforceability in California**
1. **Avoiding Overbreadth**:
   - The clause **does not prohibit competition outright** but instead targets **misuse of confidential information** and **solicitation of clients/employees**, which are more likely to be upheld under **§ 16600** (see *Edwards v. Arthur Andersen LLP* (2008) 44 Cal.4th 937).
   - The definition of "Direct Competitor" is **narrowly tied to the Company’s specific business** to avoid being struck down as overbroad.

2. **Geographic and Temporal Limits**:
   - The **50-mile radius** is tied to locations where the Consultant **actually worked**, which is more defensible than a blanket restriction (cf. *Loral Corp. v. Moyes* (1985) 174 Cal.App.3d 268).
   - The **6-month duration** is short enough to avoid being deemed unreasonable (California courts have upheld restrictions of **6–12 months** in limited contexts, e.g., *Thompson v. Impaxx, Inc.* (2003) 113 Cal.App.4th 1425).

3. **Severability**:
   - The clause includes a **savings provision** to ensure that if any portion is invalidated, the rest remains enforceable.

4. **No Prohibition on Employment**:
   - Explicitly permits the Consultant to work for competitors **so long as they do not misuse confidential information**, which aligns with California’s public policy favoring employee mobility.

Below is the addition of a reasonable non-compete clause that restricts the consultant from working with direct competitors for 6 months post-termination within a 50-mile radius, ensuring it is enforceable under California law. Note that California generally disfavors non-compete agreements, but they can be enforceable in limited circumstances, such as the sale of a business or the dissolution of a partnership. ### Article 3: CONFIDENTIALITY AND NON-COMPETITION

#### 3.3 Non-Competition

(a) The Consultant acknowledges that the Company's business is highly competitive and that the Consultant's services are of a special, unique, and extraordinary character. The Consultant further acknowledges that the Company has a legitimate interest in protecting its business and customer relationships.

(b) In consideration of the Company's engagement of the Consultant and the compensation provided herein, the Consultant agrees that, during the Term of this Agreement and for a period of six (6) months following the termination of this Agreement for any reason (the "Non-Compete Period"), the Consultant will not, directly or indirectly, within a fifty (50) mile radius of any location where the Company conducts business (the "Restricted Area"), engage in, own, manage, operate, control, or participate in the ownership, management, operation, or control of, or be employed by or associated with, any business that is in direct competition with the Company (a "Competing Business").

(c) For the purposes of this Section 3.3, a "Competing Business" is defined as any business that provides services or products that are substantially similar to those provided by the Company, including but not limited to investor relations, corporate structure, public relations, and commercial development services.

(d) The Consultant acknowledges that the restrictions set forth in this Section 3.3 are reasonable and necessary to protect the Company's legitimate business interests. If any court or other competent authority determines that any provision of this Section 3.3 is invalid or unenforceable, the remaining provisions shall remain in full force and effect, and the invalid or unenforceable provision shall be deemed modified to the extent necessary to make it valid and enforceable.

(e) The Consultant agrees that any breach of this Section 3.3 will cause irreparable harm to the Company, and the Company shall be entitled to seek injunctive relief, in addition to any other remedies available at law or in equity, to enforce the provisions of this Section 3.3.

(f) The Consultant further agrees to notify the Company in writing within ten (10) days of accepting any employment or engagement with any business during the Non-Compete Period, and to provide the Company with the name and address of the business and a description of the Consultant's role and responsibilities.

### PROPOSED ADDITION: NEW ARTICLE 8 - INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS

**[ADD]**

## ARTICLE 8 - INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS

### 8.1 Assignment of Work Product

**(a) Ownership of Work Product.** The Consultant agrees that all work product, inventions, discoveries, developments, improvements, trade secrets, know-how, processes, techniques, methods, ideas, concepts, research, data, programs, software code, documentation, designs, formulae, algorithms, specifications, and other materials or intellectual property of any nature whatsoever (whether or not patentable or copyrightable, and whether or not reduced to practice) that are created, conceived, developed, authored, invented, or reduced to practice by the Consultant, either alone or jointly with others, during the Term of this Agreement and arising out of or in connection with the performance of services under this Agreement (collectively, "Work Product"), shall be the sole and exclusive property of the Company.

**(b) Works Made for Hire.** The Consultant acknowledges and agrees that all Work Product that qualifies as a "work made for hire" as defined under the United States Copyright Act of 1976, as amended, shall be deemed a work made for hire and shall be owned exclusively by the Company. To the extent any Work Product does not qualify as a work made for hire, the Consultant hereby irrevocably assigns, transfers, and conveys to the Company all right, title, and interest in and to such Work Product, including without limitation all worldwide intellectual property rights therein, including all patents, copyrights, trademarks, trade secrets, moral rights, and other proprietary rights.

**(c) Scope of Assignment.** The assignment under this Section 8.1 includes, without limitation:
- (i) All rights to apply for, obtain, register, perfect, and enforce patents, copyrights, trademarks, trade secret protections, and other legal protections worldwide;
- (ii) All rights to sue for past, present, and future infringements or violations of any intellectual property rights in the Work Product;
- (iii) All economic and exploitation rights, including rights to reproduce, distribute, display, perform, create derivative works, and sublicense; and
- (iv) All renewals, extensions, reversions, and restorations associated with such intellectual property rights, now or hereafter provided by law.

### 8.2 Pre-Existing Intellectual Property

**(a) Disclosure of Prior Inventions.** The Consultant has disclosed to the Company in writing, prior to or contemporaneously with the execution of this Agreement, a complete list of all inventions, discoveries, writings, and other intellectual property relevant to the subject matter of the Consultant's engagement that were created, conceived, or developed by the Consultant prior to the Effective Date and that the Consultant desires to exclude from the scope of this Agreement ("Prior Inventions"). The list of Prior Inventions is attached hereto as **Schedule 8.2(a)**. If no such list is attached, the Consultant represents that there are no Prior Inventions.

**(b) Exclusion of Prior Inventions.** The Consultant retains all right, title, and interest in and to the Prior Inventions. However, if any Prior Invention is incorporated into or used in connection with any Work Product, the Consultant hereby grants to the Company a perpetual, irrevocable, worldwide, royalty-free, fully paid-up, non-exclusive license (with right to sublicense through multiple tiers) to use, reproduce, modify, create derivative works of, distribute, display, and perform such Prior Invention solely to the extent necessary to exploit the Work Product.

**(c) Third-Party Materials.** The Consultant represents and warrants that the Consultant will not incorporate into any Work Product any intellectual property owned by third parties without the Company's prior written consent. If the Company consents to such incorporation, the Consultant shall obtain, at the Company's expense, all necessary licenses and rights for the Company's use of such third-party intellectual property.

### 8.3 Moral Rights Waiver

**(a) Waiver of Moral Rights.** To the fullest extent permitted by applicable law, the Consultant hereby irrevocably waives and agrees never to assert any moral rights, droit moral, or similar rights (including without limitation rights of attribution, integrity, disclosure, withdrawal, and any other rights that may be known as or referred to as "moral rights," "artist's rights," "droit moral," or the like) that the Consultant may now or hereafter have in or to any Work Product, anywhere in the world.

**(b) Consent to Modifications.** The Consultant hereby consents to any and all uses, modifications, adaptations, edits, revisions, and changes to the Work Product by the Company or its designees, and waives any right to inspect or approve any such uses or modifications. The Consultant agrees that the Company shall have the right to use or refrain from using the Work Product in any manner the Company deems appropriate, without any obligation to the Consultant.

**(c) Attribution.** The Consultant agrees that the Company shall have no obligation to provide attribution or credit to the Consultant for any Work Product, and the Company may attribute authorship or inventorship to any person or entity, or to no person or entity, as the Company determines in its sole discretion.

**(d) Jurisdictions Not Permitting Waiver.** In any jurisdiction where moral rights cannot be waived, the Consultant agrees not to enforce such moral rights against the Company, its successors, assigns, licensees, or customers, and consents in advance to any action that would violate such moral rights in the absence of such consent.

### 8.4 Further Assurances and Cooperation

**(a) Execution of Documents.** The Consultant agrees to execute, acknowledge, and deliver to the Company, at the Company's request and expense, all such further documents and instruments, and to take all such further actions, as may be necessary or desirable to evidence, perfect, register, or enforce the Company's rights in and to the Work Product, including without limitation:
- (i) Patent, copyright, trademark, and other intellectual property applications and assignments;
- (ii) Declarations, oaths, affidavits, and other documents required by governmental authorities;
- (iii) Documents necessary to perfect title or record assignments; and
- (iv) Any other documents reasonably requested by the Company.

**(b) Cooperation After Termination.** The Consultant's obligations under this Section 8.4 shall continue beyond the termination of this Agreement. The Consultant agrees to cooperate with the Company in the prosecution, maintenance, and enforcement of intellectual property rights in the Work Product, including providing testimony and assistance in any proceedings. The Company shall compensate the Consultant at a reasonable hourly rate (not less than $200 per hour) for time spent on such cooperation after termination of this Agreement, and shall reimburse the Consultant for all reasonable out-of-pocket expenses incurred.

**(c) Power of Attorney.** The Consultant hereby irrevocably designates and appoints the Company and its duly authorized officers and agents as the Consultant's agent and attorney-in-fact to act on the Consultant's behalf to execute and file any documents and to do all other lawfully permitted acts to further the purposes of this Article 8 with the same legal force and effect as if executed by the Consultant, if the Consultant is unable or unwilling to execute such documents or take such actions. This power of attorney is coupled with an interest and shall be irrevocable.

### 8.5 Disclosure Obligations

**(a) Prompt Disclosure.** The Consultant shall promptly disclose to the Company in writing all Work Product, whether or not the Consultant believes such Work Product is subject to the assignment provisions of this Article 8.

**(b) Records and Materials.** The Consultant shall maintain adequate and current written records of all Work Product in the form of notes, sketches, drawings, electronic files, and other documents as may be reasonably requested by the Company. Such records shall be and remain the sole property of the Company and shall be delivered to the Company upon termination of this Agreement or upon the Company's earlier request.

### 8.6 Return of Materials

Upon termination of this Agreement for any reason, or at any time upon the Company's request, the Consultant shall immediately deliver to the Company all documents, materials, equipment, and other property belonging to the Company, including without limitation all embodiments of Work Product, in any form or medium, and all copies thereof, and shall not retain any copies, excerpts, or summaries thereof.

### 8.7 No Conflicting Obligations

The Consultant represents and warrants that the Consultant has no outstanding agreements, obligations, or understandings with any other person or entity that conflict with or would prevent the full performance of the Consultant's obligations under this Article 8, and that the Consultant's performance of services under this Agreement will not violate any agreement with or rights of any third party.

### 8.8 Equitable Remedies

The Consultant acknowledges that a breach of this Article 8 would cause irreparable harm to the Company for which monetary damages would be an inadequate remedy. Accordingly, the Company shall be entitled to seek equitable relief, including injunction and specific performance, in addition to all other remedies available at law or in equity, without the necessity of posting a bond.

Proposed new Article — to be inserted as a new Article 8 (Intellectual Property; Work Product) following Article 7 (General)

ARTICLE 8 INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY; WORK PRODUCT

8.1 Definitions. For purposes of this Agreement:
(a) “Work Product” means, individually and collectively, all inventions, discoveries, developments, improvements, ideas, works of authorship, designs, mask works, software (including source code and object code), algorithms, documentation, data, databases, processes, formulas, know-how, trade secrets, techniques, reports, analyses, presentations, marketing or sales collateral, and any other materials or deliverables that are authored, conceived, reduced to practice, developed, delivered or otherwise created or prepared, in whole or in part, by Consultant (alone or with others) in the course of, in connection with, or as a result of the services under this Agreement, whether or not patentable or registrable, and all tangible embodiments thereof and all intellectual property and proprietary rights therein and thereto (including all copyrights, moral rights, patent rights, trade secret rights, mask work rights, database rights and all applications and registrations for any of the foregoing).
(b) “Company Materials” means all materials, data, tools, software, information and other items provided or made available by or on behalf of the Company to Consultant.
(c) “Consultant Background IP” means any intellectual property owned or controlled by Consultant prior to the Effective Date or developed or acquired by Consultant independent of the services and without use of Company Materials or Company Confidential Information.
(d) “Third-Party Materials” means any materials, data, software, content or other items owned by a third party, including “open source software” and components licensed under copyleft, permissive or other public licenses.

8.2 Ownership; Work Made for Hire; Assignment.
(a) As between the parties, the Company shall exclusively own all right, title and interest in and to the Work Product worldwide, free and clear of any liens or encumbrances. To the maximum extent permitted by law, any copyrightable portion of the Work Product shall be deemed a “work made for hire” for the Company within the meaning of 17 U.S.C. § 101.
(b) To the extent (or in any jurisdiction where) any Work Product or any portion thereof does not qualify as a “work made for hire,” Consultant hereby irrevocably assigns, transfers and conveys to the Company (and agrees to assign, transfer and convey to the Company, automatically upon creation) all right, title and interest (including all intellectual property rights) in and to the Work Product. Consultant retains no rights in the Work Product and shall not use the Work Product for any purpose other than for the benefit of the Company under this Agreement.

8.3 Disclosure; Records. Consultant shall promptly and fully disclose to the Company in writing all Work Product. Consultant shall keep and maintain adequate, current and accurate written records of the Work Product (in the form of notes, sketches, drawings, code repositories and any other format required by the Company), which records shall be and remain the sole property of the Company and shall be available to and delivered to the Company at any time upon request and in any event upon termination of this Agreement.

8.4 Further Assurances; Assistance; Power of Attorney.
(a) Consultant shall, both during and after the Term, at the Company’s cost and expense, execute and deliver such further documents and take such further actions as the Company may reasonably request to evidence, perfect, register, maintain, enforce and defend the Company’s rights in the Work Product, including executing assignments, declarations, oaths and other papers in connection with patent, copyright, mask work and other applications and registrations in the United States and foreign jurisdictions.
(b) If Consultant is unavailable or refuses to execute any such documents after reasonable request, Consultant hereby irrevocably appoints the Company as Consultant’s attorney-in-fact, coupled with an interest, to execute such documents on Consultant’s behalf for the limited purpose of perfecting, registering, maintaining, enforcing or defending the Company’s rights in the Work Product.

8.5 Consultant Background IP; Limited License to Company.
(a) Consultant retains ownership of Consultant Background IP. Consultant shall not incorporate any Consultant Background IP into the Work Product without the Company’s prior written consent. If and to the extent any Consultant Background IP is approved in writing by the Company for incorporation into or use in connection with the Work Product, Consultant hereby grants to the Company, its affiliates and their respective successors and assigns a perpetual, irrevocable, worldwide, royalty-free, fully paid-up, transferable, sublicensable (through multiple tiers) license to use, reproduce, perform, display, modify, create derivative works of, make, have made, import, export, distribute and otherwise exploit such Consultant Background IP solely as part of or as necessary to use, operate, maintain, support, modify, improve, exploit or otherwise fully exercise the Company’s rights in the Work Product.
(b) Within ten (10) days after the Effective Date (or, for Background IP proposed for later use, before such use), Consultant shall provide the Company a written schedule describing any Consultant Background IP that Consultant proposes to use or incorporate, sufficient to identify it and its owner and to describe any license terms applicable to it. If Consultant fails to identify such Consultant Background IP in accordance with this Section 8.5(b) but nonetheless uses or incorporates it, the license in Section 8.5(a) shall apply automatically and without limitation.

8.6 Third-Party Materials; Open Source Software.
(a) Consultant shall not incorporate or use any Third-Party Materials in or in connection with the Work Product without the Company’s prior written consent identifying the specific item(s) and applicable license terms. Consultant shall comply with all license terms applicable to any approved Third-Party Materials and shall provide the Company with copies of such license terms and any required notices, at or before delivery of the applicable Work Product.
(b) Without limiting the foregoing, Consultant shall not incorporate any open source software into or with the Work Product, or otherwise use any open source software in a manner, that would (i) require the Company to disclose, license or make available any source code of the Work Product or of any Company software, (ii) require the Work Product or any Company software to be distributed at no charge, or (iii) otherwise impose any “copyleft” or similar obligations on the Work Product or any Company software, in each case without the Company’s express prior written consent.

8.7 Moral Rights Waiver. To the fullest extent permitted by applicable law, Consultant hereby irrevocably waives and agrees not to assert against the Company or its affiliates, successors, assigns, licensees and customers any and all “moral rights” or rights of a similar nature (including rights of attribution, integrity, disclosure and withdrawal) that Consultant may have in or to the Work Product in any jurisdiction. To the extent any such rights cannot be waived, Consultant agrees not to enforce such rights and hereby consents to any acts by or on behalf of the Company that would, absent such consent, infringe such rights.

8.8 Company Materials and Confidential Information. Company Materials and all Company Confidential Information shall remain the exclusive property of the Company. Consultant shall use Company Materials and Company Confidential Information solely to perform the services and shall not, without the Company’s prior written consent, incorporate any Company Materials or Company Confidential Information into any deliverable for any third party.

8.9 No Additional Compensation. Except as expressly provided in Article 2, Consultant shall not be entitled to any additional compensation or reimbursement of any kind on account of the assignment of rights in Work Product, the waiver of moral rights, or the assistance obligations set forth in this Article 8.

8.10 Delivery; Return. Upon the earlier of the Company’s request or termination of this Agreement, Consultant shall deliver to the Company all Work Product and all related records, files, media and materials (including all copies), and shall permanently delete any electronic copies in Consultant’s possession or control, subject to any legal recordkeeping obligations and Section 3.1(c).

8.11 Personnel and Subcontractors. Consultant shall ensure that all of Consultant’s employees, contractors and other personnel who perform services in connection with this Agreement have executed written agreements sufficient to secure for the Company the ownership, assignment, waiver and assistance rights set forth in this Article 8, and Consultant shall provide copies of such agreements to the Company upon request.

8.12 Survival. Consultant’s obligations under this Article 8 shall survive any expiration or termination of this Agreement.

**ARTICLE 8 – INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY**

**8.1 Assignment of Inventions and Work Product.**
(a) **Ownership of Work Product.** The Consultant hereby irrevocably assigns, transfers, and conveys to the Company, its successors, and assigns, **all right, title, and interest** (including all intellectual property rights and proprietary rights worldwide) in and to:
   (i) all **Inventions** (as defined below) **conceived, reduced to practice, authored, developed, or created** by the Consultant **solely or jointly with others** during the **Term** of this Agreement (and for **one (1) year thereafter** if related to the Company’s business or anticipated research/development);
   (ii) all **Work Product** (as defined below) **prepared, composed, or developed** by the Consultant **in the course of performing services** under this Agreement; and
   (iii) all **tangible and intangible materials** (including, without limitation, documents, reports, software, databases, designs, prototypes, presentations, marketing materials, and derivative works) **created or contributed to** by the Consultant **for or on behalf of the Company**.

(b) **Definitions.**
   - **"Inventions"** means any and all **ideas, discoveries, improvements, developments, designs, works of authorship, formulas, processes, techniques, know-how, trade secrets, algorithms, data compilations, mask works, inventions (whether patentable or not), and any other intellectual property** (including all **patent, copyright, trademark, and trade secret rights** therein) **related to the Company’s business, products, services, or research**.
   - **"Work Product"** means all **original works of authorship** (including but not limited to **software, code, documentation, manuals, reports, analyses, drawings, audiovisual works, and other deliverables**) **created by the Consultant** in the performance of this Agreement, **regardless of the medium or form** in which such works are fixed.

(c) **Scope of Assignment.** The assignment under this Section 8.1 includes all **patent rights** (including the right to apply for, prosecute, and maintain patents), **copyright rights** (including the right to claim authorship under **17 U.S.C. § 201 et seq.**), **trademark rights**, **trade secret rights**, **moral rights** (to the extent waivable under applicable law), and all other **intellectual property rights** recognized under **U.S. or foreign law**, whether now known or hereafter created.

   (i) was **conceived, developed, or reduced to practice by the Consultant prior to the Effective Date** of this Agreement (**"Pre-Existing IP"**);
   (ii) was **not conceived or developed using the Company’s equipment, supplies, facilities, or Confidential Information**; and
   (iii) is **not related to the Company’s business, actual or demonstrably anticipated research, or development**.
(c) **Burden of Proof.** The Consultant bears the **burden of proving** that any Invention or Work Product qualifies as Pre-Existing IP under Section 8.2(b). The Consultant shall **maintain contemporaneous records** (e.g., dated sketches, lab notebooks, or electronic files) to substantiate such claims.

**8.3 Moral Rights Waiver.**
To the **fullest extent permitted by applicable law**, the Consultant **irrevocably waives** all **moral rights** (including rights of **attribution, integrity, disclosure, and withdrawal**) in any Work Product or Invention assigned to the Company under this Agreement. The Consultant further **consents to any use, modification, or destruction** of such Work Product or Invention by the Company without further approval or compensation.

**8.4 Further Assurances.**
The Consultant agrees to:
(a) **Execute any documents** (e.g., patent applications, copyright assignments, or affidavits) and **perform all lawful acts** reasonably requested by the Company to **perfect, evidence, or maintain** the Company’s rights in the assigned Inventions or Work Product, both **during and after the Term** of this Agreement;
(b) **Assist the Company** in **prosecuting, defending, or enforcing** any intellectual property rights, including providing testimony or declarations in legal proceedings, **at the Company’s expense** (including reasonable compensation for the Consultant’s time);
(c) **Not challenge** the validity or enforceability of the Company’s rights in the assigned Inventions or Work Product; and
(d) **Promptly notify the Company** if the Consultant becomes aware of any **infringement or misappropriation** of the assigned intellectual property.

**8.5 Third-Party Intellectual Property.**
(a) The Consultant shall **not incorporate** any **third-party intellectual property** (e.g., open-source software, licensed content, or proprietary tools) into any Work Product or Invention **without the Company’s prior written consent**.
(b) If third-party intellectual property is used with the Company’s approval, the Consultant shall:
   (i) **Comply with all applicable license terms** (e.g., open-source obligations);
   (ii) **Provide the Company with copies of all licenses**; and
   (iii) **Indemnify the Company** against any claims arising from the Consultant’s **unauthorized use or non-compliance** with third-party licenses.

**8.6 Survival.**
The obligations under this **Article 8** shall **survive termination** of this Agreement **in perpetuity**.

---

### **KEY LEGAL CONSIDERATIONS & RECOMMENDATIONS**
1. **Jurisdictional Nuances:**
   - **Moral Rights:** Under **U.S. copyright law (17 U.S.C. § 106A)**, moral rights are **limited to visual arts** and cannot be fully waived for "works made for hire." However, the clause includes a **waiver to the maximum extent permissible** (e.g., for non-visual works or in jurisdictions like **Canada/EU** where moral rights are broader).
   - **Pre-Existing IP:** The **burden of proof** is placed on the Consultant to avoid disputes. Consider requiring a **scheduled disclosure of Pre-Existing IP** (e.g., as an **Exhibit**) at the outset.

2. **Works Made for Hire (17 U.S.C. § 101):**
   - The Agreement **does not explicitly classify** the Work Product as a "work made for hire." To strengthen the Company’s position, add:
     > **[ADD]**
     > *"To the extent any Work Product constitutes a ‘work made for hire’ under **17 U.S.C. § 101**, the Company shall be deemed the **author and owner** of such Work Product from its creation."*

3. **Open-Source & Third-Party Risks:**
   - The clause **prohibits unauthorized use** of third-party IP but does not address **copyleft licenses** (e.g., GPL). If the Consultant may use open-source tools, add a **compliance audit requirement**:
     > **[ADD]**
     > *"The Consultant shall provide the Company with a **written certification** upon request confirming that all Work Product complies with third-party license obligations, including open-source attribution and copyleft requirements."*

4. **International Enforceability:**
   - For **Israeli law** (Consultant’s jurisdiction), confirm that:
     - The **assignment of future IP** is enforceable (some jurisdictions require **separate assignments for future inventions**).
     - **Moral rights waivers** are valid under **Israeli Copyright Act, 2007** (which permits waivers for **software and commercial works**).

5. **Redflags in the Existing Agreement:**
   - **Article 7.5** allows the Consultant to **submit invoices via a third-party employer**. This could complicate IP ownership if the third party claims rights. Add:
     > **[MODIFY Article 7.5]**
     > *"Notwithstanding the foregoing, any such third-party invoicing arrangement shall not affect the Company’s exclusive ownership of all Inventions and Work Product under **Article 8**, and the Consultant shall ensure that no third party asserts any claim thereto."*

---
### **SUGGESTED PLACEMENT**
Insert the new **Article 8** **after Article 7 (General)** and **renumber subsequent articles** accordingly. Alternatively, if grouping IP with confidentiality is preferred, add as **Section 3.3** under **Article 3** and renumber existing sections.

---
### **FINAL NOTES**
- **Execution:** Ensure the Consultant **initials each page** of the amended Agreement to evidence assent.
- **Exhibits:** Attach a **schedule for Pre-Existing IP disclosures** (if any) as **Exhibit B**.
- **Governing Law:** Confirm that **New York law** (per **Article 7.10**) governs IP assignments, as some states (e.g., **California**) have **specific rules** for employee/consultant inventions (**Labor Code § 2870**).

**ARTICLE 8: INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY**

**8.1 Assignment of Intellectual Property.** The Consultant agrees that all inventions, discoveries, improvements, works of authorship, designs, trademarks, trade secrets, and other intellectual property (collectively, "Work Product") conceived, developed, or reduced to practice by the Consultant, either alone or with others, during the Term and within the scope of the Consultant's engagement with the Company, shall be the sole and exclusive property of the Company. # CONSULTING AGREEMENT REVIEW - CONSULTANT PERSPECTIVE
## Problematic and Unfair Clauses Analysis

---

### 1. PARTY IDENTIFICATION DISCREPANCY

**(a) Problematic Clause:**
The header identifies the parties as "TechVenture Solutions Inc." and "NexGen Analytics Inc." (both corporations), but the actual agreement is between "TechVenture Solutions Inc." and "Aitan Zacharin" (an individual consultant).

**(b) Why It's Concerning:**
- Creates fundamental ambiguity about who the actual contracting parties are
- Unclear whether NexGen Analytics Inc. has any obligations or rights
- Could render the entire agreement unenforceable
- May create confusion about liability, payment obligations, and legal standing

**(c) Suggested Revision:**
```
[MODIFY] Header to read:
PARTIES:
1. TechVenture Solutions Inc.
   Nevada corporation
   [Complete address to be provided]

2. Aitan Zacharin
   Individual Consultant
   Residing in Bet Shemesh, Israel
```

---

### 2. ASYMMETRIC TERMINATION NOTICE PERIODS (Section 4.1(a)(ii) and 4.1(b)(ii))

**(a) Problematic Clause:**
- Company can terminate without cause with 60 days' notice
- Consultant must provide 120 days' notice to terminate without good reason

**(b) Why It's Concerning:**
- Grossly unfair double standard that heavily favors the Company
- Consultant is locked in twice as long as the Company
- Restricts consultant's ability to pursue other opportunities
- No legitimate business justification for this disparity
- Industry standard is equal notice periods or shorter for the service provider

**(c) Suggested Revision:**
```
[MODIFY] Section 4.1(b)(ii):
"Without Good Reason. The Consultant may voluntarily terminate the Consultant's engagement with the Company at any time by giving the Company 60 days prior written Notice of the termination."

[ADD] Rationale: Notice periods should be equal for both parties to reflect a balanced commercial relationship.
```

---

### 3. UNLIMITED SCOPE CREEP (Section 1.2(c))

**(a) Problematic Clause:**
"The Consultant will provide any other services not specifically mentioned herein, but which by reason of the Consultant's capability, the Consultant knows or ought to know to be necessary to ensure that the best interests of the Company are maintained."

**(b) Why It's Concerning:**
- Vague and unlimited scope of work beyond defined duties
- "Ought to know" creates subjective standard for additional obligations
- No additional compensation for expanded duties
- Could be used to demand unlimited work
- "Best interests of the Company" is overly broad and undefined
- Violates basic principle of defined scope in consulting agreements

**(c) Suggested Revision:**
```
[DELETE] Entire Section 1.2(c)

[ADD] New Section 1.2(c):
"The Consultant will provide services related to investor relations, corporate structure and governance, public relations, and commercial development as specifically directed by the Company's officers. Any material expansion of duties beyond the scope described in Section 1.2(b) shall require a written amendment to this Agreement and may result in additional compensation to be mutually agreed upon."
```

---

### 4. MISSING NON-COMPETE PROVISIONS (Article 3)

**(a) Problematic Clause:**
Article 3 is titled "CONFIDENTIALITY AND NON-COMPETITION" but contains NO non-compete or non-solicitation provisions whatsoever.

**(b) Why It's Concerning:**
- While this appears to benefit the consultant, the title suggests such provisions were intended
- Creates ambiguity about whether non-compete obligations exist
- Company may later claim implied non-compete based on article title
- Could lead to litigation over whether consultant can work for competitors
- Best practice is to have explicit language either imposing or disclaiming such restrictions

**(c) Suggested Revision:**
```
[MODIFY] Article 3 title to: "ARTICLE 3 CONFIDENTIALITY"

[ADD] New Section 3.3:
"No Non-Compete. The parties acknowledge that this Agreement does not contain any non-competition, non-solicitation, or similar restrictive covenants. Consultant shall remain free to provide services to other clients and pursue other business opportunities during and after the Term, provided such activities do not violate the confidentiality obligations set forth in this Article 3."
```

---

### 5. VAGUE BONUS COMPENSATION (Section 2.1(c))

**(a) Problematic Clause:**
"The Consultant will be entitled to receive up to a one-time bonus of 1,500,000 shares of common stock of the NexGen Analytics Inc.'s outstanding stock equals $100 million dollars."

**(b) Why It's Concerning:**
- Completely unclear trigger for this bonus (when does consultant receive it?)
- "Up to" means consultant might receive nothing
- References "NexGen Analytics Inc." stock (wrong company - should be TechVenture)
- Condition "$100 million dollars" is ambiguous (market cap? valuation? revenue?)
- No timeline specified
- Entirely discretionary with no objective criteria
- Likely unenforceable due to vagueness

**(c) Suggested Revision:**
```
[MODIFY] Section 2.1(c):
"Performance Bonus. The Consultant shall be entitled to receive a one-time bonus of 1,500,000 shares of common stock of TechVenture Solutions Inc. upon the Company achieving a market capitalization or third-party valuation of $100 million USD, as determined by [specify method: independent valuation, acquisition offer, public market cap, etc.]. Such shares shall be issued within 30 days of the triggering event."

[ALTERNATIVE - if intent is different]:
"Discretionary Bonus. The Company may, in its sole discretion, grant the Consultant additional equity compensation. Any such grant shall be documented in a separate written agreement."
```

---

### 6. INADEQUATE ADDRESS FOR NOTICES (Section 6.1(a))

**(a) Problematic Clause:**
Company's notice address is "To be provided under separate cover within three days after the date hereof; in the event that Consultant does not receive notice of address within such period, then Consultant shall be entitled to send any notice to any email address of the Company known to Consultant and the sending of any such notice shall constitute receipt of notice whether the Company receives such notice or not."

**(b) Why It's Concerning:**
- No valid address provided at contract execution
- Creates uncertainty about where to send legal notices
- "Any email address" is far too vague for legal notices
- "Receipt whether the Company receives such notice or not" is legally problematic and likely unenforceable
- Could invalidate important notices (termination, breach, etc.)
- Professional agreements should have complete notice provisions at execution

**(c) Suggested Revision:**
```
[MODIFY] Section 6.1(a):
"in the case of the Company, to:
TechVenture Solutions Inc.
[Complete physical address]
Attention: [Specific officer/department]
Email: [specific email address]

With a copy to:
[Legal counsel if applicable]

The Company shall provide Consultant with written notice of any change of address within 10 days of such change. Until such notice is received, Consultant may rely on the address set forth above."

[DELETE] Language regarding "any email address" and deemed receipt
```

---

### 7. AMBIGUOUS WARRANT EXERCISE PRICE (Annex A)

**(a) Problematic Clause:**
"Exercise Price per share: par value"

**(b) Why It's Concerning:**
- Par value is typically nominal ($0.001 or $0.0001) and may not reflect actual value
- Creates ambiguity about actual exercise price
- Could be interpreted as current market value at time of exercise
- Lacks specificity required for equity compensation
- May have unintended tax consequences
- Should specify exact dollar amount

**(c) Suggested Revision:**
```
[MODIFY] Warrant terms:
"Exercise Price per share: $0.001 per share (or such other specific amount as the parties agree represents the par value of the Company's common stock as of the Issue Date)"

[ADD] Clarification:
"The Exercise Price is fixed as of the Issue Date and shall not be subject to adjustment except as specifically provided in Article 2 of this Warrant."
```

---

### 8. UNILATERAL PAYMENT ARRANGEMENT (Section 7.5)

**(a) Problematic Clause:**
"The Company acknowledges and agrees that the Consultant may submit to the Company invoices from a company that employs him in lieu of invoices on his name. The Consultant confirms that any such invoice will replace his own invoice and he agrees that his fees will be paid by the Company to third parties provided that it is done as per his instructions to the Company."

**(b) Why It's Concerning:**
- Creates potential tax and legal liability issues for consultant
- Unclear who is actually the contracting party
- May create employment relationship with third-party company
- Could affect consultant's ability to enforce agreement
- No protection if Company pays wrong entity
- May violate assignment provisions in Section 7.4
- Could create withholding and reporting complications

**(c) Suggested Revision:**
```
[MODIFY] Section 7.5:
"Payment Arrangements. The Consultant may direct the Company in writing to make payments due under this Agreement to a designated entity, provided that: (a) Consultant provides the Company with complete tax documentation for such entity at least 15 days prior to the first payment; (b) such arrangement does not increase the Company's tax or administrative burden; (c) Consultant remains personally liable for all obligations under this Agreement; and (d) such arrangement does not constitute an assignment prohibited by Section 7.4. The Company reserves the right to reject any such arrangement if it creates legal, tax, or compliance concerns for the Company."
```

---

### 9. EXCESSIVE CONFIDENTIALITY OBLIGATIONS (Section 3.1(b))

**(a) Problematic Clause:**
"The Consultant covenants and agrees that, as long as he works for the Company, the Consultant will keep in strict confidence the Company's Confidential Information and will not, without prior written consent of the Company, disclose, use or otherwise disseminate the Company's Confidential Information, directly or indirectly, to any third party."

**(b) Why It's Concerning:**
- Confidentiality obligation only applies "as long as he works for the Company"
- No post-termination confidentiality protection for Company (actually benefits consultant)
- However, this is inconsistent with Section 3.1(c) which requires return of information upon termination
- Creates ambiguity about post-termination obligations
- Industry standard is perpetual confidentiality for trade secrets, 3-5 years for other confidential information

**(c) Suggested Revision:**
```
[MODIFY] Section 3.1(b):
"The Consultant covenants and agrees that, during the Term and for a period of three (3) years following termination of this Agreement for any reason, the Consultant will keep in strict confidence the Company's Confidential Information and will not, without prior written consent of the Company, disclose, use or otherwise disseminate the Company's Confidential Information, directly or indirectly, to any third party; provided, however, that Consultant's obligations with respect to trade secrets shall continue for so long as such information remains a trade secret under applicable law."
```

---

### 10. INADEQUATE SEVERANCE UPON TERMINATION WITHOUT CAUSE (Section 4.3)

**(a) Problematic Clause:**
Consultant receives only 2 years of base consulting fees upon termination without cause, with vesting continuing for only 12 months.

**(b) Why It's Concerning:**
- For a 3-year agreement, 2 years severance may seem generous, BUT:
- Base fee is only $8,500/month ($102,000/year), which is quite low for this level of responsibility
- The real value is in equity compensation (1,250,000 warrant shares + potential 1,500,000 bonus shares)
- Only 12 months of continued vesting means consultant loses significant equity value
- No acceleration of equity upon termination without cause
- Company can terminate and avoid most equity compensation obligations
- Consultant has already provided services and built value that justified the equity

```

"Termination without Cause. In the event this Agreement and the Consultant's engagement with the Company is terminated by the Company without Cause (other than for death or Disability or in connection with a change of control), then in addition to the amounts specified in Section 4.1 and subject to the Consultant's execution and non-revocation of a separation agreement containing a general release and waiver of liability against the Company and anyone connected with it in form acceptable to the Company, the Consultant shall be entitled to receive:

(a) Two (2) years Base Consulting Fee (less statutory deductions and withholdings) in a single lump sum, paid in full within 30 days of termination;

(b) One hundred percent (100%) acceleration of all unvested equity compensation, including but not limited to the warrants described in Section 2.1(b) and any other stock options, restricted stock, or equity awards granted to Consultant;

(c) All vested common shares and, if applicable, options and warrants, with the right to exercise such options and warrants for a period of two (2) years following termination (but not beyond the original expiration date of such securities)."
```

### 11. MISSING INDEMNIFICATION PROVISIONS

**(a) Problematic Clause:**

Here is a detailed review of the consulting agreement from the consultant's perspective, identifying problematic or unfair clauses with suggested revisions:

---

### **Problematic Clauses & Suggested Revisions**

#### **1. Term Length (Section 1.1(a))**
- **Problematic Clause**: The initial term is **3 years** with no early termination right for the consultant except for "Good Reason." This is overly restrictive and could trap the consultant in an unfavorable arrangement.
- **Why Concerning**: Limits flexibility and may not account for changes in the consultant’s circumstances or market conditions.
- **Suggested Revision**:  
  [MODIFY] "This Agreement will commence on the Effective Date and will continue for a period of **one (1) year**, automatically renewing for successive one-year terms unless either party provides **60 days’ written notice** of non-renewal."

---

#### **2. Scope of Services (Section 1.2(c))**
- **Problematic Clause**: The consultant must provide **"any other services not specifically mentioned herein"** if deemed necessary for the Company’s best interests.
- **Why Concerning**: Creates an open-ended obligation that could lead to scope creep without additional compensation.
- **Suggested Revision**:  
  [DELETE] "and the Consultant will provide any other services not specifically mentioned herein..."  
  [ADD] "The Consultant’s duties are limited to those explicitly described in this Agreement. Any additional services require a **written amendment** with mutually agreed compensation."

---

#### **3. Compensation Discrepancy (Section 2.1(a))**
- **Problematic Clause**: The Base Consulting Fee is listed as **$3,250** but later referenced as **$75,000**, creating ambiguity.
- **Why Concerning**: Risk of underpayment or disputes over the correct amount.
- **Suggested Revision**:  
  [MODIFY] "The Consultant’s monthly base consulting fee shall be **$75,000** (the 'Base Consulting Fee'), payable within the first five days of each calendar month."

---

#### **4. Equity Compensation (Section 2.1(b)–(d))**
- **Problematic Clauses**:  
  - Warrants are tied to **1,250,000 shares** but lack clarity on vesting schedules or liquidity rights.  
  - The one-time bonus of **1,500,000 shares** is contingent on NexGen’s stock reaching **$100M valuation**, which is subjective.  
- **Why Concerning**: Unclear terms could lead to disputes over equity valuation and eligibility.  
- **Suggested Revision**:  
  [ADD] "All equity grants shall vest **monthly over 3 years** and include standard acceleration upon termination without Cause. The Company will file a Registration Statement for the shares within **12 months** of issuance."

---

#### **5. Non-Compete (Article 3)**
- **Problematic Clause**: The agreement implies a non-compete (via confidentiality obligations) but lacks explicit terms (duration, scope, geography).  
- **Why Concerning**: Overly broad restrictions could limit the consultant’s future work.  
- **Suggested Revision**:  
  [ADD] "Consultant agrees not to compete with the Company in **North America** for **6 months** post-termination, limited to **investor relations and commercial development** services."

---

#### **6. Termination Notice Disparity (Section 4.1(b))**
- **Problematic Clause**: The Company may terminate with **60 days’ notice**, while the consultant must give **120 days’ notice**.  
- **Why Concerning**: Unbalanced and burdensome for the consultant.  
- **Suggested Revision**:  
  [MODIFY] "Consultant may terminate this Agreement by providing **60 days’ prior written notice**."

---

#### **7. Survival of Compensation (Section 4.1(f))**
- **Problematic Clause**: The Company may cease services during the notice period but must still pay compensation. However, equity vesting terms are unclear.  
- **Why Concerning**: Risk of losing unvested equity if terminated.  
- **Suggested Revision**:  
  [ADD] "All unvested equity shall **immediately vest** upon termination by either party."

---

#### **8. Governing Law & Jurisdiction (Section 7.10)**
- **Problematic Clause**: New York law and courts are mandatory, which may disadvantage an international consultant.  
- **Why Concerning**: Costly and inconvenient for dispute resolution.  
- **Suggested Revision**:  
  [MODIFY] "This Agreement shall be governed by **Delaware law**, with disputes resolved via **binding arbitration** under the ICC Rules."

---

#### **9. Invoice Submission (Section 7.5)**
- **Problematic Clause**: The Company may pay a third party (e.g., the consultant’s employer) without guaranteeing the consultant’s receipt of funds.  
- **Why Concerning**: Risk of payment diversion.  
- **Suggested Revision**:  
  [ADD] "The Company remains **directly liable** to Consultant for all fees unless Consultant provides **written authorization** for third-party payment."

1. **Clarify Compensation**: Fix fee discrepancies and define equity vesting.  
2. **Limit Scope Creep**: Explicitly cap services to the agreed scope.  
3. **Balance Termination Rights**: Equalize notice periods and protect equity.  
4. **Add Dispute Resolution**: Replace New York jurisdiction with arbitration.

Based on my review of the consulting agreement from the consultant's perspective, I have identified several problematic and unfair clauses. Here is a detailed analysis with suggested revisions:

## Problematic Clauses Analysis

### 1. **Ambiguous and Potentially Unfair Compensation Terms**
**Clause:** Section 2.1(a) - Base Consulting Fee
- **Problem:** The clause contains contradictory information ($3,250 vs $75,000 vs $8,500) and outdated dates (2020). The reference to "Company's normal payroll procedures" is vague and could lead to payment delays.
- **Concern:** The consultant may face payment disputes or delays due to unclear terms.
- **Suggested Revision:** 
  ```
  [MODIFY] The Consultant's monthly base consulting fee shall be $8,500 United States dollars (the "Base Consulting Fee"). The Base Consulting Fee shall be payable on the first day of each calendar month by wire transfer to the Consultant's designated bank account. All subsequent monthly payments shall be made on or before the 5th day of each following calendar month.
  ```

### 2. **Unlimited Scope of Services**
**Clause:** Section 1.2(c) - Additional Services
- **Problem:** The clause requires the consultant to provide "any other services not specifically mentioned herein" which creates an open-ended obligation.
- **Concern:** This could be exploited to demand services beyond the agreed scope without additional compensation.
- **Suggested Revision:**
  ```
  [MODIFY] The Consultant will provide any other services not specifically mentioned herein only if: (i) such services are within the Consultant's professional expertise; (ii) such services are reasonably related to the Company's business interests; and (iii) the Company provides additional compensation for such services as mutually agreed in writing.
  ```

### 3. **Unilateral Control Over Duties**
**Clause:** Section 1.2(d) - Implementation of Duties
- **Problem:** The consultant must "assume, obey, implement and execute such duties... as may be determined or given from time to time by the Company" without limitation.
- **Concern:** This gives the Company excessive control to change duties unilaterally.
- **Suggested Revision:**
  ```
  [MODIFY] The Consultant will assume, obey, implement and execute such duties, directions, responsibilities, procedures, policies and lawful orders as may be determined or given from time to time by the Company, provided that such duties are consistent with the Consultant's role as described in Section 1.2(a)-(c) and do not constitute a material change in responsibilities without the Consultant's written consent.
  ```

### 4. **Uncertain Bonus and Equity Compensation**
**Clause:** Section 2.1(c) - Bonus and Stock
- **Problem:** The bonus provision is vague ("up to a one-time bonus") and references another company's stock (NexGen Analytics) which is not a party to this agreement.
- **Concern:** The consultant may never receive the promised bonus or equity compensation.
- **Suggested Revision:**
  ```
  [MODIFY] The Consultant shall be entitled to receive a one-time bonus of 1,500,000 shares of common stock of TechVenture Solutions Inc. (the "Company"), valued at $100 million dollars, upon achievement of mutually agreed performance milestones to be documented in writing within 90 days of the Effective Date.
  ```

### 5. **Asymmetric Termination Notice Periods**
**Clause:** Section 4.1(b)(ii) - Consultant Termination Without Good Reason
- **Problem:** The consultant must provide 120 days' notice to terminate without good reason, while the Company only needs 60 days.
- **Concern:** This creates an unfair imbalance in termination rights.
- **Suggested Revision:**
  ```
  [MODIFY] The Consultant may voluntarily terminate the Consultant's engagement with the Company at any time by giving the Company 60 days prior written Notice of the termination.
  ```

### 6. **Vague Definition of "Cause"**
**Clause:** Section 4.1(d) - Definition of Cause
- **Problem:** "Gross negligence" and "material breach" are subjective terms that could be interpreted broadly.
- **Concern:** The Company might terminate for minor infractions claiming "cause."
- **Suggested Revision:**
  ```
  [MODIFY] For the purpose of this Article 4, "Cause" means: (i) Consultant's willful and material breach of this Agreement, not cured after 30 days' written notice specifying the breach; (ii) Consultant's repeated negligence after written warning; (iii) Consultant's conviction of a felony involving fraud or dishonesty; or (iv) Consultant's willful misconduct that materially harms the Company's business.
  ```

### 7. **Restrictive Confidentiality Obligations**
**Clause:** Section 3.1(b) - Maintenance of Confidential Information
- **Problem:** The confidentiality obligation extends indefinitely ("as long as he works for the Company") but doesn't specify post-termination duration.
- **Concern:** The consultant might be bound by indefinite confidentiality obligations.
- **Suggested Revision:**
  ```
  [MODIFY] The Consultant covenants and agrees that during the term of this Agreement and for a period of three (3) years following termination, the Consultant will keep in strict confidence the Company's Confidential Information...
  ```

### 8. **Problematic Notice Provision**
**Clause:** Section 6.1(a) - Company Notice Address
- **Problem:** The Company's address is "to be provided" and if not provided, notices sent to any known email address are deemed received regardless of actual receipt.
- **Concern:** The consultant cannot ensure proper notice delivery to the Company.
- **Suggested Revision:**
  ```
  [MODIFY] in the case of the Company, to: TechVenture Solutions Inc., 350 Fifth Avenue, Suite 1800, New York, NY 10118, Attention: Chief Executive Officer, with a copy to legal@techventure.com; or to such other address as may be designated by the Company in writing.
  ```

### 9. **Unfair Assignment Provision**
**Clause:** Section 7.4 - Assignment
- **Problem:** The agreement automatically binds any successor company in a merger or acquisition without the consultant's consent.
- **Concern:** The consultant could be forced to work for an undesirable successor entity.
- **Suggested Revision:**
  ```
  [MODIFY] For the avoidance of doubt, it is agreed that in the event that the Company participates in a merger, acquisition, restructuring, reorganization or other transaction, this Agreement will remain in force only if the successor company expressly assumes in writing all obligations hereunder, and the Consultant shall have the right to terminate this Agreement within 30 days of such transaction if the successor is not acceptable to the Consultant in his sole discretion.
  ```

### 10. **Warrant Exercise Issues**
**Clause:** Annex A, Section 1.1(c)(ii) - Fair Market Value Determination
- **Problem:** If the stock is not publicly traded, the Board determines fair market value "in good faith" without objective criteria.
- **Concern:** The Board could undervalue the stock to minimize the consultant's warrant value.
- **Suggested Revision:**
  ```
  [MODIFY] If the Company's Common Stock is not so publicly traded, the per share fair market value shall be determined by an independent third-party valuation firm selected jointly by the Company and the Consultant, or if they cannot agree, by a firm appointed by the American Arbitration Association.
  ```

## Additional Concerns

1. **Governing Law:** The agreement is governed by New York law while the consultant resides in Israel, which could create practical difficulties in enforcing rights.

2. **Dispute Resolution:** There is no specified dispute resolution mechanism (arbitration/mediation), which could lead to costly litigation.

3. **Indemnification:** The agreement lacks an indemnification clause to protect the consultant from liabilities arising from the performance of duties.

4. **Insurance:** No provision requiring the Company to maintain appropriate insurance coverage.

## Recommendations

1. Request clarification and correction of all compensation amounts and dates.
2. Negotiate more balanced termination provisions.
3. Add specific performance milestones for bonus and equity compensation.
4. Include a dispute resolution clause with arbitration in a neutral location.
5. Add an indemnification provision protecting the consultant.
6. Consider adding a "most favored nations" clause ensuring the consultant receives terms at least as favorable as other consultants.

These revisions would help create a more balanced and fair agreement that protects the consultant's interests while maintaining the business relationship's integrity.

  Suggested revision: [MODIFY] Replace all party and date references with a single, consistent set: (a) “Company: TechVenture Solutions Inc., a Delaware corporation (or Nevada, as applicable—pick one and conform throughout)”; (b) “Consultant: Aitan Zacharin”; (c) “Effective Date: [October 22, 2024]”; (d) correct all dates in Article 2 to align with the Effective Date; (e) signature blocks for Company and Consultant only; remove NexGen signature unless it is a party/issuer with obligations; (f) correct Appendix 1 to reference TechVenture; (g) re-issue Annex A with the correct issuer and issue date synchronized to this agreement.

- Clause: Section 2.1(a) Base Consulting Fee (typo/ambiguity)
  Why: The text states “three thousand two hundred fifty United States dollars ($75,000 …) through 19 August 2020. Commencing on 20 August 2020, … $8,500 per calendar month.” Amounts and dates conflict, and the timeframes predate the (2024) Effective Date. This invites underpayment disputes.
  Suggested revision: [MODIFY] “Consultant’s Base Consulting Fee is $[X] per month, payable monthly in arrears, within 10 days of invoice, for services rendered in the prior month, commencing as of the Effective Date.” Remove all 2020 references.

- Clause: Section 2.1(a) “payable in accordance with the Company’s normal payroll procedures”
  Why: Referring to “payroll” suggests employee treatment and withholding, which risks misclassification, tax exposure (including in Israel), and benefit disputes for a true independent contractor.

- Clause: Section 2.1(c) “eligible to participate in benefit plans … of general applicability to other consultants”
  Why: Benefits language is inconsistent with independent contractor status and could trigger misclassification/tax risks.

- Clause: Section 2.1(b) Warrant; Annex A
  Why: Equity issuer appears to be TechVenture; other sections reference NexGen. Annex A’s Issue Date is 2020; Appendix 1 references “SLINGER BAG INC.” Inconsistencies threaten enforceability and delivery. No vesting schedule is stated, yet Article 4 references “unvested” equity.
  Suggested revision: [MODIFY] Confirm issuer (TechVenture or NexGen) and conform throughout; attach a corrected Warrant with (a) Issue Date aligned with this agreement; (b) clear vesting (e.g., 1/48th monthly over 4 years, with 100% acceleration upon a termination Without Cause or for Good Reason and upon Change in Control if terminated within 12 months); (c) a reasonable exercise price; (d) a 10‑year term from the corrected Issue Date; (e) corrected exercise notice naming the correct issuer.

- Clause: Section 1.1(b), 1.2(c) standard of performance (“maximum professional skill and care”)
