EXHIBIT 10.43 THIS AGREEMENT is dated

Parties

(1) Signature Orthopaedics Pty Ltd (ACN 106 702 416), 7 Sirius Road, Lane Cove, NSW

(2) NexGen Analytics Inc. of 1565N. Central Expressway, Suite 200, Dallas, TX 75080.

Background

The Supplier wishes to appoint the Distributor as its non-exclusive distributor for the promotion and sale of the Products within the Territory (both as defined below), and the Distributor wishes to promote and sell the Products within the Territory on the terms of this agreement.

Agreed terms

1. Definitions and interpretation

1.1 The definitions and rules of interpretation in this clause apply in this agreement.

Business Day: a day (other than a Saturday, Sunday or public holiday in Australia) when banks in Sydney are open for business.

Commencement Date: means the date of this agreement.

Control: the ability to direct the affairs of another person, whether by virtue of the ownership of shares, contract or otherwise.

Inactive Territories means a country in which the Distributor has not sold or supplied the Product during the Initial Term.

Initial Term has the meaning given to it in clause 12.1.

Products: As defined in Schedule 1 and includes any other products developed by the Supplier and which the Supplier may permit the Distributor, by express notice in writing, to distribute in the Territory.

Term: the term of this agreement, as determined in accordance with clause 11. Territory: means the territory specified in Schedule 2.

Trade Marks: the trade mark registrations listed in Schedule 3 and any further trade marks that the Supplier may permit, or procure permission for, the Distributor to use in the Territory in respect of the Products by express notice in writing.

GST: goods and services tax chargeable under the Goods and Services Tax Act and any similar replacement or additional tax or such other similar or analogous form of tax under the laws and regulations in the Territory.

Year: the period of 12 months from the Commencement Date and each consecutive period of 12 months thereafter during the Term.

1.2 Clause, schedule and paragraph headings shall not affect the interpretation of this agreement.

1.3 A person includes a natural person, corporate or unincorporated body (whether or not having separate legal personality).

1.4 The Schedules form part of this agreement and shall have effect as if set out in full in the body of this agreement. Any reference to this agreement includes the Schedules.

1.5 A reference to a company shall include any company, corporation or other body corporate, wherever and however incorporated or established.

1.6 Words in the singular shall include the plural and vice versa.

1.7 A reference to one gender shall include a reference to the other genders.

1.8 A reference to any party shall include that party's personal representatives, successors or permitted assigns.

1.9 A reference to a statute, statutory provision or any subordinated legislation made under a statute is a reference to such statute, provision or subordinated legislation as amended or re-enacted from time to time, whether before or after the date of this agreement and in the case of a reference to a statute is also to all subordinate legislation made under that statute whether before or after the date of this agreement.

1.10 A reference to writing or written includes faxes and e-mail.

1.11 Documents in agreed form are documents in the form agreed by the parties and initialled by or on behalf of them for identification.

1.12 Any reference to a legal term for any action, remedy, method of judicial proceeding, legal document, legal status, court, official or any legal concept or thing shall, in respect of any jurisdiction other than Australia, be deemed to include a reference to what most nearly approximates to the Australian legal term in that jurisdiction.

1.13 A reference to a document is a reference to that document as varied or novated (in each case, other than in breach of the provisions of this agreement) at any time.

1.14 References to clauses and schedules are to the clauses and schedules of this agreement.

1.15 Any phrase introduced by the terms including, include, in particular or any similar expression shall be construed as illustrative and shall not limit the sense of the words preceding those terms.

2. Appointment

2.1 The Supplier appoints the Distributor as its non-exclusive distributor to distribute the Products in the Territory on the terms of this agreement.

2.2 Following the expiry of the Initial Term, the Supplier may amend the Territory to remove any Inactive Territories.

2.3 Notwithstanding 2.1 and 2.2, the Supplier may sell or supply the Products to end users within USA at anytime.

2.4 The Distributor shall not:

(a) represent itself as an agent of the Supplier for any purpose; or

(b) pledge the Supplier's credit; or

(c) give any condition or warranty on the Supplier's behalf except for any warranty or guarantee which cannot be excluded under law; or

(d) make any representation on the Supplier's behalf; or

(e) commit the Supplier to any contracts; or

(f) act as the agent or the buying agent, for any person for any goods which are competitive with the Product; or

(g) retain any monies of the Supplier except on a trustee or fiduciary basis; or

(h) knowingly make any false or misleading statement to any supplier or service provider, or to the Distributor or its business, about the Products or the liability of the Supplier for the cost of any goods or services supplied to the Distributor or its business; or

(i) incur any liability or assume any obligation on behalf of the Supplier; or

2.5 The Distributor shall not without the Supplier's prior written consent make any promises or guarantees about the Products beyond those:

(a) agreed between the Distributor and the Supplier; and

(b) contained in any promotional material supplied by the Supplier.

3. Distributor's undertakings

The Distributor undertakes and agrees with the Supplier that at all times during the Term it will:

(a) use all reasonable endeavours to promote the distribution and sale of the Products;

(b) not use any promotional or advertising material for the Products not approved by the Supplier, such approval not be unreasonably withheld;

(c) provide Yearly non-binding sales forecasts;

(d) establish and maintain documented procedures for identifying the Products with a control number for traceability and copies of those records and procedures must be made available to the Supplier within thirty (30) days of request;

(e) provide regular reports on the sales activities within the Territory;

(f) employ a sufficient number of suitably qualified personnel to ensure the proper fulfilment of the Distributor's obligations under this agreement;

(g) maintain, on its own account, an inventory of the Products at levels which are appropriate and adequate for the Distributor to meet all customer delivery requirements for the Products throughout the Territory;

(h) keep full and proper books of account and records clearly showing all enquiries, quotations, transactions and proceedings relating to the Products;

(i) allow the Supplier, on reasonable notice, access to its accounts and records relating to the sale or distribution of the Products for inspection but not more than once in each year. For clarity, the Supplier will not be permitted access to any accounts or records which do not directly relate to the sale or distribution of the Products;

(j) comply with any reasonable directives or instructions given by the Supplier for any promotional activities, at the suppliers cost, concerning the nature, type, quality, characteristics, fitness for purpose, suitability, use and description of the Products;

4. Supply of products

4.1 The parties acknowledge that:

(a) the Supplier is the manufacturer of the Products; and

(b) the Supplier will have no obligation to separately supply the Products, except as otherwise provided for in this Agreement.

4.2 Supplier's undertakings

The Supplier undertakes to:

(a) provide information and support that may reasonably be requested by the Distributor to enable it to discharge its duties under this agreement properly and efficiently; and

(b) approve or reject any promotional information or material submitted by the Distributor within 28 days of receipt.

5. Prices and payment

5.1 The prices to be paid by the Distributor to the Supplier for the Products are to be the Price, as set out in Schedule 4.

5.2 Any and all expenses, costs and charges incurred by the Distributor in the performance of its obligations under this agreement will be paid by the Distributor, unless the Supplier has expressly agreed in advance in writing to pay such expenses, costs and charges.

5.3 The Distributor must pay the full amount invoiced to it by the Supplier in USD$'s within thirty (45) days of the date of invoice.

5.4 Neither party may withhold payment of any amount due to the other because of any set-off, counter-claim, abatement, or other similar deduction.

6. GST and taxes (Only Applicable to Australian companies)

6.1 All sums payable under this agreement, or otherwise payable by any party to any other party under this agreement are exclusive of any GST chargeable on the supplies for which such sums (or any part of them) are the whole or part of the consideration for GST purposes.

6.2 Where, under this agreement, any party makes a supply to any other party (Recipient) for GST purposes and GST is or becomes chargeable on that supply for which the supplying party is required to account to the relevant tax authority, the Recipient shall, subject to the receipt of a valid GST invoice, pay the supplying party (in addition to, and at the same time as, any other consideration for that supply) the amount of such GST.

6.3 Where any party is required by this agreement to reimburse or indemnify any other party for any cost or expense, that first party shall reimburse or indemnify the other party for the full amount of the cost or expense, including any GST on that amount,

except to the extent that the other party is entitled to credit or repayment for that GST from any relevant tax authority.

6.4 All import taxes, charges, levies, assessments and other fees of any kind imposed on the purchase or import of the Products shall be the responsibility of, and for the account of, the Distributor.

7. Advertising and promotion

7.1 The Distributor shall:

(a) cooperate with the Supplier in relation to the promotion and advertisement of the Products;

(b) not make any written statement as to the quality or manufacture of the Products without the prior written approval of the Supplier; and

(c) pays its own costs of advertising the Product except where there is any separate advertising campaign which the Supplier and the Distributor have agreed to fund jointly in any agreed proportion.

8. Anti-bribery compliance

8.1 The Distributor shall:

(a) comply with all applicable laws, statutes and regulations relating to anti-bribery and anti- corruption; and

(b) not engage in any activity, practice or conduct which would constitute an offence.

9. Trade marks and intellectual property

9.1 The Supplier hereby grants to the Distributor the non-exclusive right, in the Territory, to use the Trade Marks in the promotion, advertisement and sale of the Products, subject to, and for the duration of, this agreement.

9.2 The Distributor may sell and/or distribute the Products using the Trade Marks in conjunction with any trade marks owned or licensed by the Distributor.

9.3 All representations of the Trade Marks that the Distributor intends to use shall be submitted to the Supplier for approval before use.

9.4 Within limiting this clause 12, the Distributor shall be entitled to add a label to the Products it purchases to show that the products purchased are being distributed by the Distributor.

9.5 The Supplier represents and warrants that:

(a) Trade Marks; and

(b) The Products, do not infringe any intellectual property rights of any third parties and the Supplier agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the Distributor against any clauses by a third party for infringement of intellectual property rights in relation to the Products or the Trade marks.

9.6 The Distributor shall not sub-license, transfer or otherwise deal with the rights of use of the Trade Marks granted under this agreement.

9.7 The Distributor shall not do, or omit to do, anything in its use of the Trade Marks that could adversely affect their validity or the goodwill of the Supplier.

9.8 The Distributor shall immediately enter into any document necessary for the recording, registration or safeguarding of the Supplier's Trade Mark rights with the Supplier for the marketing of the Products under the Trade Marks in a form satisfactory to the Supplier, at the suppliers cost.

9.9 Each party shall promptly give notice in writing to the other if it becomes aware of:

(a) any infringement or suspected infringement of the Trade Marks or any other intellectual property rights relating to the Products within the Territory; or

(b) any claim that any Product or the manufacture, use, sale or other disposal of any Product within the Territory, whether or not under the Trade Marks, infringes the rights of any third party,

9.10 In respect of any matter that falls within clause 9.9(a):

(a) the Supplier shall in its absolute discretion, decide what action to take in respect of the matter (if any);

(b) the Supplier shall conduct and have sole control over any consequent action that it deems necessary; and

(c) the Supplier shall pay all costs in relation to that action and shall be entitled to all damages and other sums that may be paid or awarded as a result of that action.

9.11 In respect of any matter that falls within clause 9.9(b):

(a) the Supplier and the Distributor shall agree:

(i) what steps to take to prevent or terminate the infringement; and

(ii) the proportions in which they shall share the cost of those steps and any damages and other sums which may be awarded to or against them, being agreed between the parties that the Supplier shall hold Distributor harmless against any damages connected with any material or workmanship defect of the Products; and

(b) failing agreement between the parties, either party may take any action as it considers necessary or appropriate, at its own expense, to defend the claim and shall be entitled to and responsible for all damages and other sums that may be recovered or awarded against it as a result of that action.

9.12 Each party shall, at the request and expense of the other, provide any reasonable assistance to the other (including the use of its name in, or being joined as a party to, proceedings) with any action to be taken by the other party under this clause 9, provided that that party is given such indemnity as it may reasonably require against any losses, costs and expenses it may incur as a result of or in connection with providing such assistance.

10. Product liability and insurance

10.1 Subject to the Distributor fulfilling all the conditions in this clause 10, the Supplier shall indemnify the Distributor, defend and hold harmless against any liability incurred by the Distributor in respect of damage to property, death or personal injury arising from any fault or defect in the design of the Products and any reasonable costs, claims, demands and expenses, including reasonable attorneys' fees, arising out of or in connection with that liability (Relevant Claim), except to the extent the liability arises as a result of the wilful misconduct of the Distributor. The Supplier shall add the distributor to their current insurance certificate.

10.2 The Distributor shall, within five days of a matter which may result in a Relevant Claim:

(a) give the Supplier written notice of the details of the matter;

(b) give the Supplier access to and allow copies to be taken of any materials, records or documents as the Supplier may require to take action under clause 10.2(c);

(c) allow the Supplier the exclusive conduct of any proceedings and take any action that the Supplier requires to defend or resist the matter, including using professional advisers nominated by the Supplier; and

(d) not admit liability or settle the matter without the Supplier's written consent.

10.3 During the Term, the Supplier shall maintain product liability insurance with a reputable insurer of no less than AU$25,000 million for any one occurrence for any and all liability (however arising) for a claim that the Products are faulty or defective. The Supplier shall provide a copy of the insurance policy to the Distributor on request.

10.4 The Distributor undertakes to maintain appropriate, up-to-date and accurate records to enable the immediate recall of any Products or batches of Products from the retail or wholesale markets. These records shall include records of deliveries to customers (including batch numbers, delivery date, name and address of customer, telephone number, fax number and e-mail address).

10.5 The Distributor shall, at the Supplier's cost, give any assistance that the Supplier shall reasonably require to recall, as a matter of urgency, Products from the retail or wholesale market.

11. Duration and termination

11.1 This agreement begins on the Commencement Date and, subject to clause 11.2, shall continue for an initial term of one (1) years (Initial Term) and indefinitely after that until terminated by either party giving at least twelve (12) months' prior written notice to expire on or after the expiry date of the initial term.

(b) the other party commits a material breach of any material term of this agreement and (if such breach is remediable) fails to remedy that breach within a period of 14 days of being notified in writing to do so; or

### Schedule 2 - Territory and Distribution Rights

#### 2A. EXCLUSIVE TERRITORY

The Distributor is hereby granted exclusive distribution rights for the Products in the following states (the "Exclusive Territory"):

(a) California  
(b) Oregon  
(c) Washington

Within the Exclusive Territory, the Supplier agrees that it shall not:

(i) directly sell or distribute the Products to any third party;  
(ii) appoint any other distributor or sales representative;  
(iii) solicit orders for the Products; or  
(iv) fulfill orders for the Products, except as provided in clause 2A(c) below.

#### 2B. NON-EXCLUSIVE TERRITORY

The Distributor is hereby granted non-exclusive distribution rights for the Products in all other states within the United States of America, excluding the Exclusive Territory (the "Non-Exclusive Territory"). Within the Non-Exclusive Territory, the Supplier reserves the right to:

(a) sell or distribute the Products directly to end users;  
(b) appoint additional distributors or sales representatives; and  
(c) engage in any other sales or distribution activities without restriction.

#### 2C. ONLINE SALES AND E-COMMERCE

(a) The Distributor may sell the Products through online channels, including but not limited to its own website, third-party e-commerce platforms, and digital marketplaces, subject to the following provisions:

(i) For sales where the Products are shipped to a delivery address located within the Exclusive Territory, such sales shall be deemed exclusive to the Distributor regardless of where the online transaction was initiated or processed;

(ii) For sales where the Products are shipped to a delivery address located within the Non-Exclusive Territory, such sales shall be subject to the non-exclusive provisions of clause 2B;

(iii) The Distributor shall implement reasonable technical measures to identify the shipping destination of online orders prior to order fulfillment;

(iv) The Distributor's online presence, including websites and digital advertising, may be accessible nationwide, provided that the Distributor shall not specifically target or direct advertising to customers outside the Exclusive Territory in a manner that would undermine the Supplier's rights in the Non-Exclusive Territory.

(b) The Supplier may sell the Products through its own online channels nationwide, provided that:

(i) For orders with shipping destinations in the Exclusive Territory, the Supplier shall refer such customers to the Distributor or, if the Supplier fulfills such orders directly, shall pay the Distributor a referral commission equal to [INSERT PERCENTAGE]% of the net sale price;

(ii) The Supplier shall not engage in targeted online advertising or marketing specifically directed at customers in the Exclusive Territory.

#### 2D. CROSS-BORDER SALES AND CUSTOMER LOCATION

(a) For purposes of determining territorial rights under this Agreement, a sale shall be deemed to occur in the jurisdiction where the Products are delivered to the end customer, regardless of:

(i) where the purchase order was placed;  
(ii) where the purchasing entity is incorporated or has its principal place of business;  
(iii) where payment is processed; or  
(iv) the billing address of the customer.

(b) If a customer located outside the Exclusive Territory requests delivery of Products to an address within the Exclusive Territory, such sale shall be treated as occurring within the Exclusive Territory and subject to the Distributor's exclusive rights.

(c) If a customer located within the Exclusive Territory requests delivery of Products to an address outside the Exclusive Territory, such sale shall be treated as occurring outside the Exclusive Territory and subject to the non-exclusive provisions of clause 2B.

(d) Neither party shall engage in practices designed to circumvent the territorial provisions of this Agreement, including but not limited to:

(i) establishing sham delivery addresses;  
(ii) encouraging customers to provide false shipping information;  
(iii) routing shipments through intermediary locations to obscure the final destination; or  
(iv) splitting orders to avoid territorial restrictions.

#### 2E. NATIONAL ACCOUNTS AND MULTI-STATE CUSTOMERS

(a) For customers with locations in multiple states spanning both the Exclusive Territory and Non-Exclusive Territory ("National Accounts"), the parties agree to negotiate in good faith regarding the allocation of such accounts, taking into consideration:

(i) the primary location of the customer's purchasing decision-maker;  
(ii) the volume of Products to be delivered to each territory;  
(iii) existing relationships between either party and the customer; and  
(iv) the ability of each party to service the account effectively.

(b) Unless otherwise agreed in writing, sales to National Accounts shall be allocated based on the delivery destination of each individual order in accordance with clause 2D(a).

#### 2F. PASSIVE SALES

The Distributor shall not be restricted from accepting and fulfilling unsolicited orders from customers located outside the Exclusive Territory ("Passive Sales"), provided that the Distributor does not actively solicit such orders through targeted marketing, advertising, or sales efforts directed at the Non-Exclusive Territory.

---

## SUMMARY OF KEY CHANGES

**1. Exclusive vs. Non-Exclusive Rights:** Clearly delineates California, Oregon, and Washington as exclusive territory, with all other U.S. states as non-exclusive.

**2. Online Sales Provisions:** Establishes that territorial rights are determined by shipping destination, not transaction location, addressing the complexities of e-commerce.

**3. Cross-Border Clarity:** Provides detailed rules for determining where a sale occurs, preventing disputes over customers who order from one location but ship to another.

**4. Anti-Circumvention:** Prohibits both parties from engaging in practices designed to undermine territorial restrictions.

**5. National Accounts:** Addresses the common issue of multi-state customers with a framework for good-faith negotiation.

**6. Passive Sales:** Permits the Distributor to accept unsolicited orders from outside the exclusive territory, which is standard in distribution agreements.

**7. Supplier Online Sales:** Allows the Supplier to maintain online presence while protecting the Distributor's exclusive territory through referral commissions.

These revisions provide comprehensive protection for both parties while addressing modern distribution challenges including e-commerce and cross-border transactions.

**Legal Analysis and Rationale for Revisions:**

The primary goal is to establish exclusive distribution rights for California, Oregon, and Washington, while maintaining non-exclusive rights for all other U.S. states. Additionally, clarity on online sales and cross-border issues is required.

1.  **Definition of "Territory" (Schedule 2 and Clause 1.1):**
    *   The original definition of "Territory" as simply "USA" is too broad for the intended exclusive/non-exclusive split.
    *   A new definition is needed to clearly delineate the "Exclusive Territory" (CA, OR, WA) and the "Non-Exclusive Territory" (all other U.S. states).
    *   This split is crucial for the operational clauses that follow.

2.  **Appointment Clause (Clause 2.1):**
    *   The original Clause 2.1 states a "non-exclusive distributor... within the Territory." This needs to be modified to reflect the dual nature of the distribution rights.
    *   It's essential to explicitly state the exclusive appointment for the specified states and the non-exclusive appointment for the remainder of the U.S.

3.  **Online Sales and Cross-Border Issues:**
    *   The original contract is silent on online sales, which is a significant gap given modern distribution channels.
    *   To address this, a new sub-clause is added to Clause 2.1. This clause clarifies that online sales originating from the Exclusive Territory are covered by the exclusive rights, and sales into the Exclusive Territory from outside are restricted.
    *   For the Non-Exclusive Territory, online sales are permitted consistent with the non-exclusive nature.
    *   The concept of "originating from" and "shipping into" helps define the scope of online sales within the respective territories.
    *   A provision is also added to prevent the Distributor from actively marketing or selling into the Exclusive Territory from outside, or from the Exclusive Territory into other exclusive territories the Supplier might establish.

4.  **Supplier's Right to Sell (Clause 2.3):**
    *   The original Clause 2.3 allows the Supplier to sell directly to end users within the USA at any time. This directly conflicts with the concept of exclusive distribution.
    *   This clause must be modified to carve out the Exclusive Territory, meaning the Supplier cannot directly sell into California, Oregon, or Washington. They retain the right to sell directly into the Non-Exclusive Territory.

5.  **Distributor's Undertakings (Clause 3):**
    *   Clause 3(a) ("use all reasonable endeavours to promote the distribution and sale of the Products") is generally fine, but the intensity of "endeavours" might be interpreted differently for exclusive vs. non-exclusive territories. While not strictly necessary to redline, it's an area where performance expectations could be further clarified in a separate schedule if desired. For this revision, the general undertaking remains.

6.  **Trade Marks and Intellectual Property (Clause 9.1):**
    *   The grant of rights to use trademarks in Clause 9.1 should align with the revised territory structure. The non-exclusive right to use trademarks should apply to the entire Territory (both exclusive and non-exclusive parts), as the Distributor will be operating in both.

2. **Online Sales Attribution**: Establishes clear rules for determining which state's rights apply to online transactions based on customer location data

**Revised Clause 2: Appointment**

2.1 The Supplier appoints the Distributor as its [MODIFY] exclusive distributor for the promotion and sale of the Products in the states of California, Oregon, and Washington, and as its non-exclusive distributor for all other U.S. states [END MODIFY] on the terms of this agreement.

(d) make any representation on the Supplier's behalf; or

Below is a **redlined revision** of the **Territory Clause** (Clause 2.1, Schedule 2, and related provisions) to reflect **exclusive distribution rights in California, Oregon, and Washington** and **non-exclusive rights in all other U.S. states**, while addressing **online sales and cross-border issues**. The revisions also ensure clarity on **jurisdictional conflicts, passive sales, and direct supplier sales**.

### **1. Modifications to Clause 2 (Appointment)**
#### **Current Text (Clause 2.1):**
> *"2.1 The Supplier appoints the Distributor as its **non-exclusive** distributor to distribute the Products in the Territory on the terms of this agreement."*

#### **Revised Text (Redlined):**
> **"2.1 Territory and Exclusivity**
> **(a) Exclusive Territory.** The Supplier appoints the Distributor as its **sole and exclusive** distributor for the promotion, marketing, and sale of the Products within the **Exclusive Territory** (as defined in Schedule 2), subject to the terms of this Agreement. During the Term, the Supplier shall not, without the Distributor’s prior written consent:
>   (i) appoint any other distributor for the Exclusive Territory;
>   (ii) sell or supply the Products directly to end users within the Exclusive Territory, except as permitted under Clause 2.3; or
>   (iii) engage in any activity that would undermine the Distributor’s exclusivity in the Exclusive Territory.
>
> **(b) Non-Exclusive Territory.** For the **Non-Exclusive Territory** (as defined in Schedule 2), the Supplier appoints the Distributor as a **non-exclusive** distributor. The Supplier retains the right to:
>   (i) appoint additional distributors;
>   (ii) sell or supply the Products directly to end users; or
>   (iii) engage in any other commercial activity in the Non-Exclusive Territory without restriction.
>
> **[ADD] (c) Online Sales and Cross-Border Restrictions.**
>   (i) **Online Sales.** The Distributor may sell the Products online to customers **physically located within the Exclusive Territory**, provided that:
>     - The Distributor implements **geo-blocking, IP verification, or other commercially reasonable measures** to prevent sales to customers outside the Exclusive Territory;
>     - The Distributor’s website and marketing materials **clearly state** that online sales are restricted to the Exclusive Territory; and
>     - The Distributor **does not fulfill orders** for shipment to addresses outside the Exclusive Territory without the Supplier’s prior written consent.
>   (ii) **Passive Sales.** The Distributor shall not **actively solicit** sales outside the Exclusive Territory (e.g., through targeted advertising, cold outreach, or trade shows). However, the Distributor may fulfill **unsolicited orders** from customers in the Non-Exclusive Territory, provided such sales do not conflict with the Supplier’s existing distribution agreements.
>   (iii) **Cross-Border Issues.** If a customer in the Non-Exclusive Territory attempts to purchase Products for use or resale in the Exclusive Territory, the Distributor shall **notify the Supplier promptly** and **decline the sale** unless authorized in writing by the Supplier.
>   (iv) **Supplier’s Direct Sales.** Notwithstanding Clause 2.1(a), the Supplier reserves the right to sell Products **directly to national accounts, government entities, or multi-state corporate customers** (e.g., hospital chains, GPOs) with operations in the Exclusive Territory, provided the Supplier:
>     - **Notifies the Distributor in writing** at least **30 days prior** to any such sale;
>     - **Offers the Distributor a right of first refusal** to fulfill the order on commercially reasonable terms; and
>     - **Compensates the Distributor** with a **commission of [X]%** of the net revenue from such sales (payable within 30 days of invoice)."

#### **Rationale for Changes:**
- **Exclusivity Carve-Out:** Clearly delineates **exclusive** (CA, OR, WA) vs. **non-exclusive** (other U.S. states) territories.
- **Online Sales Controls:** Addresses **jurisdictional conflicts** by requiring geo-blocking and prohibiting fulfillment to out-of-territory addresses.
- **Passive vs. Active Sales:** Permits **unsolicited orders** (passive sales) but prohibits **active solicitation** outside the Exclusive Territory.
- **Supplier’s Direct Sales:** Balances the Supplier’s need for **national accounts** while protecting the Distributor’s exclusivity via **right of first refusal** and **commission**.

### **6. Summary of Key Legal Considerations**
1. **Antitrust Compliance (U.S.):**
   - Exclusivity is **generally permissible** under U.S. antitrust law (e.g., *Continental T.V., Inc. v. GTE Sylvania Inc.*), provided it does not **foreclose competition** or create **market allocation issues**.
   - **Recommendation:** Include a **savings clause** in Clause 19 (Severance) to clarify that exclusivity is subject to applicable antitrust laws.

2. **Online Sales and Jurisdiction:**
   - **Geo-blocking** and **customer location verification** help enforce territorial restrictions but may raise **technical and UX challenges**.
   - **Recommendation:** Specify that the Distributor is **not liable for incidental sales** to out-of-territory customers if it implements **commercially reasonable controls**.

3. **Cross-Border Enforcement:**
   - **Passive sales** (unsolicited orders) are **less restrictive** under competition law than active solicitation.
   - **Recommendation:** Define "active solicitation" in Clause 1.1 to avoid disputes (e.g., targeted ads, trade shows, direct outreach).

4. **Supplier’s Direct Sales:**
   - **National accounts** often require direct supplier relationships. The **right of first refusal** and **commission** balance the Distributor’s interests.
   - **Recommendation:** Cap the Supplier’s direct sales in the Exclusive Territory at **no more than [X]% of annual revenue** to prevent circumvention.

   (b) Cross‑Border Sales: For any orders originating from or delivered to customers located outside the United States, such transactions shall not be deemed part of the exclusive territory, and such cross‑border sales shall remain on a non‑exclusive basis. The parties acknowledge that cross‑border transactions may be subject to additional regulatory and logistical issues, and the Distributor and Supplier agree to cooperate in good faith to address and resolve any such issues.”

This helps prevent circumvention of exclusivity through digital sales channels.

• It is recommended that any modifications be reviewed by counsel to address any potential conflicts or ambiguities with other provisions of the Agreement.

This proposed revision maintains the overall structure and tone of the Agreement while providing the necessary clarity on both geographic exclusivity and online/cross‑border sales.

### Revised Territory Clause

**Schedule 2 Territory**

**2.1 Exclusive Territory**

The exclusive territory for the purposes of this agreement (the "Exclusive Territory") shall be the states of California, Oregon, and Washington (collectively, the "Exclusive States"). The Distributor shall have the exclusive right to distribute the Products within the Exclusive Territory, and the Supplier shall not appoint any other distributor or sell the Products directly to end users within the Exclusive Territory during the Term of this agreement.

**2.2 Non-Exclusive Territory**

The non-exclusive territory for the purposes of this agreement (the "Non-Exclusive Territory") shall be all other states within the United States of America (the "Non-Exclusive States"). The Distributor shall have the non-exclusive right to distribute the Products within the Non-Exclusive Territory, and the Supplier may appoint other distributors or sell the Products directly to end users within the Non-Exclusive Territory during the Term of this agreement.

**2.3 Online Sales and Cross-Border Issues**

2.3.1 **Online Sales**

The Distributor may engage in online sales of the Products, provided that such sales are conducted in a manner that does not undermine the exclusive rights of the Distributor within the Exclusive Territory or the non-exclusive rights within the Non-Exclusive Territory. The Distributor shall ensure that its online sales platform clearly identifies the Exclusive Territory and Non-Exclusive Territory and complies with all applicable laws and regulations.

2.3.2 **Cross-Border Sales**

The Distributor shall not engage in sales of the Products to customers located outside the United States without the prior written consent of the Supplier. Any such sales shall be subject to the terms and conditions agreed upon by the parties in writing. **2.4 Inactive Territories**

Following the expiry of the Initial Term, the Supplier may amend the Territory to remove any Inactive Territories, as defined in clause 2.2 of this agreement.

# PROPOSED AMENDMENT TO DISTRIBUTOR AGREEMENT

## MINIMUM PURCHASE OBLIGATION CLAUSE

I recommend adding the following new Section 3.12 to the existing contract. This placement is logical as it follows the pricing and payment provisions already established in Section 3.

---

**[ADD] Section 3.12 - Minimum Purchase Obligations**

**3.12.1 Quarterly Minimum Purchase Requirement.** Power2Ship shall purchase from WLI Products and Licensed Programs having an aggregate purchase price of not less than Twenty-Five Thousand Dollars ($25,000.00) during each calendar quarter of the Term (the "Quarterly Minimum"). For purposes of this Section 3.12, a "calendar quarter" shall mean each successive three-month period commencing on January 1, April 1, July 1, and October 1 of each year during the Term. The first calendar quarter under this Agreement shall be the first full calendar quarter following the Effective Date.

**3.12.2 Calculation of Purchases.** For purposes of calculating whether Power2Ship has satisfied the Quarterly Minimum, the following shall apply:

(a) Only purchases of Products (hardware) pursuant to Section 3.1 shall be counted toward the Quarterly Minimum;

(b) Monthly License Fees paid pursuant to Sections 3.1 and 3.3 shall not be counted toward the Quarterly Minimum;

(c) Purchases of optional antennas pursuant to Section 3.9 shall be counted toward the Quarterly Minimum;

(d) The purchase price shall be calculated based on the actual amount paid by Power2Ship to WLI for Products during the applicable calendar quarter, excluding shipping costs, taxes, and any other ancillary charges;

(e) Products ordered and paid for in one calendar quarter but delivered in a subsequent calendar quarter shall be credited to the quarter in which payment was received by WLI.

**3.12.3 Shortfall Payment.** If Power2Ship fails to purchase the Quarterly Minimum during any calendar quarter (a "Shortfall Quarter"), Power2Ship shall, within thirty (30) days following the end of such Shortfall Quarter, pay to WLI an amount equal to twenty percent (20%) of the difference between the Quarterly Minimum and the actual amount of Products purchased during such Shortfall Quarter (the "Shortfall Payment"). The Shortfall Payment shall be in addition to, and not in lieu of, any other amounts owed by Power2Ship to WLI under this Agreement.

**3.12.4 Consecutive Shortfall Quarters - Termination Right.** If Power2Ship fails to meet the Quarterly Minimum for two (2) consecutive calendar quarters, WLI shall have the right, in addition to receiving Shortfall Payments for both quarters, to terminate this Agreement upon thirty (30) days' prior written notice to Power2Ship. Power2Ship may cure such default and prevent termination by: (i) paying all outstanding Shortfall Payments within fifteen (15) days of receiving WLI's termination notice; and (ii) placing a purchase order for Products totaling not less than the Quarterly Minimum, with full payment, within such fifteen (15) day period.

**3.12.5 Annual True-Up.** Notwithstanding the quarterly calculation set forth above, at the end of each twelve-month period during the Term (each, an "Annual Period"), the parties shall conduct a true-up calculation. If Power2Ship's aggregate purchases during an Annual Period equal or exceed One Hundred Thousand Dollars ($100,000.00), WLI shall credit or refund to Power2Ship any Shortfall Payments made during that Annual Period within thirty (30) days of the end of such Annual Period.

**3.12.6 Force Majeure Exception.** Power2Ship shall be excused from its obligation to meet the Quarterly Minimum, and no Shortfall Payment shall be due, for any calendar quarter during which Power2Ship's ability to purchase, accept delivery of, or resell Products is prevented, hindered, or delayed by a Force Majeure Event (as defined below). To invoke this exception, Power2Ship must:

(a) Provide written notice to WLI within ten (10) business days of becoming aware of the Force Majeure Event, describing in reasonable detail the nature of the event and its anticipated impact on Power2Ship's ability to meet the Quarterly Minimum;

(b) Use commercially reasonable efforts to mitigate the effects of the Force Majeure Event and resume normal purchasing operations as soon as reasonably practicable; and

(c) Provide WLI with periodic updates (not less than monthly) regarding the status of the Force Majeure Event and Power2Ship's efforts to mitigate its effects.

**3.12.7 Definition of Force Majeure Event.** For purposes of this Section 3.12, a "Force Majeure Event" means any event or circumstance beyond the reasonable control of Power2Ship, including but not limited to:

(a) Acts of God, including earthquakes, floods, hurricanes, tornadoes, severe weather, pandemics, epidemics, or other natural disasters;

(b) War (declared or undeclared), acts of terrorism, civil unrest, riots, insurrection, or armed conflict;

(c) Government actions, including embargoes, sanctions, import or export restrictions, quarantines, or other governmental orders or regulations that directly prevent or prohibit Power2Ship from purchasing or reselling the Products;

(d) Strikes, lockouts, or other labor disputes affecting Power2Ship's operations (but not including strikes or labor disputes solely affecting Power2Ship's suppliers or customers);

(e) Fire, explosion, or other casualty that materially damages Power2Ship's facilities or infrastructure necessary for receiving, storing, or distributing Products;

(f) Failure or disruption of public utilities, telecommunications, or internet services for a period exceeding five (5) consecutive business days;

(g) Cyber-attacks or data breaches that materially impair Power2Ship's ability to conduct business operations.

Notwithstanding the foregoing, a Force Majeure Event shall not include: (i) Power2Ship's financial inability to purchase Products; (ii) changes in market conditions or customer demand; (iii) Power2Ship's failure to obtain financing; or (iv) any event or circumstance that could have been avoided or mitigated through the exercise of reasonable care and diligence by Power2Ship.

**3.12.8 Duration of Force Majeure Relief.** The relief from the Quarterly Minimum provided under Section 3.12.6 shall apply only for the duration of the Force Majeure Event and its direct effects on Power2Ship's operations. If a Force Majeure Event continues for more than two (2) consecutive calendar quarters, either party may terminate this Agreement upon thirty (30) days' prior written notice to the other party, without penalty or liability to either party, except for obligations that accrued prior to the effective date of termination.

**3.12.9 Partial Quarter Relief.** If a Force Majeure Event affects only a portion of a calendar quarter, the Quarterly Minimum for that quarter shall be reduced on a pro-rata basis. The reduction shall be calculated by multiplying the Quarterly Minimum by a fraction, the numerator of which is the number of days during the quarter that the Force Majeure Event prevented Power2Ship from purchasing Products, and the denominator of which is the total number of days in that calendar quarter.

**3.12.10 No Double Recovery.** WLI's rights under this Section 3.12 are cumulative but not duplicative. WLI may not recover both Shortfall Payments and damages for the same failure to purchase Products. If WLI exercises its right to terminate this Agreement pursuant to Section 3.12.4, any Shortfall Payments already paid shall be credited against any damages WLI may seek for breach of this Agreement.

**3.12.11 Reporting.** Within fifteen (15) days following the end of each calendar quarter, WLI shall provide Power2Ship with a written statement showing: (i) the total purchase price of Products purchased by Power2Ship during such quarter; (ii) whether the Quarterly Minimum was met; and (iii) if applicable, the amount of any Shortfall Payment due. Power2Ship shall have fifteen (15) days from receipt of such statement to dispute any calculation in good faith, with supporting documentation.

## LEGAL ANALYSIS AND RECOMMENDATIONS

**Key Features of This Clause:**

1. **Clear Minimum Obligation:** The $25,000 quarterly minimum is unambiguous and easily calculable.

2. **Reasonable Consequences:** The 20% shortfall payment is a liquidated damages provision that is reasonable and not punitive, making it more likely to be enforceable.

3. **Escalating Remedies:** Two consecutive shortfall quarters trigger termination rights, providing WLI with meaningful recourse for persistent non-performance.

4. **Annual True-Up:** This provision rewards strong annual performance and provides flexibility, making the clause more commercially reasonable.

5. **Comprehensive Force Majeure:** The force majeure exceptions are detailed and balanced, protecting Power2Ship from circumstances truly beyond its control while excluding financial hardship and market conditions.

6. **Procedural Safeguards:** Notice requirements, cure periods, and reporting obligations ensure transparency and fairness.

**Potential Issues Flagged:**

- The shortfall payment mechanism should be reviewed to ensure it constitutes a reasonable estimate of WLI's damages and not an unenforceable penalty under applicable law.
- The force majeure definition excludes financial inability, which is standard but may be harsh in extreme economic circumstances.
- Consider whether the first quarter after the Effective Date should have a reduced minimum to allow Power2Ship to ramp up operations.

**Recommendation:** This clause strikes a reasonable balance between protecting WLI's interests and providing Power2Ship with flexibility and force majeure relief. The structure is commercially reasonable and should be enforceable under New Jersey law (the governing law per Section 16.1).

[ADD NEW SECTION 3.12 - MINIMUM PURCHASE OBLIGATIONS]

3.12 Minimum Purchase Requirements and Consequences

(a) Minimum Quarterly Purchase Obligation. During the Term of this Agreement, Power2Ship shall purchase from WLI a minimum of Twenty-Five Thousand Dollars ($25,000) worth of Products (the "Minimum Purchase Obligation") per calendar quarter (each a "Measurement Period"). For purposes of this Section, "Products" shall include all hardware units, Licensed Programs, and accessories purchased under this Agreement.

(b) Measurement and True-Up. Within fifteen (15) days following the end of each Measurement Period, WLI shall provide Power2Ship with a written statement of aggregate purchases during the preceding Measurement Period. If Power2Ship fails to meet the Minimum Purchase Obligation in any Measurement Period ("Shortfall Amount"), Power2Ship shall have thirty (30) days from receipt of such statement (the "Cure Period") to either:
   (i) Make additional purchases to cover the Shortfall Amount; or
   (ii) Pay WLI an amount equal to fifty percent (50%) of the Shortfall Amount as liquidated damages (the "Shortfall Payment"), which the parties agree represents a reasonable estimate of WLI's damages given the difficulty of calculating actual damages.

(c) Consequences of Continued Non-Performance. If Power2Ship fails to meet the Minimum Purchase Obligation in two (2) consecutive Measurement Periods and fails to cure such deficiency pursuant to Section 3.12(b), WLI may, at its sole discretion:
   (i) Convert Power2Ship's non-exclusive distribution rights to non-exclusive rights;
   (ii) Reduce Power2Ship's territory; or
   (iii) Terminate this Agreement upon thirty (30) days written notice.

(d) Force Majeure Exception. Power2Ship's failure to meet the Minimum Purchase Obligation shall be excused to the extent such failure is caused by a Force Majeure Event (as defined in Section 16.3), provided that:
   (i) Power2Ship provides WLI with written notice of the Force Majeure Event within five (5) business days of its occurrence;
   (ii) The Minimum Purchase Obligation for the affected Measurement Period shall be reduced proportionally based on the duration of the Force Majeure Event; and
   (iii) Power2Ship uses commercially reasonable efforts to mitigate the effects of such Force Majeure Event.

(e) Good Faith Adjustment. If market conditions materially change or if Power2Ship can demonstrate consistent good faith efforts to meet the Minimum Purchase Obligation (including documented marketing expenditures and sales efforts), the parties shall negotiate in good faith to adjust the Minimum Purchase Obligation for future Measurement Periods.

**Legal Analysis and Rationale:**

1.  **Placement:** The clause is inserted as a new Section 3.12, logically following the existing pricing terms (Sections 3.1-3.11) as it directly relates to purchase volume and pricing implications.

2.  **Clarity of Obligation (3.12(a)):**
    *   **Specific Amount:** "$25,000.00 per calendar quarter" clearly defines the monetary threshold.
    *   **Timeframe:** "per calendar quarter" and the definition of the "first calendar quarter" provide unambiguous periods for assessment.
    *   **Scope of Value:** Clarifies that the value is based on "Unit prices specified in Section 3.1 and 3.6, excluding any License Fees, taxes, shipping costs, or antenna purchases." This prevents ambiguity regarding what counts towards the minimum and ensures the focus is on product acquisition.
    *   **Commencement:** "Commencing from the Effective Date" ties the obligation directly to the start of the agreement.

3.  **Reporting (3.12(b)):**
    *   **Timely Reporting:** Requires Power2Ship to report within 15 days after each quarter, allowing WLI to monitor compliance promptly.
    *   **Content:** Specifies "total aggregate value of Products purchased," aligning with the obligation.

4.  **Consequences of Failure (3.12(c)):**
    *   **Threshold for Action:** "any two (2) consecutive calendar quarters" provides a reasonable grace period, preventing immediate punitive action for a single underperforming quarter, while still ensuring consistent performance. This balances WLI's need for commitment with potential market fluctuations for Power2Ship.
    *   **Discretionary Remedies:** WLI has "the right, at its sole discretion," to choose from several remedies. This provides flexibility for WLI based on the severity of the underperformance and the overall relationship.
    *   **Specific Remedies:**
        *   **Termination:** This is the most severe consequence and is explicitly linked to Section 14.1(a) (termination for cause), ensuring consistency with existing termination provisions.
        *   **Conversion to Non-Exclusive/Non-Preferred:** This is a less drastic step, allowing the relationship to continue but reducing Power2Ship's competitive advantage. It incentivizes Power2Ship to improve performance.
        *   **Adjust Pricing:** This allows WLI to recover potential lost revenue by adjusting future pricing, reflecting that Power2Ship is not generating the expected volume discounts.
    *   **Notice Period:** A 30-day notice period for WLI's chosen remedy provides Power2Ship time to understand and react.
    *   **No Relief from Other Obligations:** Explicitly states that failure to meet minimums does not excuse other contractual duties, particularly payment for goods received.

5.  **Force Majeure Exception (3.12(d)):**
    *   **Reference to Existing Clause:** Directly references Section 16.3, which already contains a force majeure provision, ensuring consistency.
    *   **Notice Requirement:** Power2Ship must provide timely notice of a force majeure event and its anticipated impact, allowing WLI to understand the situation.
    *   **Equitable Adjustment/Waiver:** The obligation is not simply removed but "equitably adjusted or waived," implying a discussion and agreement between the parties, and only for the "duration of such Force Majeure event."
    *   **Mitigation Duty:** Requires Power2Ship to use "commercially reasonable efforts to mitigate the impact," which is standard practice in force majeure clauses.

**Potential Issues/Considerations:**

*   **Definition of "Purchase":** The clause specifies "aggregate value of Products purchased." It's assumed this means *ordered and paid for* by Power2Ship, not necessarily *sold to end-users*. This is consistent with Section 7.1 ("Power2Ship must pay WLI for the Products in full on the day it submits a PO").
*   **Market Conditions:** While force majeure covers extreme events, it doesn't account for general market downturns or competitive pressures that might make meeting the minimum difficult. Power2Ship might argue for a "cure period" or a more flexible adjustment mechanism if they foresee such issues. However, for a minimum purchase obligation, the intent is usually a firm commitment.
*   **Remedy Selection:** While WLI has sole discretion, Power2Ship might prefer a tiered approach to remedies (e.g., first failure leads to pricing adjustment, second to termination). The current draft gives WLI maximum flexibility.
*   **Integration with Existing Clauses:** The clause is designed to integrate smoothly with existing sections, particularly Section 14 (Termination) and Section 16.3 (Force Majeure).

This clause provides a robust framework for a minimum purchase obligation, balancing WLI's need for commitment with reasonable exceptions.

Power2Ship shall provide WLI with written notice of the Force Majeure Event within ten (10) business days of its occurrence and shall use commercially reasonable efforts to mitigate the impact of such event on its ability to meet the minimum purchase obligation.

    (b) **Consecutive Failure.** If Power2Ship fails to meet the minimum purchase obligation for two (2) consecutive Quarters, WLI shall have the right, at its sole discretion and upon written notice to Power2Ship, to (i) convert Power2Ship's status to a non-exclusive distributor without minimum purchase requirements, which may result in less favorable pricing, or (ii) terminate this Agreement for cause in accordance with Section 14.1.

3.12.3 **Force Majeure Exception.** Notwithstanding the foregoing, Power2Ship's obligation to meet the minimum purchase requirement shall be suspended for the duration of any period in which Power2Ship's performance is prevented, delayed, or impaired by a Force Majeure Event. A "Force Majeure Event" shall mean any event beyond the reasonable control of Power2Ship, including but not limited to, acts of God, war, civil commotion, strikes, lockouts, labor disputes, fires, floods, explosions, governmental actions, embargoes, or national emergencies. Power2Ship shall provide WLI with written notice of the Force Majeure Event within ten (10) business days of its occurrence and shall use commercially reasonable efforts to mitigate the impact of such event on its ability to meet the minimum purchase obligation.

---

### **Legal Analysis and Justification**

1.  **Placement and Structure:** The clause is placed within Section 3 (Prices) as it directly relates to the financial obligations of the distributor. It logically follows the specific pricing mechanisms and precedes the general payment terms in Section 7.

2.  **Minimum Purchase Obligation (Section 3.12.1):**
    *   **Clarity:** The clause clearly states the $25,000 minimum per calendar quarter.
    *   **Commencement:** It specifies that the obligation begins in the first full quarter after the Effective Date, avoiding ambiguity for partial quarters at the start of the agreement.
    *   **Calculation Method:** It defines the purchase value as the net invoice price, excluding taxes, shipping, and recurring license fees. This is critical to prevent disputes over what counts toward the minimum. The focus is on the one-time purchase of hardware Products, which aligns with the distributor's primary role.

3.  **Consequences for Failure (Section 3.12.2):**
    *   **Shortfall Payment (Subsection a):** This provides a direct financial remedy for a single quarter's failure. It is a common and enforceable mechanism that compensates the supplier for the unmet commitment without immediately terminating the relationship. The 30-day payment window is standard.
    *   **Consecutive Failure (Subsection b):** This introduces escalating consequences for repeated failure, which is a fair and commercially reasonable approach. It provides WLI with two options:
        *   **Status Change:** This offers a less severe alternative to termination, allowing the relationship to continue under modified terms. This can be a valuable tool for preserving a business relationship that may have value despite the distributor's performance issues.
        *   **Termination:** This preserves WLI's right to terminate for cause, referencing the existing termination clause (Section 14.1) for consistency. The two-quarter threshold provides the distributor with a grace period to remedy performance issues.

4.  **Force Majeure Exception (Section 3.12.3):**
    *   **Standard Language:** The definition of a "Force Majeure Event" incorporates standard, well-established legal terms (acts of God, war, strikes, etc.), ensuring its enforceability.
    *   **Specificity:** It is tailored to this clause by specifying that the obligation is "suspended" rather than excused entirely, with the duration tied to the event's impact.
    *   **Procedural Requirements:** The requirement for written notice within 10 business days and a duty to mitigate are standard and essential components. The notice requirement allows WLI to plan accordingly, and the mitigation duty prevents the distributor from using the clause as a shield for poor performance.

5.  **Ambiguities and Potential Issues:**
    *   **Party Names:** The drafted clause uses "Power2Ship" and "WLI" to match the body of the provided agreement. However, the contract header lists the parties as "NexGen Analytics Inc." and "Quantum Insights Corp." This is a significant discrepancy in the source document. The clause has been drafted to be consistent with the operative text of the agreement. **This discrepancy should be flagged and rectified in the entire agreement.**
    *   **Product Definition:** The clause refers to "Products." The agreement defines "Products" in Section 1.1 as being limited to the G3001 GPSLink. This clause will apply only to those defined products. If the scope of products expands via amendment, this clause will automatically apply to the newly added products, which is the intended commercial outcome.

This drafted clause provides a clear, enforceable, and commercially balanced framework for ensuring the distributor meets a minimum purchase commitment while including necessary protections and exceptions.

[ADD] 17. MINIMUM PURCHASE COMMITMENT

17.1. Minimum Purchase Requirement. For each Calendar Quarter during the Term, Power2Ship shall purchase from WLI Products (hardware Units only, as “Products” are defined in Section 1.1) having an aggregate Net Purchase Value of not less than twenty-five thousand U.S. dollars (USD $25,000) (the “Minimum Purchase Commitment”). For any partial Calendar Quarter during the Term, the Minimum Purchase Commitment shall be prorated on a daily basis.

17.2. Definitions.
(a) “Calendar Quarter” means each consecutive three-month period ending March 31, June 30, September 30, and December 31.
(b) “Net Purchase Value” means the total dollar amount invoiced by WLI to Power2Ship for Products shipped in the applicable Calendar Quarter, exclusive of (i) any License Fees or other software or services fees, (ii) taxes, duties, shipping, insurance and other logistics charges, and (iii) credits, allowances, rebates, or returns.

17.3. Measurement; Carry-Forward. Excess Net Purchase Value in any Calendar Quarter (i.e., the amount by which Power2Ship’s Net Purchase Value exceeds the Minimum Purchase Commitment) may be applied as a credit toward the Minimum Purchase Commitment in the immediately succeeding two (2) Calendar Quarters only; thereafter, any unused excess expires. Shortfalls may not be carried back to prior Calendar Quarters.

17.4. Quarterly Statement; True-Up. Within fifteen (15) days after the end of each Calendar Quarter, WLI will provide Power2Ship a statement of Net Purchase Value for such Calendar Quarter. If the statement reflects a shortfall, then within thirty (30) days after receipt of the statement, Power2Ship shall either:
(a) place and pay for purchase orders in accordance with Section 7.1 for sufficient Products to cure the shortfall (with shipment to occur within a commercially reasonable time thereafter), or
(b) pay to WLI a shortfall fee equal to ten percent (10%) of the dollar amount of the shortfall (the “Shortfall Fee”). The Shortfall Fee is a reasonable estimate of WLI’s administrative costs and channel readiness expenses and is not a penalty. The Shortfall Fee shall be due within fifteen (15) days of invoice and shall accrue interest if unpaid in accordance with Section 7.6.

17.5. Consequences of Repeated Shortfalls. Payment of a Shortfall Fee does not satisfy or reduce any future Minimum Purchase Commitment. If (i) Power2Ship fails to cure a Quarterly shortfall as provided in Section 17.4, or (ii) Power2Ship incurs shortfalls (whether or not cured by Shortfall Fee) in any two (2) Calendar Quarters within any rolling four (4) Calendar Quarter period, such failure shall constitute a default under Section 14.1(a) and WLI may exercise its rights thereunder, including termination for cause upon written notice.

17.6. Excused Performance; Force Majeure. The Minimum Purchase Commitment for any Calendar Quarter shall be reduced proportionally (day-for-day) to the extent Power2Ship’s ability to purchase, or WLI’s ability to supply, Products is materially prevented or delayed by events described in Section 16.3 (Force Majeure). In addition, to the extent WLI is unable to fulfill one or more conforming purchase orders from Power2Ship during a Calendar Quarter solely due to WLI’s supply constraints or delays not caused by Power2Ship, the Minimum Purchase Commitment for that Calendar Quarter shall be reduced dollar-for-dollar by the value of the affected orders, or, at Power2Ship’s election, the measurement period shall be extended for a reasonable period to permit fulfillment.

17.7. No Waiver; Cumulative Remedies. WLI’s acceptance of purchases below the Minimum Purchase Commitment in any Calendar Quarter, or acceptance of a Shortfall Fee, shall not constitute a waiver of any future Minimum Purchase Commitment. The rights and remedies in this Section 17 are cumulative of, and in addition to, all other rights and remedies available under this Agreement and at law or in equity.

**17. MINIMUM PURCHASE OBLIGATION**

17.1 **Minimum Purchase Requirement.** Power2Ship agrees to purchase a minimum of $25,000 worth of Products from WLI per calendar quarter during the term of this Agreement. The calculation of the purchase amount shall be based on the net invoice price of the Products, excluding taxes, shipping, and other ancillary charges.

17.2 **Failure to Meet Minimum Purchase Requirement.** In the event that Power2Ship fails to meet the minimum purchase requirement in any given quarter, WLI reserves the right to take one or more of the following actions:

   a. **Notice of Default.** WLI may issue a written notice of default to Power2Ship, providing a 30-day period to cure the deficiency by purchasing the shortfall amount.

   b. **Suspension of Rights.** If the deficiency is not cured within the specified period, WLI may suspend Power2Ship's rights under this Agreement, including the right to distribute Products, until the deficiency is remedied.

   c. **Termination.** Persistent failure to meet the minimum purchase requirement for two consecutive quarters may result in WLI terminating this Agreement pursuant to Section 14.1(a).

17.3 **Force Majeure Exception.** Power2Ship shall not be liable for failing to meet the minimum purchase requirement if such failure is due to a force majeure event as defined in Section 16.3 of this Agreement. In such cases, Power2Ship must notify WLI in writing within ten (10) business days of the occurrence of the force majeure event, detailing the nature of the event and its expected impact on Power2Ship's ability to meet the purchase obligation.

17.4 **Quarterly Reporting.** Power2Ship shall provide WLI with a quarterly report detailing the total dollar amount of Products purchased during the preceding quarter. This report shall be submitted within fifteen (15) days following the end of each calendar quarter.

- A **quarterly minimum purchase requirement** of **$25,000**,
- **Consequences for non-compliance** (including liquidated damages and potential termination rights), and
- A **force majeure exception**.

The clause is designed to align with the contract’s existing structure, tone, and legal framework. Redlined modifications are marked for clarity.

### **[ADD] NEW SECTION 3.12 – MINIMUM PURCHASE OBLIGATION**
*(Insert after Section 3.11 and renumber subsequent sections accordingly.)*

**3.12 Minimum Purchase Obligation.**
**3.12.1 Obligation to Purchase.** During the term of this Agreement, **Quantum Insights Corp.** ("Distributor") shall purchase from **NexGen Analytics Inc.** ("Supplier") a minimum aggregate value of **Twenty-Five Thousand U.S. Dollars ($25,000.00) worth of Products (as defined in Section 1.1) per calendar quarter** ("Minimum Purchase Obligation"). The Minimum Purchase Obligation shall be calculated based on the **wholesale price of Products as set forth in Section 3.1 et seq.** and shall exclude any taxes, shipping fees, or other ancillary charges unless otherwise specified in writing by Supplier.

**3.12.2 Measurement and Reporting.**
(a) The Minimum Purchase Obligation shall be measured on a **quarterly basis**, with each quarter commencing on the first day of January, April, July, and October of each year.
(b) By the **15th day of the month following the end of each quarter**, Distributor shall provide Supplier with a **written report** (the "Purchase Report") certifying:
   (i) The total value of Products purchased during the prior quarter;
   (ii) The model numbers, quantities, and unit prices of such Products; and
   (iii) Any extenuating circumstances that may have affected Distributor’s ability to meet the Minimum Purchase Obligation.
(c) The Purchase Report shall be submitted in **Excel or PDF format** via email to **[Supplier’s designated contact/email]** and shall be deemed accurate unless challenged by Supplier in writing within **thirty (30) days** of receipt.

**3.12.3 Consequences for Non-Compliance.**
(a) **Liquidated Damages.** If Distributor fails to meet the Minimum Purchase Obligation in any quarter, Distributor shall pay Supplier **liquidated damages equal to ten percent (10%) of the shortfall amount** (the "Shortfall Damages"). For example, if Distributor purchases **$20,000** in a quarter (a **$5,000 shortfall**), Distributor shall pay Supplier **$500** in Shortfall Damages. Shortfall Damages shall be **due within thirty (30) days** of Supplier’s written demand and shall not limit Supplier’s right to pursue other remedies under this Agreement or at law.
(b) **Cure Period.** Distributor shall have **one (1) additional quarter** to cure a shortfall (the "Cure Period"). If Distributor meets or exceeds **one hundred twenty-five percent (125%) of the Minimum Purchase Obligation** in the Cure Period, the Shortfall Damages for the prior quarter shall be **waived in full**.
(c) **Termination Right.** If Distributor fails to meet the Minimum Purchase Obligation in **two (2) consecutive quarters** or **three (3) non-consecutive quarters** during any **twelve (12)-month period**, Supplier may, at its sole discretion, **terminate this Agreement upon sixty (60) days’ written notice** to Distributor, pursuant to Section 14.1(a).

**3.12.4 Force Majeure Exception.**
(a) Distributor shall not be liable for failure to meet the Minimum Purchase Obligation if such failure is **directly caused by a Force Majeure Event**, as defined in Section 16.3. For purposes of this Section 3.12, a **Force Majeure Event** shall also include:
   (i) **Government actions** (e.g., trade restrictions, embargoes, or regulatory bans) that prohibit or materially restrict Distributor’s ability to purchase or resell the Products;
   (ii) **Supplier’s material breach** of its obligations under this Agreement (e.g., failure to deliver Products as ordered or failure to maintain product quality); or
   (iii) **Market disruptions** (e.g., natural disasters, pandemics, or labor strikes) that **materially impair Distributor’s operations or customer demand** for a period exceeding **sixty (60) consecutive days**.
(b) To invoke the Force Majeure Exception, Distributor must:
   (i) Provide **written notice** to Supplier **within ten (10) business days** of the occurrence of the Force Majeure Event, including **detailed documentation** (e.g., government orders, news reports, or third-party certifications) evidencing the event and its impact;
   (ii) **Use commercially reasonable efforts** to mitigate the effects of the Force Majeure Event; and
   (iii) **Resume compliance** with the Minimum Purchase Obligation **within thirty (30) days** of the cessation of the Force Majeure Event.
(c) If a Force Majeure Event persists for **more than ninety (90) consecutive days**, either party may **terminate this Agreement upon thirty (30) days’ written notice** without liability.

**3.12.5 Non-Exclusivity.** The Minimum Purchase Obligation is **not exclusive** and does not restrict Distributor from purchasing similar products from third parties, provided that such purchases do not **conflict with Distributor’s obligations under Section 4 (Confidentiality) or Section 13 (Use of Trademarks)**.

**3.12.6 Survival.** The obligations under this Section 3.12 shall survive the **expiration or termination** of this Agreement with respect to any **unpaid Shortfall Damages** or **undisputed Purchase Reports** submitted prior to such expiration or termination.

---
### **Key Legal Considerations:**
1. **Liquidated Damages:**
   - The **10% shortfall penalty** is designed to be **proportionate and enforceable** under U.S. contract law (avoiding challenges as an unenforceable penalty). Courts typically uphold liquidated damages if they represent a **reasonable pre-estimate of actual damages** (e.g., lost profit margins, administrative costs).
   - **Alternative:** If Supplier’s actual damages are higher (e.g., due to high fixed costs), consider increasing the percentage or tying it to **Supplier’s average gross margin**.

2. **Force Majeure:**
   - Expands the existing **Section 16.3** to include **supplier-specific risks** (e.g., Supplier’s breach) and **market disruptions** (e.g., pandemics). This protects Distributor from **uncontrollable external events** while ensuring Supplier cannot invoke force majeure for **self-inflicted issues** (e.g., manufacturing delays).
   - **Documentation requirement** ensures Distributor cannot arbitrarily claim force majeure.

3. **Termination Rights:**
   - **Two consecutive misses** or **three misses in 12 months** triggers termination, balancing **Supplier’s need for reliability** with **Distributor’s operational flexibility**.
   - **Cure Period** incentivizes Distributor to recover without immediate termination.

4. **Reporting Obligations:**
   - Aligns with existing **Section 5 (Mandatory Reports)** to ensure **transparency** and **dispute avoidance**. The **15-day deadline** allows Supplier to **audit compliance** promptly.

5. **Tax/Fees Exclusion:**
   - Clarifies that the **$25,000 minimum applies to product value only**, excluding taxes/shipping (consistent with **Section 3.8**).

---
### **Recommended Cross-References:**
- **Section 14 (Termination):** Add a cross-reference to **Section 3.12.3(c)** under **Section 14.1(a)** to explicitly include **repeated failure to meet minimum purchase obligations** as a terminable offense.
- **Section 16.3 (Force Majeure):** Update to reference **Section 3.12.4** for consistency.
- **Section 8 (Audit):** Amend to allow Supplier to **audit Purchase Reports** under **Section 3.12.2** if discrepancies arise.

### **Potential Negotiation Points:**
1. **Distributor Pushback:**
   - **Minimum Amount:** Distributor may argue **$25,000/quarter is unrealistic** (e.g., if market demand is volatile). Consider:
     - **Tiered minimums** (e.g., $15,000 in Q1, scaling to $25,000 by Q4).
     - **Annual true-up** (allow shortfalls in some quarters if annual total meets **$100,000**).
   - **Force Majeure Scope:** Distributor may seek to include **economic downturns** or **customer insolvencies** as force majeure events. **Supplier’s Response:** Narrow to **objective, verifiable events** (e.g., GDP decline >5% in Distributor’s primary market).

2. **Supplier Pushback:**
   - **Liquidated Damages:** Supplier may prefer **higher penalties** (e.g., 15–20%). **Distributor’s Response:** Cap damages at **10–12%** to avoid punitive claims.
   - **Audit Rights:** Supplier may demand **unfettered audit access**. **Compromise:** Limit audits to **once per year** unless shortfalls exceed **20% of the Minimum Purchase Obligation**.
