Below is a **redlined mutual non-disclosure agreement (NDA)** based on the original one-way NDA embedded in the **Collaboration Agreement** between **Velocity Software Inc. (FMI)** and **Roche**. The revisions ensure **reciprocal confidentiality obligations** while preserving the original structure, tone, and key definitions.

### **Key Changes Summary**
1. **Reciprocal Confidentiality Obligations**: Modified **Section 16 (Obligation Not to Disclose Confidential Information)** to apply symmetrically to both parties.
2. **Definition of "Confidential Information"**: Expanded to clarify that **both parties** can be **Disclosing Parties** or **Receiving Parties**.
3. **Survival of Obligations**: Ensured mutual post-termination confidentiality obligations.
4. **Permitted Disclosures**: Standardized for both parties.
5. **Third-Party Disclosures**: Added reciprocal requirements for subcontractors/sublicensees.
6. **Return/Destruction of Confidential Information**: Made reciprocal.
7. **Governing Law and Dispute Resolution**: Retained as-is (already mutual).

>   (a) the **disclosing Party** provides the **other Party** with a **draft** at least **[10] Business Days** prior to release;
>   (b) the **other Party** may **request redactions** to protect its Confidential Information; and
>   (c) the **disclosing Party** shall **not unreasonably refuse** such requests.
>
> **16.4 Publications**
> If a Party (**"Publishing Party"**) intends to publish or present **any information related to this Agreement** (e.g., scientific papers, conference presentations), it shall:
>   (a) provide the **other Party** with a **draft** at least **[60] days** prior to submission;
>   (b) **delay publication** for up to **[90] days** if the other Party **objects in writing** to protect patentable inventions or Confidential Information; and
>   (c) **include the other Party’s contributions** (e.g., co-authorship, acknowledgments) where appropriate.

**Comment**:
- **Reciprocal rights** for press releases/publications.
- **Patent protection carve-out** (critical for IP-heavy collaborations).
- **Co-authorship acknowledgment** (fair credit for joint work).

Below is an example of redline text that converts a one‐way confidentiality arrangement into a mutual one. In the redline example below we assume that the original language (“one‐way”) referenced “the Disclosing Party” (and its Confidential Information) and imposed obligations only on the Receiving Party. In the revised version the same definitions and obligations apply equally to both Parties. (Note: Because the full agreement is very long, the redline below focuses on key parts – for example, Section 1.17 (Confidential Information) and Section 16 (Obligation Not to Disclose Confidential Information) – where a one‐way imbalance might typically appear. In practice, you would review additional confidentiality sections throughout the Agreement and ensure that any one‐sided language is made reciprocal.)

────────────────────────────────────────────
Example Redline Amendments to Convert the NDA into Mutual Form

1. Modification to the Definitions of “Confidential Information”

Original Section 1.17 (excerpt):
  “The term ‘Confidential Information’ shall mean any and all information, data or know‐how (including Know‐How), whether technical or non‐technical, oral or written, that is disclosed by one Party or its Affiliates (“Disclosing Party”) to the other Party or its Affiliates (“Receiving Party”). Confidential Information shall not include any information that… [list exceptions].”

Redline version:
  [MODIFY] “The term ‘Confidential Information’ shall mean any and all information, data or know‐how (including Know‐How), whether technical or non‐technical, oral or written, that is disclosed by either Party or its Affiliates (“Disclosing Party”) to the other Party or its Affiliates (“Receiving Party”). For purposes of this Agreement, each Party is both a Disclosing Party (when it discloses information) and a Receiving Party (when it receives information). Confidential Information shall not include any information that:  
   (i) was generally available to the public at the time of disclosure or later becomes available to the public through no breach of this Agreement by the Receiving Party;  
   (ii) was independently developed by the Receiving Party without reference to or reliance on the Disclosing Party’s Confidential Information (as evidenced by contemporaneous written records);  
   (iii) was known to the Receiving Party prior to disclosure by the Disclosing Party as evidenced by written documentation; or  
   (iv) is received from a Third Party without breach of any obligation of confidentiality.” [END MODIFY]

2. Modification to the Confidentiality Obligations

Original Section 16.1 (excerpt):
  “During the Agreement Term and for [X years] thereafter, a Receiving Party shall (i) treat Confidential Information provided by [the Disclosing Party] as it would treat its own information of a similar nature, (ii) take all reasonable precautions not to disclose such Confidential Information to Third Parties without the Disclosing Party’s prior written consent, and (iii) not use such Confidential Information other than for fulfilling its obligations or exercising its rights under this Agreement.”

Redline version:
  [MODIFY] “During the Agreement Term and for [X years] thereafter, each Party (i.e. each Party acting as a Receiving Party with respect to information received from the other Party) shall:  
   (i) treat the other Party’s Confidential Information with at least the same degree of care that it uses to protect its own confidential information of a similar nature (but in no event less than a reasonable standard of care);  
   (ii) not disclose or permit disclosure of the other Party’s Confidential Information to any Third Party without the prior written consent of the disclosing Party (except to employees, agents, or subcontractors who have a need to know and who are bound by confidentiality obligations no less protective than those contained herein); and  
   (iii) not use such Confidential Information for any purpose other than to perform its obligations or exercise its rights under this Agreement.” [END MODIFY]

3. Modifications to the “Permitted Disclosure” and “Press Releases” Sections

Original Section 16.3 (Press Releases) and Section 16.4 (Publications) may have been drafted one‐sided (requiring only one Party to provide notice to or obtain consent from the other). To ensure mutuality, amend these as follows:

[ADD] “All press releases, public statements, or disclosures regarding the existence or terms of this Agreement shall be issued only after both Parties have reviewed and approved the proposed language, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. Each Party agrees that if it intends to make any such press release or publication, it will provide the other Party with a copy of the proposed release at least ten (10) Business Days in advance for review.”

4. Cross‑Reference Changes

Throughout the Agreement any reference that assigns the role of “Disclosing Party” or “Receiving Party” in a manner suggesting a one‑way flow must be changed so that each Party is both a Disclosing and Receiving Party depending on the context of the disclosure. (For example, in any sections dealing with “use,” “non-use,” or “return” of Confidential Information, ensure that the language applies symmetrically.)

────────────────────────────────────────────
Summary:

• The definition of “Confidential Information” is now drafted in a mutual manner by stating that “each Party is both a Disclosing Party and a Receiving Party.”  
• Both Parties agree to protect the other Party’s Confidential Information by exercising (at minimum) a reasonable standard of care.  
• Permitted disclosures (including press releases and publications) require prior review and approval from the non‐disclosing Party.  
• All cross‑references are modified to remove one‑sided language so that confidentiality obligations run equally in both directions.

────────────────────────────────────────────
Conclusion

By incorporating the above redline changes (and reviewing all similar one‑sided terms throughout the Agreement), the NDA is converted from a one‑way to a mutual instrument. Both Parties will now share confidential information with the same degree of protection and reciprocal obligations. Please review these redline modifications in conjunction with the entire Agreement to ensure consistency and address any additional one‑sided provisions.

This sample redline is provided for guidance and illustrative purposes only. Before finalizing, please verify against the complete document and consult counsel to adapt any further details appropriately.

## EXPLANATORY NOTES

**Purpose of Amendment:** This residual knowledge exception clause balances the legitimate confidentiality interests of the Disclosing Party with the practical reality that individuals who work with confidential information will inevitably retain general concepts and ideas in their memories. This is a common provision in collaboration agreements in the life sciences and technology sectors.

**Key Protections Maintained:**
- The exception only applies to unaided memory, not documented information
- Intentional memorization is explicitly excluded
- Patent rights are preserved
- Trade secret protections under applicable law remain intact
- The burden of proof rests with the party claiming the exception

**Consistency with Existing Terms:** This provision is consistent with the Agreement's overall structure, which already contemplates various exceptions to confidentiality obligations in Sections 16.2 through 16.5. The residual knowledge exception is appropriately narrow and includes safeguards against abuse.

Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Agreement, the Receiving Party shall be permitted to use general ideas, concepts, know-how, and techniques that are retained in the unaided memories of its employees, officers, directors, or agents who have had access to the Disclosing Party's Confidential Information ("Residual Knowledge"). For purposes of clarity, Residual Knowledge does not include:  
(a) Any Confidential Information that the Receiving Party intentionally memorizes for the purpose of retaining and subsequently using or disclosing such information in violation of this Agreement; or  
(b) Any specific technical information, formulas, algorithms, processes, or other detailed proprietary information of the Disclosing Party.  

The Receiving Party's use of Residual Knowledge shall not create any license, right, title, or interest in or to the Disclosing Party's Confidential Information or intellectual property rights. This Residual Knowledge exception shall not limit any other obligations of confidentiality or non-use under this Agreement.

Based on my review of the Collaboration Agreement, I recommend adding a residual knowledge exception clause to Section 16.1 (Non-Use and Non-Disclosure). Nothing in this subsection shall be deemed to grant any right to the Receiving Party to disclose or use any specific Confidential Information that remains in the possession or control of the Receiving Party in any form other than unaided memory."

   - Maintains protection for specific confidential information in tangible form
   - Preserves the overall confidentiality framework

3. **Integration**: The clause fits logically within the existing confidentiality provisions and maintains the professional tone of the agreement.

4. **Risk Mitigation**: This balanced approach protects the disclosing party's proprietary information while acknowledging that general knowledge retention is inevitable and not actionable.

Below is a **residual knowledge exception clause** that can be added to **Section 16 (Obligation Not to Disclose Confidential Information)** of the Collaboration Agreement. This clause allows the Receiving Party to use general ideas, concepts, and know-how retained in memory after disclosure, provided they do not intentionally memorize proprietary information.

### **Proposed Addition to Section 16: Residual Knowledge Exception**
**[ADD]**
**16.6 Residual Knowledge Exception**
Notwithstanding any other provision of this Agreement, the obligations of the Receiving Party under Section 16.1 (Non-Use and Non-Disclosure) shall not apply to **general knowledge, skills, or know-how** retained in the unaided memory of employees, agents, or representatives of the Receiving Party after disclosure of Confidential Information, provided that:

1. **No Intentional Memorization**: The Receiving Party did not intentionally memorize or otherwise deliberately commit to memory any specific trade secrets, proprietary information, or other Confidential Information disclosed by the Disclosing Party;
2. **General Knowledge Only**: The retained knowledge consists of **general concepts, ideas, or skills** that are not specific, detailed, or proprietary in nature, and that could reasonably be retained by a person with similar expertise in the relevant field;
3. **No Reverse Engineering or Misappropriation**: The retained knowledge was not acquired through reverse engineering, improper means, or any violation of this Agreement or Applicable Law;
4. **No Use of Confidential Materials**: The Receiving Party does not rely on or reference any written, electronic, or other tangible materials containing Confidential Information when utilizing such residual knowledge; and
5. **No Disclosure of Specifics**: The Receiving Party does not disclose or use any **specific, detailed, or proprietary** aspects of the Disclosing Party’s Confidential Information, including but not limited to formulas, algorithms, customer lists, business strategies, or technical specifications.

For the avoidance of doubt, this exception does not permit the Receiving Party to:
- Disclose or use any **trade secrets** (as defined under Applicable Law, including the Defend Trade Secrets Act of 2016 or equivalent foreign laws);
- Reconstruct or recreate Confidential Information from residual knowledge; or
- Use residual knowledge in a manner that would compete with or harm the legitimate business interests of the Disclosing Party.

**[END ADD]**

---

### **Recommended Placement**
This clause should be inserted as a new **Section 16.6** within **Article 16 (Obligation Not to Disclose Confidential Information)**, following **Section 16.5 (Commercial Considerations)**. This placement ensures clarity and consistency with the existing confidentiality framework while addressing the specific issue of residual knowledge.

---

### **Key Legal Considerations**
1. **Alignment with Trade Secret Law**:
   - The clause is drafted to comply with trade secret protections under U.S. law (e.g., the **Defend Trade Secrets Act (DTSA)** and the **Uniform Trade Secrets Act (UTSA)**), which permit the use of general knowledge retained in memory but prohibit misappropriation of specific proprietary information.
   - Similar protections exist in other jurisdictions (e.g., EU Trade Secrets Directive), making this clause internationally adaptable.

2. **Avoiding Ambiguity**:
   - The clause explicitly distinguishes between **general knowledge** (permissible) and **specific proprietary information** (protected), reducing the risk of disputes over what constitutes residual knowledge.
   - The prohibition on **intentional memorization** ensures that the Receiving Party cannot exploit loopholes by deliberately committing Confidential Information to memory.

3. **Preservation of Business Interests**:
   - The Disclosing Party’s trade secrets and proprietary information remain protected, while the Receiving Party is not unfairly restricted from using **general skills or industry knowledge** gained through the collaboration.
   - The clause prevents the Receiving Party from reconstructing Confidential Information from memory, which could otherwise undermine the purpose of the NDA.

4. **Consistency with Industry Standards**:
   - Residual knowledge exceptions are common in NDAs, particularly in **R&D collaborations, joint ventures, and employment agreements**, where employees or partners may naturally retain general knowledge after exposure to confidential information.

[ADD] Residual Knowledge Exception.

Notwithstanding any provision of this Agreement to the contrary, the Receiving Party’s obligation not to use Confidential Information shall not apply to any general ideas, concepts, or know-how that the Receiving Party retains in its unaided memory (the “Residual Knowledge”), provided that such retention is solely the result of the Receiving Party’s independent skill, experience and professional training and is not attributable to any active or conscious effort to memorize or otherwise capture and reproduce the Disclosing Party’s Confidential Information. Explanation of Key Points:

1. Purpose and Scope:  
 • The clause permits the Receiving Party to use ideas or concepts that are retained in its unaided memory.  
 • It makes clear that only “general” ideas or know-how—resulting from common professional experience and not from an active effort to capture proprietary information—is exempt from the confidentiality restrictions.

2. Safeguard Against Abuse:  
 • The clause requires that the Residual Knowledge must not be the result of any intentional effort to memorize or reproduce Confidential Information.  
 • This preserves the core purpose of the Agreement—to protect the Disclosing Party’s specific proprietary information—while recognizing that some general knowledge may naturally be retained.

3. Consistency:  
 • The language is drafted in a manner consistent with the Agreement’s overall style and existing confidentiality obligations (e.g., Sections 1.17 and 16).

Implementation Considerations:

• Placement: Consider adding this clause immediately following the existing Confidential Information definition (or within the confidentiality obligations section) so that both Parties understand that such general knowledge is not considered a breach of the Agreement.  
• Cross-Reference: Where applicable, you might revise the relevant “non-use” language to incorporate a reference to the Residual Knowledge Exception.

This drafting provides a balanced approach that protects the confidential and proprietary information of the Disclosing Party while allowing the Receiving Party to benefit from its long‐term learning and general expertise accrued (as long as no deliberate copying of Confidential Information occurs).

**Summary of Changes and Rationale:**

1.  **Party Definitions (Preamble):**
    *   **[DELETE: SQUARE TWO GOLF INC., a New Jersey corporation (the "Company") and KATHY WHITWORTH, an individual residing at 302 La Mancha Court, Santa Fe, New Mexico 87501 (the "Recipient")]**
    *   **[ADD: NEXGEN ANALYTICS INC., a Delaware corporation ("NexGen") and INNOVATELABS LLC, a New York limited liability company ("InnovateLabs")]**
    *   **[ADD: (each a "Party" and collectively, the "Parties")]**
    *   **Rationale:** Replaces the original, irrelevant parties with the actual parties to the main contract (NexGen Analytics Inc. and InnovateLabs LLC) and introduces generic "Party" and "Parties" definitions for mutuality.
    *   **[DELETE: Company entering into said Endorsement Agreement with Recipient]**
    *   **[ADD: Parties entering into said Endorsement Agreement with each other]**
    *   **Rationale:** Makes the inducement clause reciprocal.

2.  **Definition of Confidential Information (Section (a)):**
    *   **[DELETE: Recipient acknowledges and agrees that communications for the purpose of proposing to work for or working for the Company have in the past or will entail the disclosure, observation and display to Recipient of information and materials of the Company that are proprietary, confidential and trade secret, which include, but are not limited to, golf equipment marketing plans, research, development and designs, computer software, screens, user interfaces, systems designs and documentation, processes, methods, fees, charges, know-how and any result from the work performed by InnovateLabs LLC, new discoveries, Intellectual Property (as defined below) and improvements to the Company's products made for or on behalf of the Company (all of which, singly and collectively, "Information").]**
    *   **[ADD: Each Party acknowledges and agrees that in connection with the Endorsement Agreement, it may receive or have access to information and materials of the other Party that are proprietary, confidential and trade secret, which include, but are not limited to, marketing plans, research, development and designs, computer software, screens, user interfaces, systems designs and documentation, processes, methods, fees, charges, know-how, new discoveries, Intellectual Property (as defined below), and improvements to products or services made for or on behalf of the disclosing Party (all of which, singly and collectively, "Confidential Information").]**
    *   **Rationale:** Generalizes the definition of "Information" (renamed "Confidential Information" for clarity) to encompass disclosures from *either* party to the *other*, removing the one-sided "Company" focus and the specific "golf equipment" examples.

3.  **Reciprocal Obligations (Throughout):**
    *   **[MODIFY: Information] [ADD: Confidential Information]**: Consistent renaming for clarity.
    *   **[DELETE: Recipient] [ADD: the receiving Party ("Recipient")]**: Defines "Recipient" dynamically based on who is receiving information.
    *   **[DELETE: Company] [ADD: disclosing Party]**: Defines "disclosing Party" dynamically.
    *   **Rationale:** Ensures that all obligations (use restrictions, disclosure prohibitions, exceptions, return of information, non-copying, non-reverse engineering) apply equally to whichever party is acting as the Recipient of the other's Confidential Information.

4.  **Permitted Use (Section (a)(i)):**
    *   **[DELETE: making proposals to or working under contracts with the Company]**
    *   **[ADD: fulfilling its obligations or exercising its rights under the Endorsement Agreement]**
    *   **Rationale:** Broadens the permitted use to reflect the mutual nature of the underlying Endorsement Agreement.

5.  **Disclosure Prohibition (Section (a)(ii)):**
    *   **[DELETE: NexGen Analytics Inc.'s written permission.]**
    *   **[ADD: Confidential Information to any third party without the disclosing Party's prior written permission.]**
    *   **Rationale:** Corrects a clear error in the original text ("NexGen Analytics Inc.'s written permission" was incomplete and out of context for the original one-way NDA) and makes the prohibition reciprocal.

6.  **Exceptions to Confidentiality (Section (b)):**
    *   **[DELETE: Recipient, its employees or agents] [ADD: the Recipient, its employees or agents, or any other party bound by a confidentiality obligation to the disclosing Party]** (in (b)(ii))
    *   **Rationale:** Clarifies that public knowledge arising from a breach by *any* party bound by confidentiality (not just the immediate Recipient) does not fall under the exception.

7.  **Survival of Obligations (Section (c)):**
    *   **[DELETE: Company] [ADD: Endorsement Agreement]**
    *   **Rationale:** Ties the survival to the completion of the overall agreement, not just "work for the Company."

8.  **Return of Information (Section (d)):**
    *   **[DELETE: Company] [ADD: disclosing Party]**
    *   **[DELETE: Company] [ADD: Endorsement Agreement]**
    *   **Rationale:** Makes the return obligation reciprocal and ties it to the overall agreement.

9.  **Non-Copying/Reverse Engineering (Section (e)):**
    *   **[DELETE: she] [ADD: it]**: Changes pronoun to reflect corporate entity.
    *   **[DELETE: Company] [ADD: disclosing Party]**: Makes the permission requirement reciprocal.

10. **Intellectual Property Rights (Section (f)):**
    *   **[DELETE: (entire section)]**
    *   **[ADD: This Section (f) is hereby deleted in its entirety as it pertains to work-for-hire and assignment of intellectual property, which is typically addressed in a separate agreement or the main Endorsement Agreement, and is not suitable for a mutual confidentiality agreement.]**
    *   **Rationale:** Section (f) is a work-for-hire and IP assignment clause, which is inherently one-sided (from "Recipient" to "Company"). It is inappropriate for a mutual NDA, which focuses on protecting *existing* confidential information. IP ownership and assignment should be handled in the main Endorsement Agreement or a separate IP agreement. Including it here would create complex and potentially conflicting reciprocal IP assignment obligations that are not the purpose of an NDA.

11. **Equitable Relief and Jurisdiction (Section (g)):**
    *   **[DELETE: Company] [ADD: other Party]**: Makes the acknowledgment of harm and right to seek relief reciprocal.
    *   **[DELETE: Federal and County Courts in Essex County, New Jersey] [ADD: state and federal courts located in New York, New York]**: Updates the jurisdiction to a neutral or mutually agreeable location, given NexGen is Delaware-based and InnovateLabs is New York-based. New York is a common choice for commercial disputes.
    *   **Rationale:** Ensures both parties have the same rights to seek equitable relief and establishes a mutually agreed-upon jurisdiction.

#### **1. DEFINITIONS**
**[ADD]**

**[MODIFY]**
2.1 **Reciprocal Confidentiality**. Each Receiving Party agrees to:
   (a) Use the Disclosing Party’s Confidential Information **solely for the Purpose** and not for any competitive or personal benefit;
   (b) **Not disclose** the Confidential Information to any third party without the Disclosing Party’s prior written consent, except to employees, agents, or advisors who:

A Receiving Party’s obligations under Section 2 shall not apply to Confidential Information that:

   (b) Is or becomes **publicly available** through no fault of the Receiving Party;

### **KEY FLAGS AND RECOMMENDATIONS**
1. **Ambiguity in "Purpose"**: The Parties should **explicitly define the business purpose** (e.g., "evaluating a joint venture for AI-driven analytics") to avoid disputes over permissible use.
2. **Term/Survival**: Added placeholder terms (e.g., 3-year term, 5-year survival). **Adjust based on industry standards** (e.g., trade secrets may require longer protection).

4. **IP Assignment**: **Removed unilateral IP assignment clauses** (original (e)-(f)) as they are **inappropriate for a mutual NDA** and should be addressed in a separate agreement (e.g., IP Assignment Agreement).
5. **Third-Party Disclosures**: Added **carve-out for "need to know" disclosures** to employees/agents, but ensure subcontractors are bound by **written NDAs**.
6. **Return/Destruction**: Clarified that **either return or destruction** is acceptable, with **certification required** for destruction.

- Confirm the **business purpose** (Section 1.2) with the Parties.
- Negotiate **term/survival periods** (Section 6).
- Verify **jurisdiction preference** (Section 7.1).
- If IP ownership is a concern, **draft a separate IP Agreement**.

# LEGAL ANALYSIS AND PROPOSED MODIFICATION

## Analysis

The current NDA contains standard confidentiality and non-use provisions but lacks a residual knowledge exception clause. This type of clause is increasingly common in modern NDAs as it balances the disclosing party's need to protect truly confidential information with the receiving party's practical ability to continue working in their field without fear of inadvertent breach.

**Current Relevant Provisions:**
- Section (a) defines "Information" broadly and imposes strict confidentiality obligations
- Section (b) provides standard exceptions (prior knowledge, public domain, independent source, legal process)
- Section (c) establishes perpetual confidentiality obligations

**Recommended Placement:**
The residual knowledge exception should be added as a new subsection (b)(v) within the existing exceptions framework in Exhibit A, as this maintains logical flow and groups all exceptions together.

## LEGAL CONSIDERATIONS

### 1. **Scope and Limitations**
The proposed clause carefully balances interests by:
- Allowing use of genuinely retained general knowledge
- Prohibiting intentional memorization of specific proprietary details
- Excluding trade secrets and specifically restricted information
- Preserving all IP rights (patents, copyrights)

### 2. **Key Protective Elements for NexGen Analytics Inc.**
- **"Unaided memory" requirement**: Prevents systematic extraction of information
- **No intentional memorization**: Addresses the concern about deliberate retention of proprietary data
- **Trade secret carve-out**: Maintains protection for the most sensitive information
- **IP rights preservation**: Ensures no implied license is granted

### 3. **Benefits for InnovateLabs LLC**
- Allows continued work in the field without fear of inadvertent breach
- Recognizes practical reality that individuals cannot "unlearn" general concepts
- Provides clarity on what can be used post-engagement

### 4. **Enforceability Considerations**
This clause is drafted to be enforceable because it:
- Uses objective standards ("unaided memory," "intentional memorization")
- Maintains protection for core proprietary information
- Reflects industry practice and reasonableness
- Is consistent with case law recognizing the impracticality of prohibiting all use of retained knowledge

### 5. **Potential Issues to Discuss**
- **Definition clarity**: The parties may wish to further define what constitutes "general ideas" versus specific proprietary information
- **Burden of proof**: Consider whether to specify which party bears the burden of proving intentional memorization
- **Industry context**: Given this involves golf equipment and analytics, consider whether specific technical data should be explicitly excluded

---

## RECOMMENDATION

I recommend adopting this residual knowledge exception clause as drafted. It represents a balanced approach that:
- Protects NexGen Analytics Inc.'s legitimate proprietary interests
- Provides InnovateLabs LLC with reasonable operational flexibility
- Reflects modern NDA best practices
- Should be enforceable in both Delaware and New York jurisdictions

The clause should be reviewed by both parties' counsel to ensure it aligns with their specific business objectives and risk tolerance.

Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Agreement, Recipient shall not be prohibited from using general ideas, concepts, know-how, or techniques that are retained in the unaided memory of Recipient's employees or representatives after termination or expiration of this Agreement, provided that:
     
          (i) such retained knowledge was acquired during the course of Recipient's engagement with the Company; and
          
          (ii) such use does not result from the intentional memorization of Confidential Information for the purpose of retaining and subsequently using such information in violation of this Agreement; and
          
          (iii) such use does not infringe the Company's intellectual property rights or violate any other provision of this Agreement; and
          
          (iv) such use does not involve the disclosure or reproduction of specific Confidential Information in any tangible form.

For purposes of this provision, "unaided memory" means memory without the use or reference to any documents, materials, or other Confidential Information in any form, whether written, electronic, or otherwise.

1. Balances protection of confidential information with reasonable use of general knowledge
2. Explicitly prohibits intentional memorization as a workaround
3. Maintains protection for specific confidential information
4. Uses clear definitions to prevent ambiguity
5. Preserves the Company's intellectual property rights
6. Follows the structure and style of the existing agreement

This clause follows the standard approach seen in modern confidentiality agreements while providing appropriate protections for both parties. The language is consistent with the existing agreement's level of formality and legal precision.

**Legal Analysis and Rationale for the Addition:**

The request is to add a "residual knowledge exception" clause. This type of clause is common in Non-Disclosure Agreements (NDAs) and aims to balance the disclosing party's need to protect its confidential information with the receiving party's practical reality that its employees will inevitably retain general knowledge and experience gained during the engagement.

**Location:**
The most appropriate place for this exception is within Section (b) of Exhibit A, which already lists other exceptions to the Recipient's confidentiality obligations. Placing it here ensures that it is clearly understood as a carve-out from the general non-disclosure requirements.

**Clause Language:**
The proposed language for the new sub-clause (v) is:

"[ADD] (v) that consists of general ideas, concepts, know-how, or techniques that are retained in the unaided memory of Recipient's personnel after exposure to the Information, without intentional memorization of specific proprietary details or trade secrets of the Company. This clause does not grant Recipient the right to disclose or use any specific Confidential Information, trade secrets, or copyrighted material of the Company. [ADD]"

**Rationale for Specific Wording:**

1.  **"general ideas, concepts, know-how, or techniques"**: This phrasing is standard for defining what constitutes "residual knowledge." It distinguishes general learning from specific, protectable confidential information.
2.  **"retained in the unaided memory of Recipient's personnel"**: This is a critical limitation. It means the Recipient cannot actively consult notes, documents, or other records to recall the information. It must be genuinely remembered without external aid. This prevents the Recipient from systematically extracting and using confidential data.
3.  **"without intentional memorization of specific proprietary details or trade secrets of the Company"**: This further clarifies the scope. It explicitly excludes any deliberate effort to commit the Company's core proprietary information or trade secrets to memory for later use. This addresses the "bad faith" scenario where an individual might try to circumvent the NDA by consciously memorizing sensitive data.
4.  **"This clause does not grant Recipient the right to disclose or use any specific Confidential Information, trade secrets, or copyrighted material of the Company."**: This is an important clarifying sentence. It reinforces that the residual knowledge exception is narrow and does not permit the use or disclosure of the actual confidential information itself, but rather the general, non-specific learning derived from it. This helps prevent misinterpretation and ensures the core protection of the NDA remains intact.

**Potential Issues/Ambiguities:**

*   **Subjectivity of "Unaided Memory" and "Intentional Memorization"**: While common, these terms can be subjective and difficult to prove or disprove in a dispute. What one person considers "unaided memory," another might view as a deliberate recall of proprietary information. Similarly, proving "intentional memorization" is challenging.
*   **Scope of "General Ideas" vs. "Specific Proprietary Details"**: There can be a fine line between a general concept and a specific proprietary detail, especially in highly technical fields. The effectiveness of this clause often depends on the specific facts and the interpretation of a court.

Despite these inherent ambiguities, residual knowledge clauses are widely accepted as a practical necessity in NDAs, acknowledging that human minds cannot be completely "wiped clean" of all general learning. The added language attempts to define the boundaries of this exception as clearly as possible to mitigate potential disputes.

Below is the proposed **Residual Knowledge Exception Clause** to be inserted into **Exhibit A** of the NDA. This clause ensures that the Receiving Party (Recipient) may retain and use general knowledge, skills, and concepts gained through exposure to the Disclosing Party’s (Company’s) confidential information, provided they do not intentionally memorize or misuse proprietary details.

---

### **Proposed Amendment to Exhibit A**
**Location:** Insert as a new subsection **(h)** under **Exhibit A** (following subsection (g)).

---

#### **[ADD] (h) RESIDUAL KNOWLEDGE EXCEPTION.**
Notwithstanding any other provision of this Agreement, the **Recipient** shall not be restricted from using **general knowledge, skills, concepts, or know-how** retained in the **unassisted memory** of its employees, representatives, or agents after exposure to the **Company’s Information**, provided that:

1. **No Intentional Memorization.** The Recipient and its personnel did not **intentionally memorize** or otherwise **actively commit to memory** any portion of the **Company’s proprietary or confidential Information** for the purpose of retaining or using such Information after termination of this Agreement;
2. **No Use of Confidential Materials.** The retained knowledge does not include **specific trade secrets, proprietary data, or other Confidential Information** as defined in this Agreement;
3. **No Reverse Engineering or Misappropriation.** The retained knowledge was not acquired through **reverse engineering, unauthorized copying, or any other improper means**; and
4. **No Unfair Competition.** The use of such residual knowledge does not **unfairly compete** with the **Company’s business** or **diminish the value** of its **Confidential Information or trade secrets**.

For the avoidance of doubt, this exception **does not permit** the Recipient to:
- Disclose or use **specific details, formulas, algorithms, customer lists, business strategies, or other proprietary materials** covered by this Agreement;
- Rely on **written, electronic, or other tangible records** of the Company’s Confidential Information; or
- Use residual knowledge in a manner that would **breach any other obligation** under this Agreement.

This provision shall not be construed to **limit the Company’s rights** under applicable **trade secret laws, copyright laws, or other intellectual property protections**.

---

### **Legal Analysis & Justification**
1. **Purpose of the Clause**
   - Balances the **Disclosing Party’s (Company’s) interest** in protecting proprietary information with the **Receiving Party’s (Recipient’s) legitimate need** to apply general industry knowledge and skills acquired through professional experience.
   - Prevents **overreach** by ensuring that the Recipient is not unfairly restricted from using **non-proprietary, general concepts** retained in memory.

2. **Key Protections for the Disclosing Party**
   - **No intentional memorization:** Ensures the Recipient cannot claim residual knowledge if they **actively memorized** confidential details.
   - **No use of specific proprietary data:** Clarifies that **trade secrets, customer lists, and exact methodologies** remain protected.
   - **No unfair competition:** Prevents the Recipient from using residual knowledge in a way that **harms the Company’s market position**.

3. **Compliance with Trade Secret Law (DTSA/UTSA)**
   - Aligns with the **Defend Trade Secrets Act (DTSA)** and **Uniform Trade Secrets Act (UTSA)**, which permit **general knowledge retention** but prohibit **misappropriation** of specific proprietary information.
   - Avoids **overbroad restrictions** that could be challenged as **unreasonable restraints on professional mobility**.

4. **Clarity & Enforceability**
   - Uses **precise language** to distinguish between **permissible general knowledge** and **impermissible use of confidential details**.
   - Explicitly **excludes reliance on tangible records**, reinforcing that residual knowledge must be **genuinely retained in memory**.

---

### **Recommended Placement in the Contract**
The clause should be inserted as **subsection (h)** in **Exhibit A**, immediately following **subsection (g)** (which addresses injunctive relief). This placement ensures logical flow:
- **(a-g)** Define confidentiality obligations and restrictions.
- **(h)** Carves out a **limited, reasonable exception** for residual knowledge.

     (f) Recipient further acknowledges and agrees that all new discoveries, inventions, improvements, processes, formulae, designs, drawings, training materials, original works of authorship, photos, video tapes, electronic images, documentation, trademarks and copyrights (the "Intellectual Property"), that may be developed, conceived, or made by Recipient, alone or jointly with others during her work for the Company, shall be the exclusive property of the Company and shall be deemed a work for hire. Recipient hereby assigns and agrees to assign all Recipient's rights in any Intellectual Property to the Company. Recipient hereby grants to the Company power of attorney for the purpose of assigning all Recipient's rights in Intellectual Property to the Company for the purposes of filings, registrations and other formalities deemed necessary by the Company to prosecute, protect, perfect or exploit its ownership and interests in Intellectual Property. Recipient further agrees to execute, acknowledge and deliver any documentation, instruments, specifications or disclosures necessary to assign, prosecute, protect, perfect or exploit the Company ownership of Intellectual Property.

     (g) Recipient acknowledges and agrees that the Company possesses valuable know-how, proprietary, confidential and trade secret Information that has been procured or developed by the Company at great expense and that its unauthorized disclosure would result in substantial damages to the Company that may not be adequately compensated by monetary relief. Accordingly, Recipient hereby consents to the jurisdiction of the Federal and County Courts in Essex County, New Jersey and agrees that the Company may seek temporary restraining orders against it or other extraordinary relief necessary to protect the Information.

# EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
## Joint Venture Agreement

---

## (A) PARTIES AND PURPOSE

**Parties:**
- **Tate & Lyle Fermentation Products Ltd.** ("T&L") – Delaware corporation, subsidiary of Velocity Software Inc.
- **Igene Biotechnology, Inc.** ("Igene") – Delaware corporation

**Purpose:**
The parties have formed a joint venture to manufacture and sell Astaxanthin and derivative products worldwide, excluding uses as neutraceuticals or for direct human consumption (the "Field of Agreement"). The joint venture structure consists of two entities: (1) an Operating Company organized as a Bermuda limited liability company owned equally by both parties, and (2) a Manufacturing Company organized as a UK corporation wholly owned by the Operating Company. The parties intend to capitalize on Igene's technology and expertise in Astaxanthin production and T&L's fermentation manufacturing capabilities, with initial target markets in Chile, Europe, Japan, and Asia.

---

## (B) FINANCIAL TERMS

**Capital Contributions:**
- **T&L**: $3,091,000 in cash ($91,000 initial + $3,000,000 upon formation), plus construction of a Manufacturing Facility valued at $21,614,000 (turnkey project capable of producing 14,000 kg per annum of pure Astaxanthin)
- **Igene**: Transfer of technology, intellectual property, and other assets related to Astaxanthin manufacturing (the "Transferred Assets")

**Ownership & Profit Sharing:**
- Each party holds a 50% interest in the Operating Company
- Profits and losses shared equally (50/50)
- All distributions, dividends, and returns of capital made equally to both parties

**Distributions:**
- **Minimum Distribution**: Annual distribution by March 15 equal to the larger of the two parties' estimated tax liabilities, with quarterly advance payments if required
- **Target Distribution**: Additional annual distribution equal to 20% of net income (subject to Board discretion)
- Additional distributions at Board's discretion

**Support Services:**
Both parties provide ongoing services to the Joint Venture at specified prices under separate Support Services Agreements, including sales/marketing, research, engineering, operations, and administrative services.

---

## (C) TERM AND TERMINATION

**Term:**
The Joint Venture continues indefinitely from the Effective Date (March 18, 2003), subject to termination provisions.

**Termination Rights:**

1. **Right of First Refusal** (Article 12.1): After one year from Effective Date, if either party receives a bona fide third-party offer to purchase its interest, the other party has 30 days to either (i) purchase the selling party's interest on the same terms, or (ii) sell its own interest to the selling party on the same terms.

2. **Event of Bankruptcy** (Article 12.2(a)): If either party has an Event of Bankruptcy, the other party may elect within 60 days to either (i) terminate the Joint Venture and liquidate, or (ii) purchase the bankrupt party's interest at market value determined by qualified experts.

3. **Deadlock Resolution** (Article 22.2): If Board disputes remain unresolved after escalation to Party Heads and specified time periods (18-54 months depending on issue type), either party may trigger a "buy-sell" mechanism by delivering an Offer Notice with a specified price. The receiving party must elect within 21 days to either sell its interest or buy the offering party's interest at the stated price.

4. **Mutual Agreement** (Article 12.2(b)): Parties may agree to terminate and liquidate at any time.

5. **Pre-Formation Termination** (Article 15.2): Either party may terminate before formation if governmental approvals are denied, adverse litigation determinations occur, material adverse changes arise, or the Effective Date doesn't occur by March 3, 2003.

**Transition Services:**
Upon termination, the departing party must provide support services for transition periods of 12-36 months depending on service type.

---

## (D) KEY OBLIGATIONS

**Governance:**
- **Board of Directors**: Six members (three appointed by each party); decisions require majority vote including at least one member from each party
- **Chairman**: Alternates annually between parties (Igene in odd years, T&L in even years)
- **General Manager**: Selected by Board to manage day-to-day operations (initial: Peter Boynton)

**Board Approval Required For:**
- Capital investments exceeding $50,000
- Distributions beyond Minimum Distribution
- Mergers, acquisitions, or asset sales over $50,000
- Incurrence of debt
- Contracts exceeding 12 months
- Annual business plans and budgets
- Changes to business purpose

**Non-Compete** (Article 7):
Both parties and their affiliates must completely withdraw from the Field of Agreement and may not engage in manufacturing Astaxanthin or developing/selling products in the Field of Agreement while owning an interest in the Operating Company, and for 10 years after transferring their interest (if Joint Venture continues as going concern).

**Future Developments** (Article 8):
- Any opportunities within the Field of Agreement discovered by either party must be offered exclusively to the Joint Venture
- Neutraceutical opportunities must be presented to the Board for acceptance/rejection
- Either party may purchase Astaxanthin from the Operating Company at Average Market Price for uses outside the Field of Agreement

**Support Services** (Article 11):
- Igene provides: sales/marketing, research services, contract administration
- T&L provides: engineering/operations, technical/research services, transportation/logistics, finance/accounting, utilities/waste treatment

---

## (E) RISK ALLOCATION PROVISIONS

**Representations & Warranties** (Article 14):
- Both parties warrant: valid corporate existence, authority to enter agreement, no material litigation (except disclosed Lawsuit), no bankruptcy proceedings
- **Igene specifically warrants**: (i) Technology and Transferred Assets constitute all relevant IP for the Field of Agreement, (ii) good and workable title free of liens (except pending Lawsuit), (iii) no infringement of third-party rights
- **T&L specifically warrants**: Manufacturing Facility will be constructed per specifications, free of liens, as turnkey project capable of producing 14,000 kg/year

**Indemnification** (Article 13):
Igene indemnifies T&L, the Operating Company, and their affiliates against all claims arising from actual or alleged IP infringement related to the Technology, including the pending Archer Daniels Midland lawsuit and any similar claims.

**Limitation on Recourse** (Article 3.7):
All Joint Venture debt shall be non-recourse against the parties. Neither party is required to contribute additional capital or guarantee Joint Venture obligations.

**Assignment Restrictions** (Article 17):
No assignment without prior written consent (not to be unreasonably withheld), except to wholly-owned subsidiaries with parent guarantee. No pledging or encumbering of interests without consent.

**Confidentiality** (Article 21.4):
Both parties must hold in confidence all technical, financial, and commercial information disclosed by the other party or the Joint Venture, with standard exceptions for public domain information, independently developed information, and legally compelled disclosure. Obligations survive termination for 5 years.

**Dispute Resolution** (Article 22.1):
Board disputes must be addressed in two quarterly Board meetings, then escalated to Party Heads for 30-day negotiation period before triggering buy-sell or liquidation mechanisms.

**Guarantee** (Article 21.10):
Tate & Lyle Industries Ltd. (Parent) guarantees T&L's performance of all obligations under the Agreement.

## Executive Summary: Joint Venture Agreement

**Contract ID:** contract_014
**Effective Date:** March 18, 2003 (as stated in the Agreement, though the document header lists April 30, 2023)

This Executive Summary outlines the key provisions of the Joint Venture Agreement ("Agreement") between Tate & Lyle Fermentation Products Ltd. ("T&L") and Igene Biotechnology, Inc. ("Igene") for the manufacture and sale of Astaxanthin and derivative products.

**(a) Parties and Purpose**

The parties to this Agreement are **Tate & Lyle Fermentation Products Ltd.** (a subsidiary of Velocity Software Inc.) and **Igene Biotechnology, Inc.** The primary purpose of the Joint Venture ("JV") is to **manufacture and sell Astaxanthin and derivative products worldwide** for all uses *other than* as a Neutraceutical or for direct human consumption (the "Field of Agreement"). The JV is structured as two legal entities: a Bermuda-organized limited liability company ("Operating Company") and a UK-formed corporation ("Manufacturing Company"). The JV aims to leverage Igene's technology and expertise in Astaxanthin manufacturing and T&L's expertise in fermentation and production.

**(b) Financial Terms**

*   **Initial Contributions:** T&L will contribute $91,000 in cash to the Operating Company, plus an additional $3,000,000 to capital upon Formation (Article 3.1). Igene will transfer and assign its "Transferred Assets" (technology and intellectual property related to Astaxanthin) to the Operating Company (Article 3.2).
*   **Manufacturing Facility:** The Manufacturing Company will enter into a Construction Agreement with T&L's Parent (Tate & Lyle Industries Ltd.) for the construction of a manufacturing facility for $21,614,000, to be capitalized by the Operating Company using T&L's capital contribution (Article 3.6).
*   **Profit/Loss Sharing & Distributions:** Profits and losses are shared equally (50/50) between the Parties as long as they maintain equal interest (Article 4.2). The Operating Company will annually declare and pay a "Minimum Distribution" by March 15, equal to the larger of the two estimated annual tax liabilities of the Parties, with quarterly advance payments (Article 6.2). An additional "Target Distribution" of 20% of net income will be paid annually, unless the Board determines otherwise (Article 6.3).
*   **Debt:** Any debt incurred by the JV is intended to be non-recourse against each Party, and neither Party is required to contribute additional capital or guarantee JV debt (Article 3.7).
*   **Service Charges:** The Operating Company will pay for Support Services provided by T&L and Igene or their Affiliates (Article 11.1.3).

**(c) Term and Termination**

*   **Indefinite Term:** The JV is envisioned to continue for an indefinite period, subject to termination in accordance with the Agreement (Recital E).
*   **Termination Events:**
    *   **Event of Bankruptcy:** If either Party experiences an "Event of Bankruptcy," the other Party may elect to terminate the JV (triggering liquidation procedures) or purchase the bankrupt Party's interest at market value (Article 12.2(a)).
    *   **Mutual Agreement:** The Parties may mutually agree to terminate the JV (Article 12.2(b)).
    *   **Dispute Resolution Failure:** If a Board Dispute remains unresolved after the specified dispute resolution procedures (Article 22.1), either Party may initiate a "buy-sell" mechanism (Article 22.2) or, if no such notice is sent, trigger liquidation (Article 22.3).
*   **Pre-Formation Termination:** Either Party may terminate the Agreement prior to Formation under specific conditions, including court orders prohibiting transactions, adverse determination of the "Lawsuit" (Archer Daniels Midland Corporation v. Igene Biotechnology, Inc.), material adverse changes to Transferred Assets, or failure of the Effective Date to occur by March 3, 2003 (Article 15.2).
*   **Right of First Refusal:** After one year from the Effective Date, a Party receiving a Third Party Offer to sell its interest must offer the other Party the right to purchase that interest or sell its own interest on the same terms (Article 12.1).

**(d) Key Obligations**

*   **Formation:** Parties must take all steps to create the JV entities promptly after execution (Article 2.2).
*   **Regulatory Approvals:** Parties must use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain necessary governmental consents, including HSR Act approval, sharing costs equally (Article 2.3).
*   **Contributions:** T&L to contribute cash; Igene to transfer Transferred Assets (Articles 3.1, 3.2).
*   **Withdrawal from Field of Agreement:** Each Party and its Affiliates must withdraw from the Field of Agreement and are prohibited from engaging in competing businesses globally while owning an interest in the Operating Company, and for 10 years after transfer of interest (Article 7.1, 7.2).
*   **Future Opportunities:** Opportunities within the Field of Agreement discovered by a Party must be exploited exclusively by the Operating Company (Article 8.1). Neutraceutical Opportunities must be presented to the Board for election (Article 8.2).
*   **Management:** The JV will be managed by a six-member Board (three appointed by each Party), with decisions by majority vote including at least one member from each Party (Article 9.1, 9.4). The Board appoints a General Manager for day-to-day operations (Article 9.5(a), 10.1).
*   **Support Services:** Each Party or its Affiliates will provide specified support services to the JV under separate agreements (Article 11.1).
*   **Confidentiality:** Parties agree to hold confidential and not disclose or use proprietary information (Article 21.4).
*   **Guarantee:** Tate & Lyle Industries Ltd. guarantees T&L's performance (Article 21.10).

**(e) Risk Allocation Provisions**

*   **Indemnification:** Igene indemnifies T&L and the JV entities against claims arising from actual or alleged infringement of intellectual property rights related to the Technology, including the pending "Lawsuit" (Article 13.1).
*   **Warranties:**
    *   **General:** Each Party warrants its corporate standing, authority, enforceability of the Agreement, absence of material liens on Transferred Assets (except for taxes/materialsmen's liens), and disclosure of material adverse facts (Article 14.1.1).
    *   **Litigation/Bankruptcy:** Each Party warrants no pending or threatened litigation or bankruptcy proceedings that would materially adversely affect its business or the JV, except for the Lawsuit (Article 14.1.2, 14.1.3).
    *   **Igene Specific:** Igene warrants that the Transferred Assets constitute all relevant know-how/IP for the Field of Agreement, it has clear title to them (except for the Lawsuit), and they do not infringe third-party rights (Article 14.2, 14.3).
    *   **T&L Specific:** T&L warrants that the Manufacturing Facility will be constructed as a turnkey project capable of producing 14,000 kg/year of Astaxanthin, free of liens (Article 14.4).
*   **Dispute Resolution:** A multi-tiered dispute resolution process is outlined, starting with Board negotiations, escalating to "Party Heads," and potentially leading to a "buy-sell" mechanism or liquidation if unresolved (Article 22).
*   **Limitations on JV Actions:** The Board's authority is subject to specific shareholder instructions for dissolution, sale of substantially all assets, or engaging in material commerce outside the Field of Agreement (Article 9.6).
*   **Tax Estimates:** A process for determining and approving Party Tax Estimates is established, involving a Neutral Auditor if there is a dispute (Article 6.1).
*   **Material Adverse Change:** Either Party may terminate the Agreement prior to Formation if there is a material adverse change outside its control regarding the other Party's Transferred Assets (Article 15.2(D)).

# EXECUTIVE SUMMARY: JOINT VENTURE AGREEMENT

## (a) Parties and Purpose
This Joint Venture Agreement establishes a collaboration between **Tate & Lyle Fermentation Products Ltd.** (T&L) and **Igene Biotechnology, Inc.** (Igene) to manufacture and sell Astaxanthin and derivative products worldwide, excluding neutraceutical uses. The joint venture structure comprises two entities: an Operating Company (Bermuda LLC) and a Manufacturing Company (UK corporation). The primary market initially targets Chile, parts of Europe, Japan, and other Asian regions.

## (b) Financial Terms
- **Contributions:** T&L contributes $91,000 cash plus $3,000,000 capital; Igene transfers technology and related assets (Transferred Assets)
- **Ownership:** Equal 50/50 ownership interest in Operating Company
- **Construction:** Manufacturing Facility construction cost of $21,614,000 (turnkey project)
- **Distributions:** 
  - Minimum Distribution (estimated tax liabilities)
  - Target Distribution (20% of net income)
  - Additional discretionary distributions
- **Financing:** Joint Venture debt to be non-recourse against parties; no additional capital contributions or guarantees required

## (c) Term and Termination
- **Term:** Indefinite period commencing Effective Date (March 3, 2003)
- **Termination Triggers:** 
  - Event of Bankruptcy (Article 12.2)
  - Mutual agreement
  - Deadlock resolution procedures
  - Material breach conditions
- **Exit Mechanisms:** Right of First Refusal after one year; tag-along rights; buy-sell provisions upon deadlock; liquidation procedures (Article 22.3)

## (d) Key Obligations
- **T&L Obligations:** Engineering/operations services, technical/research services, transportation/logistics, finance/accounting, utilities/waste treatment services
- **Igene Obligations:** Sales/marketing services, research services, manufacturing contract administration
- **Exclusivity:** Both parties must withdraw from Field of Agreement and refrain from competing activities (10-year post-exit restriction)
- **Support Services:** Ongoing services provided via Support Services Agreements with transition periods upon ownership transfer

## (e) Risk Allocation Provisions
- **Indemnification:** Igene indemnifies T&L for IP infringement claims related to Technology (Article 13)
- **Warranties:** Mutual representations regarding corporate authority, asset ownership, litigation status, and bankruptcy (Article 14)
- **Bankruptcy Protection:** Non-breaching party may terminate or purchase bankrupt party's interest at market value
- **Deadlock Resolution:** Multi-tiered dispute resolution culminating in buy-sell mechanism (Article 22)
- **Confidentiality:** Five-year post-termination confidentiality obligations for proprietary information
- **Limitation of Liability:** No personal liability for parties beyond their investments (non-recourse debt structure)

Executive Summary – Joint Venture Agreement (Execution Copy)

(a) Parties and Purpose
- Parties: Tate & Lyle Fermentation Products Ltd. (“T&L,” England) and Igene Biotechnology, Inc. (“Igene,” Maryland) (together, the “Parties”). Parent guarantor: Tate & Lyle Industries Ltd. (“Parent”) guarantees T&L’s performance (Art. 21.10). Note: Cover page metadata lists different parties and dates; the operative agreement is between T&L and Igene with Effective Date March 3, 2003 (Art. 1.9).
- Purpose/Scope: Form a jointly controlled venture to manufacture and sell Astaxanthin and derivative products worldwide, except for neutraceutical/direct human consumption uses (the “Field of Agreement”) (Art. 2.1; Recitals A–E).
- Structure: Operating Company (Bermuda LLC) owned 50/50 by the Parties; it owns Manufacturing Company (UK company) (Art. 2.2). Facilities to be located at Selby, England (Arts. 1.21, 3.5–3.6).

(b) Financial Terms
- Initial Contributions: T&L contributes $91,000 at signing, plus $3,000,000 to the Operating Company upon Formation (Art. 3.1). Igene contributes “Transferred Assets” (Technology, Brands, and related IP/know-how listed in Appendices) to the Operating Company, free of liens (Arts. 3.2–3.4, 14.2).
- Construction/Capitalization: Manufacturing Facility built under a turnkey Construction Agreement supervised by Parent for $21,614,000; Operating Company capitalizes Manufacturing Company with at least that amount (Arts. 3.5–3.6).
- Debt: Intended to be non-recourse to the Parties; no obligation for additional capital or guarantees by either Party (Art. 3.7).
- Economics: Equal 50/50 ownership and equal sharing of profits/losses while each holds 50% (Art. 4.1–4.2). Special adjustment if T&L’s contribution proves materially less valuable due to Facilities not being constructed as provided (cash true-up or revaluation and potential liquidation; Art. 4.3).
- Distributions: Annual “Minimum Distribution” to each Party to cover taxes, equal to the larger of the approved Party tax estimates; paid quarterly in advance as needed and trued up by March 15 (Arts. 6.1–6.2). Additional annual “Target Distribution” equal to 20% of net income (50/50 to the Parties), unless the Board determines otherwise (Art. 6.3). Other distributions at Board discretion and subject to law (Arts. 6.4–6.5).

(c) Term and Termination
- Duration: Indefinite, subject to termination under the Agreement (Recital E; Art. 2.1).
- Pre-Formation Conditions/Termination: Obligations conditioned on required approvals (HSR/competition and other governmental, board approvals; Art. 15.1). Either Party may terminate pre-Formation for specified legal/regulatory impediments, adverse outcomes in the pending ADM lawsuit or other material adverse litigation/changes (Art. 15.2).
- Transfers/ROFR: No transfers in first year post-Effective Date; thereafter, a Party receiving a good-faith third-party cash offer for its entire interest must give the other Party a right to either buy the Selling Party’s interest or require the Selling Party to buy the Offeree’s interest on the same terms (Art. 12.1).
- Bankruptcy: On an Event of Bankruptcy of a Party, the other may terminate and liquidate or purchase the bankrupt Party’s interest at market value per appraisal mechanism (Art. 12.2).
- Deadlock/Buy–Sell: Unresolved Board disputes escalate to Party Heads; if still unresolved, a timed buy–sell (Offer Notice) mechanism allows either Party to force a buy or sell at the named price after stated waiting periods tied to Commencement/Effective Dates (Art. 22.1–22.2).
- Liquidation: Procedures include potential short period of continued operations to sell as a going concern; proceeds distributed by capital accounts (Art. 22.3).

(d) Key Obligations
- Non-Compete/Withdrawal: Each Party and its Affiliates must withdraw from the Field of Agreement globally as of the Effective Date and not compete while an owner; if a Party exits and the JV remains a going concern, the non-compete continues for 10 years (Art. 7.1–7.2; with blue-pencil provision).
- Opportunity/Technology: Field opportunities discovered by a Party must be offered exclusively to the Operating Company; neutraceutical opportunities must be presented to the Board for election (Arts. 8.1–8.2). JV-developed processes/products with applications outside the Field must be offered for license to the Parties on reasonable commercial terms (Art. 8.3).
- Supply for Non-Field Uses: Either Party may buy Astaxanthin from the Operating Company for non-Field uses (e.g., neutraceuticals) at Average Market Price; further processing at that Party’s cost (Art. 8.4).
- Governance: Six-person Board (3 appointed by each Party; no UK residents), with majority vote including at least one director from each Party and extensive list of reserved matters (Arts. 9.1–9.6, 10.1–10.2).
- Services: Each Party provides defined support services to the JV under Support Services Agreements (sales/marketing, R&D, engineering/operations, logistics, finance/accounting, utilities/waste), reimbursed by the Operating Company; transition service obligations apply upon ownership changes (Arts. 11.1–11.3).
- Site/Facility: Parent leases the Site to Manufacturing Company for 50 years at $1/year and manages turnkey construction; facility to produce 14,000 kg/year of pure Astaxanthin (Arts. 1.21, 3.5–3.6, 14.4).
- Confidentiality; Assignment Limits: Robust confidentiality with exceptions (Art. 21.4); assignment and pledging restrictions with limited affiliate assignment and required guarantees (Art. 17).

(e) Risk Allocation Provisions
- Indemnity: Igene indemnifies T&L, the JV entities, and their officers/directors for IP infringement claims arising from the Technology, including risks related to the pending Archer Daniels Midland v. Igene litigation (Art. 13.1). No reciprocal indemnity from T&L, though T&L provides facility-related warranties (Art. 14.4).
- Warranties: Mutual corporate authority and no-liens warranties (Art. 14.1). Igene warrants title and non-infringement for Technology/Brands/Transferred Assets (Arts. 14.2–14.3). T&L warrants turnkey construction, lien-free facility, and output capacity (Art. 14.4).
- Non-Recourse Debt/No Additional Capital: JV debt intended to be non-recourse to the Parties; no obligation to contribute additional capital or guarantee JV obligations (Art. 3.7).
- Dispute Resolution/Exit: Structured deadlock resolution with buy–sell and liquidation mechanisms (Arts. 22.1–22.3).
- Parent Guarantee: Parent guarantees T&L’s obligations, enhancing counterparty risk coverage (Art. 21.10).

Notable Issues/Ambiguities to Flag
- Party/Date Inconsistencies: The cover metadata lists different parties and an Effective Date of April 30, 2023; the body governs with Parties T&L/Igene and Effective Date March 3, 2003 (Art. 1.9). The opening paragraph appears to misstate T&L as a “subsidiary of Velocity Software Inc.” which is likely a drafting error.
- Asymmetric Indemnity: Igene bears broad IP indemnity without a corresponding indemnity from T&L; no stated caps.
- Non-Compete Scope: Worldwide, up to 10 years post-exit; enforceability may vary by jurisdiction (Art. 7.2).
- Cash Flow Strain: Tax “Minimum Distribution” equals the higher of the Parties’ tax estimates paid to both Parties, potentially leading to over-distribution relative to one Party’s tax needs and JV cash constraints (Arts. 6.1–6.2).
- Support Services Pricing/Scope: Material terms are in separate Support Services Agreements not included here; potential cost/scope uncertainty (Art. 11).

**Executive Summary of Joint Venture Agreement**

**(a) Parties and Purpose:**
The Joint Venture Agreement is between Tate & Lyle Fermentation Products Ltd. ("T&L"), a subsidiary of Velocity Software Inc., and Igene Biotechnology, Inc. ("Igene"). The purpose of the agreement is to form a joint venture for the manufacture and sale of Astaxanthin and derivative products worldwide, excluding uses as a Neutraceutical or for direct human consumption. The joint venture aims to leverage the technological expertise of Igene and the fermentation production capabilities of T&L.

**(b) Financial Terms:**
T&L will contribute $91,000 in cash and an additional $3,000,000 upon formation to the Operating Company. Igene will transfer certain assets, including technology and intellectual property, to the Operating Company. The joint venture will be structured as a limited liability company in Bermuda, with a subsidiary in the UK. Profits and losses will be shared equally, and any debt incurred by the joint venture will be non-recourse to the parties.

**(c) Term and Termination:**
The joint venture is intended to continue indefinitely but can be terminated under specific conditions, such as an Event of Bankruptcy or mutual agreement. The agreement includes a right of first refusal for either party to purchase the other's interest in the event of a proposed sale to a third party after one year from the effective date.

**(d) Key Obligations:**
- **Contributions:** T&L and Igene are responsible for their respective contributions to the joint venture, including financial and asset transfers.
- **Management:** The joint venture will be managed by a board of directors with equal representation from both parties. Day-to-day operations will be overseen by a General Manager.
- **Services:** Both parties will provide ongoing services to the joint venture, such as sales, marketing, engineering, and logistics, as outlined in separate support services agreements.

**(e) Risk Allocation Provisions:**
- **Indemnification:** Igene will indemnify T&L and related entities against claims related to intellectual property infringements.
- **Warranties:** Both parties provide warranties regarding their corporate status, authority to enter the agreement, and the condition of transferred assets.
- **Dispute Resolution:** Disputes will be resolved through negotiation, with escalation to party heads if necessary. If unresolved, a buy-sell mechanism is triggered.

This summary highlights the essential elements of the Joint Venture Agreement, focusing on the roles and responsibilities of the parties, financial commitments, and mechanisms for managing risks and resolving disputes.

# Executive Summary: Joint Venture Agreement between Tate & Lyle Fermentation Products Ltd. and Igene Biotechnology, Inc.

**Date:** March 18, 2003 (Effective Date: March 3, 2003)  
**Contract ID:** contract_014 (Joint Venture Agreement for Astaxanthin Production)

This executive summary provides a high-level overview of the key elements of the Joint Venture Agreement (the "Agreement") between Tate & Lyle Fermentation Products Ltd. ("T&L"), an English corporation and subsidiary of Tate & Lyle Industries Ltd., and Igene Biotechnology, Inc. ("Igene"), a Maryland corporation (collectively, the "Parties"). The Agreement establishes a joint venture for the manufacture and sale of Astaxanthin and derivative products. References to specific sections are included for clarity.

### (a) Parties and Purpose
The Parties are T&L and Igene, each contributing complementary expertise: Igene provides technology and know-how for Astaxanthin production, while T&L offers fermentation manufacturing capabilities (Recitals A-B). The purpose is to form a joint venture (the "Joint Venture") to manufacture, market, and sell Astaxanthin and derivatives worldwide within the "Field of Agreement," which excludes neutraceuticals or direct human consumption (Article 2.1). The Joint Venture consists of a Bermuda limited liability company (the "Operating Company") owned equally by the Parties, which in turn owns a UK corporation (the "Manufacturing Company") for production operations (Article 2.2). The primary initial markets are Chile, Europe, Japan, and Asia, with the Joint Venture operating independently but receiving initial support from the Parties (Recitals C-D).

### (b) Financial Terms
The Parties each hold a 50% interest in the Operating Company, with contributions valued equally (Article 4.1). T&L contributes $91,000 in cash initially and $3,000,000 upon formation, plus oversight of a $21,614,000 turnkey construction of a manufacturing facility in Selby, England, capable of producing 14,000 kg of pure Astaxanthin annually (Articles 3.1, 3.6). Igene contributes Transferred Assets, including technology, intellectual property, and brands (free of encumbrances except a specified lawsuit) (Articles 3.2, 3.4; Appendix 3.2). Profits, losses, distributions, dividends, and allocations are shared equally (Article 4.2). Key distributions include: (i) annual Minimum Distributions by March 15 to cover estimated tax liabilities (calculated per Party Tax Estimates, with disputes resolved by a Neutral Auditor) (Article 6.1-6.2); (ii) Target Distributions of 20% of net income (Article 6.3); and (iii) discretionary distributions (Article 6.4), all subject to applicable law (Article 6.5). Debt is non-recourse to the Parties, with efforts to secure third-party financing (Article 3.7). No additional capital contributions or guarantees are required.

### (c) Term and Termination
The Joint Venture is intended to continue indefinitely, subject to termination provisions (Recital E). Termination may occur upon: (i) mutual agreement (Article 12.2(b)); (ii) an Event of Bankruptcy of one Party, allowing the other to buy out or liquidate (Article 12.2(a)); (iii) unresolved Board Disputes after negotiation, triggering a buy-sell mechanism where one Party offers a price and the other elects to buy or sell (Article 22.2, with restrictions before 18-54 months post-Commencement/Effective Date); or (iv) failure of conditions precedent, material adverse changes, or litigation (Article 15.2). Post-1 year from Effective Date, transfers are subject to right of first refusal and tag-along rights (Article 12.1). Upon termination, liquidation follows, with proceeds distributed proportionally after expenses (Article 22.3).

### (d) Key Obligations
The Parties must withdraw from the Field of Agreement and adhere to a 10-year non-compete post-transfer if the Joint Venture continues (Articles 7.1-7.2). They must present future opportunities in the Field or neutraceutical uses to the Joint Venture (Articles 8.1-8.2). Management is via a six-member Board (three appointees each), with majority decisions requiring one vote from each Party's appointees (Articles 9.1, 9.4); deadlocks trigger dispute resolution (Article 9.5). Day-to-day operations are delegated to a General Manager (initially Peter Boynton) (Article 10.1). Parties provide support services (e.g., Igene: sales/marketing/research; T&L: engineering/finance) via agreements, with fees reimbursed (Article 11). Assignments require consent, except to wholly-owned affiliates (Article 17). Confidentiality and non-disclosure obligations apply for five years post-termination (Article 21.4).

### (e) Risk Allocation Provisions
Risk is allocated through indemnification, warranties, and limitations. Igene indemnifies T&L, Affiliates, and Joint Venture entities against IP infringement claims, including the pending Archer Daniels Midland lawsuit (Article 13.1). Mutual warranties cover corporate authority, no liens on assets, no material litigation (except the lawsuit), and no bankruptcy (Article 14.1). Igene specifically warrants title to and non-infringement of Transferred Assets (Articles 14.2-14.3); T&L warrants facility construction (Article 14.4). Liabilities are non-recourse for debt (Article 3.7). Disputes are resolved via negotiation, buy-sell, or liquidation (Article 22); governed by Delaware law (Article 20). Costs and taxes are borne by the Joint Venture, except income taxes by the transferring Party (Article 18). Parent (Tate & Lyle Industries Ltd.) guarantees T&L's performance (Article 21.10).

This summary highlights core elements; refer to the full Agreement for details. Potential issues include IP litigation risks (Article 13) and deadlock resolution dependencies (Article 22).
